Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Detect Thoughts.name: Detect Thoughts
Detect Thoughts.description:
For the duration, you can read the thoughts of certain creatures. When you cast the spell and as your action on each turn until the spell ends, you can focus your mind on any one creature that you can see within 30 feet of you. If the creature you choose has an Intelligence of 3 or lower or doesn't speak any language, the creature is unaffected.

You initially learn the surface thoughts of the creature—what is most on its mind in that moment. As an action, you can either shift your attention to another creature's thoughts or attempt to probe deeper into the same creature's mind. If you probe deeper, the target must make a Wisdom saving throw. If it fails, you gain insight into its reasoning (if any), its emotional state, and something that looms large in its mind (such as something it worries over, loves, or hates). If it succeeds, the spell ends. Either way, the target knows that you are probing into its mind, and unless you shift your attention to another creature's thoughts, the creature can use its action on its turn to make an Intelligence check contested by your Intelligence check; if it succeeds, the spell ends.

Questions verbally directed at the target creature naturally shape the course of its thoughts, so this spell is particularly effective as part of an interrogation.

You can also use this spell to detect the presence of thinking creatures you can't see. When you cast the spell or as your action during the duration, you can search for thoughts within 30 feet of you. The spell can penetrate barriers, but 2 feet of rock, 2 inches of any metal other than lead, or a thin sheet of lead blocks you. You can't detect a creature with an Intelligence of 3 or lower or one that doesn't speak any language.

Once you detect the presence of a creature in this way, you can read its thoughts for the rest of the duration as described above, even if you can't see it, but it must still be within range.

materials.value: A copper piece

Minor Illusion.name: Minor Illusion
Minor Illusion.description:
You create a sound or an image of an object within range that lasts for the duration. The illusion also ends if you dismiss it as an action or cast this spell again.

If you create a sound, its volume can range from a whisper to a scream. It can be your voice, someone else's voice, a lion's roar, a beating of drums, or any other sound you choose. The sound continues unabated throughout the duration, or you can make discrete sounds at different times before the spell ends.

If you create an image of an object—such as a chair, muddy footprints, or a small chest—it must be no larger than a 5-foot cube. The image can't create sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect. Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it.

If a creature uses its action to examine the sound or image, the creature can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the illusion becomes faint to the creature.

materials.value: A bit of fleece.

Invisibility.name: Invisibility
Invisibility.description:
A creature you touch becomes invisible until the spell ends. Anything the target is wearing or carrying is invisible as long as it is on the target's person. The spell ends for a target that attacks or casts a spell.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.

materials.value: An eyelash encased in gum arabic

Invisibility.name: Invisibility
Invisibility.description: The target becomes Invisible until the spell ends. Anything the target is wearing or carrying is invisible as long as it is on the target's person. The spell ends for a target that attacks or casts a spell.

Major Image.name: Major Image
Major Image.description:
You create the image of an object, a creature, or some other visible phenomenon that is no larger than a 20-foot cube. The image appears at a spot that you can see within range and lasts for the duration. It seems completely real, including sounds, smells, and temperature appropriate to the thing depicted. You can't create sufficient heat or cold to cause damage, a sound loud enough to deal thunder damage or deafen a creature, or a smell that might sicken a creature (like a troglodyte's stench).

As long as you are within range of the illusion, you can use your action to cause the image to move to any other spot within range. As the image changes location, you can alter its appearance so that its movements appear natural for the image. For example, if you create an image of a creature and move it, you can alter the image so that it appears to be walking. Similarly, you can cause the illusion to make different sounds at different times, even making it carry on a conversation, for example.

Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it. A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the creature can see through the image, and its other sensory qualities become faint to the creature.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the spell lasts until dispelled, without requiring your concentration.

materials.value: A bit of fleece

Programmed Illusion.name: Programmed Illusion
Programmed Illusion.description:
You create an Illusion of an object, a creature, or some other visible phenomenon within range that activates when a specific condition occurs. The illusion is imperceptible until then. It must be no larger than a 30-foot cube, and you decide when you cast the spell how the illusion behaves and what sounds it makes. This scripted Performance can last up to 5 minutes.

When the condition you specify occurs, the illusion springs into existence and performs in the manner you described. Once the illusion finishes performing, it disappears and remains dormant for 10 minutes. After this time, the illusion can be activated again.

The triggering condition can be as general or as detailed as you like, though it must be based on visual or audible Conditions that occur within 30 feet of the area. For example, you could create an illusion of yourself to appear and warn off others who attempt to open a trapped door, or you could set the illusion to trigger only when a creature says the correct word or phrase.

Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it. A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the Illusion for what it is, the creature can see through the image, and any noise it makes sounds hollow to the creature

materials.value: A bit of fleece and jade dust worth at least 25gp

Project Image.name: Project Image
Project Image.description:
You create an illusory copy of yourself that lasts for the Duration. The copy can appear at any location within range that you have seen before, regardless of intervening obstacles. The Illusion looks and sounds like you but is intangible. If the illusion takes any damage, it disappears, and the spell ends.

You can use your action to move this illusion up to twice your speed, and make it gesture, speak, and behave in whatever way you choose. It mimics your mannerisms perfectly.

You can see through its eyes and hear through its ears as if you were in its space. On Your Turn as a Bonus Action, you can switch from using its senses to using your own, or back again. While you are using its senses, you are Blinded and Deafened in regard to your own surroundings.

Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it. A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine that it is an Illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the creature can see through the image, and any noise it makes sounds hollow to the creature.

materials.value: A small replica of you made from material worth at least 5gp

Ratfolk.name: Ratfolk
Ratfolk.description:
The halfling-sized, furred creature has a twitching snout, bony feet, and a long, pink tail.

The ratfolk are canny survivors, rogues, and tricksters. Their strong family ties make it easy for them to found or join criminal societies—though others serve as expert scouts and saboteurs, able to infiltrate army camps, city sewers, and even castle dungeons with equal ease. Ratfolk leaders are often spellcasters and rogues.

Adaptable. Ratfolk swim well and can survive on little. Some groups are endemic to tropical and subtropical islands. Others inhabit forests, sewers, labyrinths, and ancient, ruined cities.

Fast Fighters. Ratfolk prefer light weapons and armor, fighting with speed and using numbers to bring down a foe. They have been known to ally themselves with goblins, darakhul (see page 202), and kobolds on occasion, but more often prefer to serve a “Rat King” who may or may not be a rat of any kind. Such rat rulers might include a wererat, a @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures-r.Actor.GcBC7Zm06wmpaYGF]{rat king} (see page 300), an ogre, a minor demon, or an intelligent undead.

Nimbleness.name: Nimbleness
Nimbleness.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move through the space of any Medium or larger hostile creature, and such a space isn’t difficult terrain for the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

Pack Tactics.name: Pack Tactics
Pack Tactics.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn’t incapacitated.

Studded Leather Armor.name: Studded Leather Armor
Studded Leather Armor.description: Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.

Mordant Snare.name: Mordant Snare
Mordant Snare.description:
The ground rumbles and a gigantic starfish with eleven arms rises from the earth, grasping at nearby prey.

Mordant snares were created by war mages of ancient times. Each resembles an immense, eleven-armed starfish weighing eight tons, and yet a mordant snare is never obvious. Instead, it controls a dozen humanoids shuffling about aimlessly, paying little attention to their surroundings.

Starfish Puppet Masters. Snares bury themselves under loose soil to attack creatures walking above them. After killing a humanoid, they inject acid into the victim’s body that liquefies organs and muscle while leaving the skeleton, tendons, and skin intact. With the body thus hollowed out and refilled with acid and filaments, the mordant snare can control it from below like a puppet.

Brains Preferred. The mordant snare prefers intelligent food and hunts until an area is empty of sustenance. A village can suffer tremendous losses or even be wiped out before discovering the cause. However, a mordant snare is intelligent enough to know that escaped victims may come back with friends, shovels, and weapons, ready for battle. When this occurs, the snare abandons its puppets, burrows deeper underground, and seeks a new home.

Cooperative Killers. Mordant snares are few in number and cannot reproduce. Since the secret of their creation was lost long ago, eventually they will disappear. Until then, they cooperate with each other when in the same areas, using puppets to lure victims to one another.

Mordant Puppets.name: Mordant Puppets
Mordant Puppets.description:
A [[lookup @name lowercase]] can spend 8 hours draining a dead Humanoid of its fluids and internal organs, replacing them with the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s acid and filaments. The Humanoid’s body then becomes a puppet controlled by the snare.

Mordant puppets share a telepathic link with the snare, and each puppet uses the statistics of a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NAISFPoNNgUCsEyW]{zombie}.

The puppets can’t move more than 30 feet away from the snare. The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can have no more than twelve puppets under its control at one time.

When a puppet is destroyed, each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the puppet must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take [[/damage average]] damage.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies, all puppets it controls immediately crumble into desiccated husks as the animating acid and filaments leave them.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and four [[/item Tentacle]] attacks, or it makes four [[/item Acid Spike]] attacks.

Tentacle.name: Tentacle
Tentacle.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 18) if it is a Large or smaller creature.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has eleven tentacles, each of which can grapple only one target.

Grappled.name: Grappled
Grappled.description: The target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} if it is a Large or smaller creature.

Hidden Trap.name: Hidden Trap
Hidden Trap.description:
While underground, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] covers itself in dirt, sand, or other material and lurks just below the surface.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is indistinguishable from the ground around it while motionless and covered in this way.

When a creature enters the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s space, the snare can make one [[/item Tentacle]] attack against the creature as a reaction, removing the covering material.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Trollkin Reaver.name: Trollkin Reaver
Trollkin Reaver.description:
The humanoid’s skin is thick and knobby, and it sports wicked talons and tusks.

In the north, the masses huddle in fear at night, dreading the horns and howls of reavers come to slaughter and pillage.

Fearsome Savages. Trollkin have a well-deserved reputation for savagery, and the reavers help reinforce that perception among their neighbors. With claws and fangs larger and sharper than their brethren, reavers are a sight to behold.

War Leaders. Raiding is a staple industry among the trollkin, and the reavers lead the most savage raiding parties in search of wealth, slaves, and supplies. They often recruit other creatures or mercenaries into their bands. It is not uncommon to see bloodthirsty humans, gnolls, or hobgoblins in a reaver’s band.

Spirit Talkers. Trollkin reavers are quite fearful of spirits and ghosts, and they listen to their clan shaman and to the words of powerful fey or giants. They prefer to raid only in times of good omens.

Hide Armor.name: Hide Armor
Hide Armor.description: This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. It is commonly worn by barbarian tribes, evil humanoids, and other folk who lack access to the tools and materials needed to create better armor.

Thick Hide.name: Thick Hide
Thick Hide.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s skin is thick and tough, granting it a +1 bonus to Armor Class. This bonus is already factored into the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s AC.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks, or it makes three [[/item Handaxe]] attacks. It can replace one Claw attack with a [[/item Battleaxe]] attack.

Howl of Battle.name: Howl of Battle
Howl of Battle.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] howls a battle cry at up to three friendly creatures it can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

Each target can make one weapon attack as a reaction and has advantage on the attack roll.

Regeneration.name: Regeneration
Regeneration.description:
The [[lookup @name]] regains [[/heal]] at the start of its turn.

If the trollkin takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn’t function at the start of the trollkin’s next turn.

The trollkin dies if it starts its turn with 0 hp and doesn’t regenerate.

Battleaxe.name: Battleaxe
Battleaxe.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]]  or [[/damage twoHanded average]] damage if used with two hands.

Ravenfolk Warrior.name: Ravenfolk Warrior
Ravenfolk Warrior.description:
The creature’s face resembles that of a great raven or crow, and it is covered in feathers from head to toe, though without wings.

The ravenfolk are an avian race of scoundrels, schemers, and sneaks—but they are much more than that. Long ago when Odin brokered the truce that brought peace among the gods, the wily deity magically created the ravenfolk from feathers plucked from his ravens Huginn (Thought) and Muninn (Memory). He placed this new race into the world alongside elves, dwarves, humans, and others to be his eyes and ears.

Odin’s Children. To this day, the ravenfolk are Odin’s agents and embody his thought and memory. They are thieves of objects, yes, but primarily, they are thieves of secrets. Their black feathers and long beaks are spotted on the road from place to place, trading information or helping to hatch plots. They are widely viewed as spies, informers, thieves, and troublemakers, but when the ravenfolk swear an oath, they abide by it. Odin grants the best of his ravenfolk magical runespears and runestaves, weapons enchanted to serve his messengers. The ravenfolk consider them special tokens meant for their use, and no one else’s.

Flightless But Bold. Though they have no wings and normally cannot fly, the physiology of ravenfolk is strikingly similar to that of true avians. They stand roughly 5 feet tall and, because of their hollow bones, weigh just 95–105 pounds. Albino ravenfolk are often found in southern climates. Ravenfolk eat almost anything, but they prefer raw meat and field grains, such as corn, soy, and alfalfa. They even scavenge days-old carrion, a practice that repulses most other humanoids.

Feather Speech. The ravenfolk have two languages: a verbal language full of croaks and whistles and a language of feathers. Ravenfolk can communicate volumes without speaking a word through the dyeing, arrangement, preening, and rustling of their plumage. This language is inherent to ravenfolk, and though others may use magic to understand it, it can’t be used by creatures without feathers.

Ravenfolk in Midgard

If the ravenfolk of Midgard have a homeland, it is Beldestan to the East, on a branch of Wotan’s tree in the North, or a high cliff of Horus’ hidden temple in the South. They have settlements in Trollheim, Vidim, Domovogrod, Zobeck, Nuria Natal, and the Dragon Empire, but none are large.

They avoid the West and the Seven Cities most of the time and are highly honored in Nuria Natal, where they serve the temples of Horus as sworn guardians, assassins, and seekers of forgotten arcana. Some are said to be members of the Emerald Order, a society devoted to arcane mysteries.

Studded Leather Armor.name: Studded Leather Armor
Studded Leather Armor.description: Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.

Odin’s Call.name: Odin’s Call
Odin’s Call.description: When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes damage while below half its hp maximum, it moves up to half its speed without provoking &Reference[opportunity attacks].

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Peck]] attack and one [[/item Runespear]] attack, or it makes two [[/item Longbow]] attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of [[/item Ghost Wings]].

Mimicry.name: Mimicry
Mimicry.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can mimic animal sounds and Humanoid voices.

A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful [[/check format]].

Rune-Powered Weapons.name: Rune-Powered Weapons
Rune-Powered Weapons.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s weapon attacks are magical.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra 1d8 radiant damage (included in the attack).

Ghost Wings.name: Ghost Wings
Ghost Wings.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] furiously “beats” a set of phantasmal wings.

Each creature within 5 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the start of its next turn.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the start of its next turn.

Dipsa.name: Dipsa
Dipsa.description:
Except for a pair of tiny fangs, the entire body of this yellowish-green worm looks like a ropy tangle of slime-covered tubes and puddles of mucus.

Anesthetic Ooze. Many jungle clans believe the dipsa is an eyeless snake, but it is a tubular ooze with a lethal, poisonous bite. The dipsa’s venom has an anesthetic quality that allows the ooze to cling to creatures and slowly turn their innards to jelly without being noticed until the victim falls down dead. Once the poison’s numbing property wears off, however, victims report an agonizing sense of burning from the inside out.

Tiny Fangs. A dipsa’s undulating movement evokes that of a snake as much as its serpentine form, but close examination reveals that it has neither bones nor internal organs, only tiny fangs of the same color and substance as the rest of its body. A dipsa never exceeds 1 foot in length. Its coloration oscillates between sickly hues of yellow or green.

Gelatinous Eggs. Dipsas are hermaphroditic. When two dipsas breed, they leave behind a hundred gelatinous eggs in a small puddle of highly acidic milt. A dozen become fertilized and survive long enough to hatch, after which they immediately devour the others.

Amorphous.name: Amorphous
Amorphous.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

Discreet Bite.name: Discreet Bite
Discreet Bite.description:
The bite of a [[lookup @name lowercase]] is barely perceptible and the wound is quickly anesthetized.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with a [[/item Bite]] attack, the target must succeed on a [[/check format=long]] to notice the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and its attack.

Each time the creature takes acid damage from an attached [[lookup @name lowercase]], it can repeat this check, noticing the [[lookup @name lowercase]] on a success.

A creature that takes acid damage from the [[lookup @name lowercase]] while below half its hp maximum automatically succeeds on this check.

Swamp Camouflage.name: Swamp Camouflage
Swamp Camouflage.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in swampy terrain.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the dipsa attaches to the target.

While attached, the dipsa can’t attack, and at the start of each of the dipsa’s turns, the target takes [[/damage average activity=jOBKyeWnsIsUoBod]] damage and must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or have its hp maximum reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken.

This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0.

The attached dipsa moves with the target whenever the target moves, requiring none of the dipsa’s movement. It can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement on its turn.

A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the dipsa.

Malphas.name: Malphas
Malphas.description:
Keen eyed and dangerous, this winged fey warrior is dressed in finery.

Sworn to the Shadow Fey. Raised with a sword in their hands, the malphas are fierce warriors who serve the aristocracy of the shadow fey (see page 158) unswervingly.

Corvid Fey. The malphas have many crow-like features, including beaks, black-feathered bodies and wings, and clawed feet and hands. On occasion, a cloaked ravenfolk traveling in fey lands might be mistaken for a malphas, and some less scrupulous ravenfolk use this to their advantage to manipulate fey they encounter. Malphas don’t take kindly to such impersonations and are merciless toward any ravenfolk they discover pretending to be one of them.

Messengers. Laconic in speech, they nevertheless serve as envoys and messengers from time to time. However, as much or more is communicated by the choice in messenger as in the message itself. Their crow-like features and the tendency of their masters to send bad news via malphas has earned them the nickname “storm crows” among many fey.

Shadow-infused Weapons.name: Shadow-infused Weapons
Shadow-infused Weapons.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s weapon attacks are magical.

When it hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra 3d6 necrotic damage (included in the attack).

Sunlight Sensitivity.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
Sunlight Sensitivity.description: While in sunlight, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

Shadow Call.name: Shadow Call
Shadow Call.description:
When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is hit by a ranged attack, it can make one [[/item Shadow Bolt]] attack against the attacker.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t have disadvantage on this attack from being within 5 feet of a hostile creature, though it may still have disadvantage from other sources.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Longsword]] attacks or three [[/item Shadow Bolt]] attacks.

If both Longsword attacks hit one creature, the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its next turn, as shadows fill its eyes.

A creature that can see through magical darkness has advantage on this saving throw.

save.condition: If both longsword attacks hit

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its next turn, as shadows fill its eyes.

Studded Leather Armor.name: Studded Leather Armor
Studded Leather Armor.description: Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.

Longsword.name: Longsword
Longsword.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]]  or [[/damage twoHanded average]] damage if used with two hands.

Cobbleswarm.name: Cobbleswarm
Cobbleswarm.description:
The paving stones underfoot suddenly lurch and tumble over one another. Thousands of tiny limbs, pincers, and stingers break from the stony surface and frantically scuttle forward.

A cobbleswarm is made up of tiny, crablike creatures with smooth, stony shells. Individually they are referred to as cobbles. The creatures vary in size, shape, and color, but all have six segmented legs, a whiplike stinger, and a single eye.

Paving Stone Mimics. When the eye is closed and the limbs are pulled under the shell, cobbles are nearly indistinguishable from lifeless paving stones. Victims of cobbleswarms are caught unaware when the floor beneath them suddenly writhes and shifts, and dozens of eyes appear where there should be none.

Trap Affinity. Cobbleswarms have a rudimentary understanding of traps. They often hide in places where their Shift and Tumble ability can slide intruders into pits or across trapped areas. Kobold tribes prize them for this reason.

False Appearance.name: False Appearance
False Appearance.description: While the [[lookup @name lowercase]] remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from normal stones.

Shifting Floor.name: Shifting Floor
Shifting Floor.description:
Whenever the [[lookup @name lowercase]] moves into a creature’s space or starts its turn in another creature’s space, the creature must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or fall &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}

A prone creature must succeed on a [[/check format=long]] to stand up in a space occupied by the swarm.

Stings.name: Stings
Stings.description: Melee Weapon Attack: [[/attack]], reach 0 ft. , one target in the swarm’s space. [[/damage average extended]], or [[/damage average activity=EGkts01xIG5WSeqP]] damage if the swarm has half its hp or fewer.

Shift and Tumble.name: Shift and Tumble
Shift and Tumble.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] pushes a prone creature in its space up to 5 feet away from it.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can occupy another creature’s space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny stone. The swarm can’t regain hp or gain temporary hp.

Myling.name: Myling
Myling.description:
Dressed in rags, this small humanoid has cold, blue skin and large, black eyes.

Mylings are the souls of the unburied, those who died in the forest from abandonment or exposure and can find no peace until their bodies are properly interred. Given the circumstances around their deaths, mylings tend to be solitary, haunting the places where they died. When some tragedy ended in multiple deaths, the resulting mylings stay together and hunt as a pack.

Attack in a Rage. Mylings prefer to attack lone wanderers. They target a group when desperate or when there’s more than one myling in the pack. They shadow a target until after dark, then jump onto the target’s back and demand to be carried to their chosen burial ground. They cling tightly to a victim with arms and legs locked around the victim’s shoulders and midsection, begging, threatening, and biting until the victim gives in to their demands. Mylings bite victims to death if the victim is unable or unwilling to carry them, or if a victim moves too slowly.

Ungrateful Rest. While all mylings seek a creature to carry them to their final resting place, even when a “mount” is willing, the creature’s body grows immensely heavy as it nears its burial place. Once there, the myling sinks into the earth, taking its bearer with it.

Urchin Rhymes and Songs. Some mylings maintain traces of the personalities they had while alive— charming, sullen, or sadistic—and can speak touchingly and piteously. Dressed in ragged clothing, their skin blue with cold, they sometimes reach victims who believe they are helping an injured child or young adult. They hide their faces and sing innocent rhymes when they aren’t screeching in fury, for they know that their dead eyes and cold blue skin cause fright and alarm.

Enfeebling Attacks.name: Enfeebling Attacks
Enfeebling Attacks.description:
Each time the [[lookup @name lowercase]] deals necrotic damage to a creature that is below half its hp maximum, the target’s Strength score is reduced by [[/r 1d4]].

The target dies if this reduces its Strength to 0.

Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.

affects.special: Creature that is below half its hp maximum

Claw.name: Claw
Claw.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or the [[lookup @name lowercase]] attaches to it.

While attached, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] sinks its teeth into the target and can’t attack, and at the start of each of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s turns, the target takes [[/damage average activity=uby6Nkv7OI9a6M6c]] damage.

The attached [[lookup @name lowercase]] moves with the target whenever the target moves, requiring none of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s movement.

It can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement on its turn.

A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the [[lookup @name lowercase]] by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]].

check.condition: A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the myling

Myling Attached.name: Myling Attached
Myling Attached.description: The myling is attached to the target.

Bury Alive.name: Bury Alive
Bury Alive.description:
The creature to which the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is attached is knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}, dragged into the ground, and buried just below the surface, ending the attachment.

The buried creature is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained} and unable to breathe or stand up.

A creature, including the buried creature, can take its action to free the buried creature by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]].

affects.special: A creature, including the buried creature

Buried Alive.name: Buried Alive
Buried Alive.description:
The target is attached is knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}, dragged into the ground, and buried just below the surface, ending the attachment.

The buried creature is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained} and unable to breathe or stand up.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Havoc Runner.name: Havoc Runner
Havoc Runner.description:
A sprinting gnoll laughs as it runs, axe held high and flashing in the sun.

With the bristly mane and spotted fur characteristic of all gnolls, havoc runners blend into their tribe. Only the canny glint in the eyes hints at the deadly difference before the havoc runner explodes into violence.

Blinding Raids. Havoc runners are scouring storms across the trade routes that crisscross the tribe’s territory. Like all gnolls, they are deadly in battle. Havoc runners incorporate another quality that makes them the envy of many raiders: they can tell at a glance which pieces of loot from a laden camel or wagon are the most valuable, without spending time rummaging, weighing, or evaluating. Their ability to strike into a caravan, seize the best items, and withdraw quickly is unparalleled.

Chain Shirt.name: Chain Shirt
Chain Shirt.description: Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearer's upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers.

Harrying Attacks.name: Harrying Attacks
Harrying Attacks.description: If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] attacks more than one creature in the same turn, the first target has disadvantage on attack rolls until the end of its next turn.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Battleaxe]] attacks.

Pack Tactics.name: Pack Tactics
Pack Tactics.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn’t incapacitated.

Battleaxe.name: Battleaxe
Battleaxe.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]]  or [[/damage twoHanded average]] damage if used with two hands.

Steam Golem.name: Steam Golem
Steam Golem.description:
With wicked axe blades fastened along its arms and bronze runes inlaid on its armored torso, this golem is a smooth-running machine of death.

Boilers and Hydraulics. A steam golem is built around a central boiler with clockwork gears and hydraulic cylinders powering its legs and arms. Most steam golems have axe blades welded onto each of their arms, and many have one arm extended in a single, long-hafted axe. They tower 10 feet tall, and their legs are often built with reversed knee joints for greater leverage when they move. The eyes of a steam golem glow orange or red from its internal fires.

Steam Whistle. A steam golem has four to six vents for releasing steam. These whistles are mounted over the shoulders and can be heard at distances up to a mile in open terrain.

Fuel Required. A steam golem’s machinery consumes 30 pounds of coal and 100 gallons of water per day if it engages in more than brief combat. When resting or standing guard, a steam golem needs only one third of those amounts.

Boiler Weakness.name: Boiler Weakness
Boiler Weakness.description:
If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] starts its turn immersed in water, or if it was soaked with at least 20 gallons of water on its previous turn, it risks losing steam pressure in its boiler.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or its internal fire is extinguished.

Until its internal fire is relit, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] speed is halved, its AC is reduced by 2, and it must repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns.

On a failure, it stops repeating this saving throw and becomes dormant, effectively dead until the fire is relit.

A Medium or smaller creature within 5 feet of the golem can take an action to relight the golem’s internal fire, making it active again.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect is available on the Effects tab to apply the changes to the golem's speed and AC.

Speed & AC Reduction.name: Speed & AC Reduction
Speed & AC Reduction.description: Until its internal fire is relit, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] speed is halved, its AC is reduced by 2, and it must repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns.

Heated Weapons.name: Heated Weapons
Heated Weapons.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s weapon attacks are magical.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra 4d8 fire damage (included in the attack).

Whistle.name: Whistle
Whistle.description:
When a creature the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it casts a spell, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] emits a shriek from its twin steam whistles.

The spellcaster must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or the spell fails and has no effect.

save.condition: When a creature the golem can see within 30 feet of it casts a spell.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The steam golem makes one [[/item Axe Arm]] attack and one [[/item Long Axe]] attack.

Steam Blast.name: Steam Blast
Steam Blast.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] releases a blast of steam in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]] or in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=IporwrpKwcLAm6fA]]-foot-radius cloud that extends from it, spreading around corners.

Each creature in the area must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Construct Nature.name: Construct Nature
Construct Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Immutable Form.name: Immutable Form
Immutable Form.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Ancient Sea Dragon.name: Ancient Sea Dragon
Ancient Sea Dragon.description:
This aquamarine dragon has a shark’s head that tapers off into a sleek eel-like body. Its large fins double as wings.

Divine Dragons. Sea dragons are the children of the ocean and believe they are semi-divine beings, worthy of worship. Given their size and power, they might be right; certainly, they are often companions or steeds to gods of the sea. Despite the solemn duties the sea dragons invoke thanks to their lineage, they are extremely whimsical. While these immense creatures are playful, their games can shatter hulls and drown sailors. The sea dragons course through the waves with tangible joy as they hunt whales and entire schools of tuna.

Shipwreck Art. Sea dragons love collecting treasure. They especially prize the sunken, treasure-filled hulls of ships lost to storm, battle, or their own handiwork. While they appreciate all wealth, they prefer hardy items that stand up to long exposure to sea water. Precious metals and gemstones add a dramatic luster to the dragon’s lair when they catch stray beams of light. Sea dragons take more perishable treasures and place them on a reef-altar, to dissolve in the sea as a tithe to the sea gods.

Sunken Memorials. A sea dragon’s lair is littered with meticulously arranged ships consigned to the deeps. These wrecks are often artfully smashed to allow the treasures in the hold to spill out onto the sea floor. It may seem haphazard, but it displays a complex aesthetic that only other sea dragons can truly appreciate. Because they arrange these wrecks so carefully, a dragon notices immediately if its hoard is disturbed.

A Sea Dragon’s Lair

Sea dragons dwell in lairs beneath the waves: ocean fissures and caves, lightless trenches full of strange rock formations, and sheltered reefs of cultivated coral. Whatever the place, it’s dedicated to the worship of sea gods. Despite the draconic instinct for seclusion and protection when choosing a lair, sea dragons always choose lairs relatively close to humanoid trade routes and abundant supplies of fish.

The sky surrounding a sea dragon’s lair is perpetually stormy, and the seas run high. If a captain is courageous, these high winds and swift-running currents can cut significant time off a voyage.

Lair Actions

On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row:

  • Create Coral Wall. The dragon creates an opaque wall of living coral on a solid surface it can see within 120 feet of it. The wall can be up to 30 feet long, 30 feet high, and 1 foot thick. When the wall appears, each creature in its area is pushed 5 feet out of the wall’s space on whichever side of the wall it wants, and it must make a [[/save dex 15 format=long]], taking [[/damage 4d8 slashing average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. While the wall remains, any creature that touches the wall must also make the saving throw. Each 10-foot section of the wall has AC 5, 30 hp, resistance to fire damage, and immunity to poison damage and psychic damage. The wall lasts until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

  • Invoke the Sea’s Calm. The currents around up to four creatures in the water and that the dragon can see within 120 feet of it work against the creatures. Each target must succeed on a [[/save str 15 format=long]] or it can’t use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can’t make more than one attack on its turn until initiative count 20 on the next round.

  • Whirlpools. Four vortexes of water appear centered on points underwater or on the water’s surface that the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. Each vortex takes the shape of a cylinder that is 30 feet tall with a 5-foot radius. Each creature that enters a vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a [[/save str 15 format=long]] or be &Reference[restrained]{restrained}. A creature, including a restrained creature, can take its action to free the restrained creature by succeeding on a [[/check str 15 format=long]]. The vortexes last until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

Regional Effects

The region containing a legendary sea dragon’s lair is warped by the dragon’s magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

  • Chill of the Deeps. Water temperatures drop sharply within 1 mile of the dragon’s lair, turning the water frigid and endangering swimming creatures not accustomed to arctic waters.

  • Tempestuous Weather. Storms and rough water are more common within 6 miles of the lair.

  • Thriving Waterways. Sea life becomes richer within 6 miles of the lair. Schools of fish move into new waters, sharks become common, and whale migration paths shift to pass near the area.

If the dragon dies, these effects fade over the course of [[/r 1d10]] days.

Priests of Seggotan

Every sea dragon is devoted to the dragon god of the sea. As a result, many sea dragons use the innate spellcasting variant. Sea dragons favor spells that manipulate water or the weather, emulate storms, deal lightning or cold damage, divine the future, or conjure sea creatures to fight alongside the dragon.

Sea Dragons in Midgard

Sea dragons are the offspring of Seggotan, the dragon god of time and the sea. A sea dragon shares its god’s idea that everything in the sea is the property of Seggotan, and they expect lesser beings to respect that truth.

The sea dragons are among the most powerful allies of the Mharoti Empire, securing seaways and acting as a communion point for the tidal priests. Thankfully for the Empire’s enemies, the most ancient sea dragons are too consumed with contemplation of time and their inscrutable duties in the depths of the ocean to make war.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The dragon uses its [[/item Frightful Presence]]. It then makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Fin]] attacks.

Whirlpools.name: Whirlpools
Whirlpools.description:
Four vortexes of water appear centered on points underwater or on the water’s surface that the dragon can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

Each vortex takes the shape of a cylinder that is [[lookup @target.template.height activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet tall with a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot radius.

Each creature that enters a vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}.

A creature, including a restrained creature, can take its action to free the restrained creature by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]].

The vortexes last until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

Restrained.name: Restrained
Restrained.description:
The target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}.

A creature, including a restrained creature, can take its action to free the restrained creature by succeeding on a successful check.

Tidal Breath.name: Tidal Breath
Tidal Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales a crushing wave of frigid seawater in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type capitalize activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in that area must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, the creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is pushed up to 45 feet away from the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}

On a success, the creature takes half the damage and isn’t pushed or knocked prone.

Create Coral Wall.name: Create Coral Wall
Create Coral Wall.description:
The dragon creates an opaque wall of living coral on a solid surface it can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

The wall can be up to [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet long, 30 feet high, and [[lookup @target.template.width activity=dnd5eactivity000]] foot thick.

When the wall appears, each creature in its area is pushed 5 feet out of the wall’s space on whichever side of the wall it wants, and it must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

While the wall remains, any creature that touches the wall must also make the saving throw.

Each 10-foot section of the wall has AC 5, 30 hp, resistance to fire damage, and immunity to poison damage and psychic damage.

The wall lasts until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

Invoke the Sea’s Calm.name: Invoke the Sea’s Calm
Invoke the Sea’s Calm.description:
The currents around up to four creatures in the water and that the dragon can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=iXtwTqUVcryucbZz]] feet of it work against the creatures.

Each target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or it can’t use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can’t make more than one attack on its turn until initiative count 20 on the next round.

Invoke the Sea’s Calm.name: Invoke the Sea’s Calm
Invoke the Sea’s Calm.description: The target can’t use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can’t make more than one attack on its turn until initiative count 20 on the next round.

Lair Actions.name: Lair Actions
Lair Actions.description: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If [[lookup @name lowercase]] fails a saving throw, they can choose to succeed instead.

Amphibious.name: Amphibious
Amphibious.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can breathe air and water.

Siege Monster.name: Siege Monster
Siege Monster.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] deals double damage to objects and structures.

Frightful Presence.name: Frightful Presence
Frightful Presence.description:
Each creature of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s choice that is within 120 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and aware of it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature’s saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

Frightened.name: Frightened
Frightened.description: The target is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute, and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Wing Attack.name: Wing Attack
Wing Attack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] beats its wings.

Each creature within 10 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take [[/damage average]] damage and be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can then move up to half its flying speed, or swimming speed if in the water.

Hound of the Night.name: Hound of the Night
Hound of the Night.description:
This enormous black hound pants in the moonlight, wisps of steam rising from its muzzle, as it follows its elvish master.

Fey Bloodhounds. Hounds of the night are bred by the shadow fey (see page 158) for use as hunting companions and guardians, and they excel at both tasks. Far more intelligent than other hounds, they are difficult to evade once they are on a quarry’s trail, because they can think their way past problems that would throw their lesser kin off the trail. Their shadow fey masters claim that hounds of the night can smell a shadow on running water and can sniff out a ghost passing through a wall.

Cousins to Winter. Somewhere in their early existence as a breed, some enterprising hunter interbred them with winter wolves. Every trace of their white fur is long gone, but the cold breath of those dread canines remains.

Dimensional Stepping. Hounds of night excel at distracting prey while some of their pack teleport away to achieve some larger goal, such as dragging off a treasure or overwhelming a spellcaster in the back ranks.

Fey Scent.name: Fey Scent
Fey Scent.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

If it is tracking a Fey, Giant, or Humanoid whose scent it knows, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can continue tracking that creature if the creature moves into the Border Ethereal or teleports, provided the creature isn’t in the Border Ethereal for more than 1 minute or that the creature doesn’t teleport more than 100 feet at a time.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Bite]] attacks.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Frost Breath.name: Frost Breath
Frost Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales frost in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type capitalize activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in the area must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Teleport.name: Teleport
Teleport.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

Before or after teleporting, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can make one [[/item Bite]] attack.

Feyward Tree.name: Feyward Tree
Feyward Tree.description:
Dark, bark-like rust encrusts the trunk of this metal tree, and its dull metallic leaves rustle with the sound of sharp metal.

Cold Iron Trees. These ferrous constructs are cold-forged in a process taking several years, as bits of rust and other oxidation are cultivated one layer at a time into bark and branches. In this way, the artificers create massive, twisted trunks resembling real, gnarled trees. Green-tinged leaves of beaten cold iron are welded in place by the master craftsmen, and trained warmages bring the construct to life through intense magical rituals rumored to take a full turn of seasons.

Fey Destroyers. The feyward tree unswervingly obeys the commands of its creators, guarding key points of entry across fey rivers and streams, abandoned sacred groves deep in the forest, suspected faerie rings, or possible elf encampments. Many are released deep in elvish woods with orders to attack any fey on sight. These trees are rarely, if ever, heard from again. Whether they leave a bloody trail of flayed elves in their wake or some fey counter-measure neutralizes them is unknown.

Growing Numbers. Each year, the feywardens order the construction and release of a handful of feyward trees, trusting in the destructive nature of the constructs. The feywardens leave nothing to chance, flooding fey forests with the constructs over decades.

Aversion to Cold.name: Aversion to Cold
Aversion to Cold.description:
If the feyward tree takes cold damage, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and its speed is halved until the end of its next turn.

Foundry Note

This feature includes an Active Effect (AE) that reduces the speed of the creature, but it does not automate disadvantage on attacks.

Disadv. & Speed Halved.name: Disadv. & Speed Halved
Disadv. & Speed Halved.description: The feyward tree has disadvantage on attack rolls and its speed is halved until the end of its next turn.

Construct Nature.name: Construct Nature
Construct Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Enchanted Leaves.name: Enchanted Leaves
Enchanted Leaves.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s [[/item Razor-Leafed Branch]] attacks are magical.

When the tree hits with its Razor-Leafed Branch, the branch deals an extra 9 (2d8) force damage (included in the attack).

Lightning Absorption.name: Lightning Absorption
Lightning Absorption.description: Whenever the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is subjected to lightning damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hp equal to the lightning damage dealt.

Warden’s Reach.name: Warden’s Reach
Warden’s Reach.description: A creature within 15 feet of a [[lookup @name lowercase]] that moves away from it provokes an &Reference[Opportunity Attacks] even if the creature takes the &Reference[Disengage] action.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The feyward tree makes two [[/item Razor-Leafed Branch]] attacks.

Flaying Leaves.name: Flaying Leaves
Flaying Leaves.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] launches a barrage of razor-sharp cold iron leaves from its branches.

Each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the tree must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Immutable Form.name: Immutable Form
Immutable Form.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Gug.name: Gug
Gug.description:
The giant, four-armed, two-legged creature steps forward, long claws extended. A large mouth splits its torso from shoulders to navel.

Underworld Godlings. Gugs are giants of the underworld that enjoy smashing and devouring lesser creatures. Their burbling and grunting speech displays a surprising and malign intelligence to those few who can understand it. Gugs are occasionally worshipped by tribes of derro, and their strange underworld cities are filled with esoteric monoliths and constructs.

Nocturnal Raiders. While gugs were banished into the underworld by forgotten gods long ago, they regularly flout this prohibition by raiding the surface by night. They also spend much time in the Ethereal Plane, and some gug spellcasters travel the planes with entourages of @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.YW1dkw76GGP2ORZ0]{fext} (see page 171) or @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.qD6RMPxEcVnrWXdu]{noctiny} (see page 287).

Prey on Ghouls. Gugs devour ghouls and darakhul as their preferred foodstuffs. When these are not available, they seem to prefer carrion and particular varieties of psychotropic mushrooms, as well as something that is best described as candied bats.

Towering Strength.name: Towering Strength
Towering Strength.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is considered to be a Gargantuan giant for the purpose of determining its carrying capacity.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The gug makes two four [[/item Grasping Claw]] attacks, or it makes two [[/item Grasping Claw]] attacks and two [[/item Stomp]] attacks. It can replace one Grasping Claw attack with a use of [[/item Fling]] or [[/item Swallow]].

Grasping Claw.name: Grasping Claw
Grasping Claw.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 17) if it is a Large or smaller creature.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has four Grasping Claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

Grappled.name: Grappled
Grappled.description: The target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} if it is a Large or smaller creature.

Stomp.name: Stomp
Stomp.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}

Fling.name: Fling
Fling.description:
One Large or smaller object held or creature grappled by the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is thrown up to 60 feet in a random direction and knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

If a thrown target strikes a solid surface, the target takes 3 (1d6) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown.

If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take the same damage and be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Foundry Note

Scaling for the Damage activity is available to set the damage value, with each scaling value corresponding to 5 feet of movement. For example, a value of 1 represents 10 feet, 2 represents 20 feet, and so on.

save.condition: If the grappled target is flung into another creature

affects.special: That the grappled target is flung at

damage.condition: If grappled by the gug

Swallow.name: Swallow
Swallow.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Grasping Claw]] attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target is also swallowed, and the grapple ends.

While swallowed, the target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} and &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, it has &Reference[total cover] against attacks and other effects outside the [[lookup @name lowercase]], and it takes [[/damage average]] damage at the start of each of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s turns. A [[lookup @name lowercase]] can have only one creature swallowed at a time.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] at the end of that turn or regurgitate the creature, which falls &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone} in a space within [[lookup @range.value activity=uygphpszavIkHznS]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies, a swallowed creature is no longer restrained by it and can escape from the corpse by using [[lookup @range.value activity=uygphpszavIkHznS]] feet of movement, exiting &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Save: 30+ Damage.name: Save: 30+ Damage
Save: 30+ Damage.condition: If the gug takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature

Damage: While Swallowed.name: Damage: While Swallowed
Damage: While Swallowed.condition: If a creature is swallowed by the gug

Escape Corpse.name: Escape Corpse
Escape Corpse.condition: Must use 10 feet of movement to escape

Swallowed.name: Swallowed
Swallowed.description: While swallowed, the target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} and &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, it has &Reference[total cover] against attacks and other effects outside the creature.

Prone.name: Prone
Prone.description: A swallowed creature escaping the stomach lands &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Oozasis.name: Oozasis
Oozasis.description:
The oasis appears as an idyllic desert respite, offering water, shade, and even edible fruit and nuts in the trees above.

Mockmire. The oozasis, or oasis ooze, is also known as a mockmire in other climates. It mimics a peaceful, pristine watering hole to draw in unsuspecting prey. An oozasis cycles seemingly at random between activity and dormancy.

Quest Givers. Within its odd physiology stirs an ancient mind with an inscrutable purpose. Far from being a mindless sludge, its fractured intelligence occasionally reads the thoughts of visitors. At these times, it tries to coerce them into undertaking quests for cryptic reasons.

Ancient Minds. Some tales claim these creatures preserve the memories of mad wizards from dead empires, or that they have unimaginably ancient, inhuman origins.

Oasis Appearance.name: Oasis Appearance
Oasis Appearance.description:
While the [[lookup @name lowercase]] remains motionless and partially submerged on the surface of sand or soil, it is indistinguishable from a small oasis or pond.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s body provides enough water for plants to grow around it, provided the [[lookup @name lowercase]] remains in the area for an extended period of time.

A creature that eats a fruit from a plant growing in the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s water is affected by the [[/item Waters of Unfathomable Compulsion]] trait as if it drank the water.

Waters of Unfathomable Compulsion.name: Waters of Unfathomable Compulsion
Waters of Unfathomable Compulsion.description:
A creature that drinks the water of an [[lookup @name lowercase]] experiences a cryptic dream the next time it sleeps.

When it wakes, it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be affected by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.JQyigMNPiDnGI18b]{geas} spell for 30 days.

While under the geas, the affected creature must perform a specific, seemingly minor task that furthers the decades-long goals of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]. Such a task could be planting a white rose in a specific garden, rescuing the next endangered young animal the target encounters, or standing in a specific spot at a certain time each day for three days.

affects.special: A creature that drinks the water of an oozasis

Magically Obligated.name: Magically Obligated
Magically Obligated.description: The target is affected by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.JQyigMNPiDnGI18b]{geas} spell for 30 days.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes three [[/item Pseudopod]] attacks.

Pseudopod.name: Pseudopod
Pseudopod.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]].

If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 16). Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can have up to two creatures grappled at a time.

Grappled & Restrained.name: Grappled & Restrained
Grappled & Restrained.description: If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled}. Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}.

Compelling Vapors.name: Compelling Vapors
Compelling Vapors.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] emits mind-altering vapors.

Each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and suffers either tranquility or turmoil for 1 minute.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and doesn’t suffer tranquility or turmoil. A creature suffering tranquility is &Reference[charmed apply=false]{charmed} and can’t attack.

A creature suffering turmoil is unable to distinguish friend from foe and must move to and attack the nearest creature other than the [[lookup @name lowercase]] on each of its turns, stalking off in a random direction if no creature is in range.

A creature suffering tranquility or turmoil can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Tranquility (Charmed).name: Tranquility (Charmed)
Tranquility (Charmed).description:
A creature suffering tranquility is &Reference[charmed apply=false]{charmed} and can’t attack.

A creature suffering tranquility can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Turmoil.name: Turmoil
Turmoil.description: A creature suffering turmoil is unable to distinguish friend from foe and must move to and attack the nearest creature other than the oozasis on each of its turns, stalking off in a random direction if no creature is in range.

Amorphous.name: Amorphous
Amorphous.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move through a space as narrow as 1 foot wide without squeezing.

Sap Demon.name: Sap Demon
Sap Demon.description:
The axe mark in the tree oozes with viscous sap that forms into a small, vaguely humanoid shape at the tree’s roots. It half walks and half flows forward.

Tree Oozes. Despite the name, sap demons aren’t true demons. They are sentient oozes that form when an enchanted tree is cut or injured. A few hours after the injury, they pool into a shape that vaguely resembles their tree’s attacker; if the tree cutter had a beard, the sap demon’s human-like head drips in the vague shape of a beard. After dispatching the tree’s attacker, most sap demons return to the tree, though some remain curious or malevolent enough to continue exploring the world.

Reckless Possessors. A sap demon earns its name from its ability to possess another creature by oozing down its throat. Once inside, the sap demon makes the host bleed as the tree bled and is reckless with the body. However, no matter how the body is bandaged or cured, the host perpetually bleeds.

Season’s Change.name: Season’s Change
Season’s Change.description: If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes fire damage, its speed is increased by 10 feet until the end of its next turn. If it takes cold damage, its speed is reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

Speed +10.name: Speed +10
Speed +10.description: The sap demon's speed is increased by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

Speed -10.name: Speed -10
Speed -10.description: The sap demon's speed is decreased by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Slam]] or [[/item Lob Sap]] attacks. If both Slam attacks hit a Medium or smaller creature, the creature is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC [[lookup @skills.ath.passive]]).

Grappled.name: Grappled
Grappled.description: The target is grappled after both slam attacks hit.

Lob Sap.name: Lob Sap
Lob Sap.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target’s speed is reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

Speed -10.name: Speed -10
Speed -10.description: The sap demon's speed is decreased by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

Soul Sap.name: Soul Sap
Soul Sap.description:
One humanoid the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is grappling or that is incapacitated within 5 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be possessed by the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] then disappears, and the target is &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} and loses control of its body.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] now controls the body but doesn’t deprive the target of awareness.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, except ones that restore a creature’s hp maximum.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] retains its Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma and condition immunities. It otherwise uses the possessed target’s statistics, but doesn’t gain access to the target’s knowledge, class features, or proficiencies.

While possessed, the target’s body seeps blood out of its ears, nose, and eyes, and the target takes [[/damage average]] damage at the end of each hour. Its hp maximum is also reduced by that amount. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest after the possession ends.

The possession lasts until the body drops to 0 hp, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] ends it as a bonus action, or the ooze is forced out by an effect like the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.WzvJ7G3cqvIubsLk]{greater restoration} spell.

When the possession ends, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] reappears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the body.

The target is immune to this [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Soul Sap for 24 hours after succeeding on the saving throw or after the possession ends.

Foundry Note - Transformation Process for Possess Humanoid

To transform the Sap Demon into one of the player characters (PCs) using the Possess Humanoid activity, follow these steps:

  1. Edit the Activity: Open the Possess Humanoid activity and navigate to the Transformation tab (ensure you are in the Profiles section).

  2. Prepare the PC: Drag the desired PC into the “Drop Creature Here” area from the Actor Directory (not from the scene) and close the activity.

  3. Select the Sap Demon: Find the Sap Demon on the scene and click on the Possess Humanoid activity, which will then place a card in the chat.

  4. Hide the PC’s Token: Make sure to hide the token of the target PC in the scene.

  5. Transform the Sap Demon: In the chat, click on the Transform button, which will change the Sap Demon into the possessed PC.

  6. Revert the Transformation: Once the possession is over, click on the three dots in the header (top right) of the transformed Sap Demon’s character sheet. Select the “Revert Transformation” button, which changes the Sap Demon into its original form.

  7. Unhide the PC’s Original Token: Finally, unhide the original PC’s token and continue with your encounter.

By following these steps, you can successfully use the Possess Humanoid activity to transform characters during your game.

Rime Worm Grub.name: Rime Worm Grub
Rime Worm Grub.description:
The long, crusty slug sparkles like ice, and long tendrils dangle from its gaping mouth.

Ice Burrowers. The rime worm’s tendrils help it burrow through ice and snow as well as absorb sustenance from prey. Their pale, almost translucent, skin is coated with ice crystals, making them difficult to spot in their snowy habitat.

Spray Black Ice. The worms are fierce hunters, and their abilities to spray skewers of ice and freeze their prey make them extremely dangerous.

Ravenous Larva.name: Ravenous Larva
Ravenous Larva.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can make an &Reference[opportunity attacks]{opportunity attack} against any creature that leaves its reach, even if the creature takes the &Reference[Disengage] action.

In addition, it has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn’t have all its hp.

Amphibious.name: Amphibious
Amphibious.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can breathe air and water.

Snow Camouflage.name: Snow Camouflage
Snow Camouflage.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

Snow Stride.name: Snow Stride
Snow Stride.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can burrow through nonmagical snow and ice in addition to sand, earth, and mud. In addition, &Reference[difficult terrain] composed of snow or ice doesn’t cost it extra movement.

Grappled.name: Grappled
Grappled.description: The target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} if it is a Medium or smaller creature

Mirror Hag.name: Mirror Hag
Mirror Hag.description:
This hunchbacked crone’s sallow skin is covered with growths and lesions.

Hideous Hex. Until a creature can see past the hag’s deformities, she curses it with the pain of a disfigured life. Some mirror hags do this for the betterment of all, but most do it because causing pain amuses them.

Warped Features. Mirror hags are hunchbacked, with growths and lesions covering their skin. Their joints misalign, and the extremities of their bones press against their skin. However, it is their faces that inspire legends: the blackest moles sprouting long white hairs, noses resembling half-eaten carrots, and eyes mismatched in size, color, and alignment. If a creature recoils from a mirror hag’s looks, she bestows her reconfiguring curse on it.

Mirror Covens. Mirror hags can form a coven with two other hags. Generally, mirror hags only form covens with other mirror hags, but from time to time a mirror hag will join a coven of witches or green hags.

Confounding Ugliness.name: Confounding Ugliness
Confounding Ugliness.description:
Any Humanoid that starts its turn within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and can see the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s true form must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} until the start of its next turn.

If the Humanoid’s saving throw is successful, it is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Confounding Ugliness for the next 24 hours.

Unless the target is &Reference[surprise]{surprised} or the revelation of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s true form is sudden, the target can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the Humanoid does so, it can’t see the [[lookup @name lowercase]] until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again.

If the Humanoid looks at the [[lookup @name lowercase]] in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

Incapacitated.name: Incapacitated
Incapacitated.description: The target is &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} until the start of its next turn.

Reconfiguring Curse.name: Reconfiguring Curse
Reconfiguring Curse.description:
The mirror hag curses one creature she can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of her, corrupting its form.

The target must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a success, the target is immune to the hag’s Reconfiguring Curse for the next 24 hours.

On a failure, the target is cursed, suffering one of the following effects of the hag’s choice:

  • Disfigured. The target’s skin erupts with growths and lesions, and it has disadvantage on all Charisma checks made to influence Humanoids, except for Intimidation.

  • Sickly. The target becomes frail and unhealthy, and it has disadvantage on Constitution saving throws. It regains only half its lost hp at the end of a long rest, and it halves the result of any Hit Dice rolled to restore hp during a short rest.

  • Twisted. The target’s limbs and spine become bent and clumsy. It has disadvantage on all Dexterity checks and Dexterity saving throws, and its speed is reduced by 10 feet.

  • Withered. The target’s muscles atrophy, and it has disadvantage on all Strength checks and Strength saving throws.

Foundry Note

  1. The Disfigured activity provides an Active Effect that will set a CHA-based skill checks at disadvantage.

  2. The Sickly activity provides an Active Effect that will set a CHA save at disadvantage and hooks into a module level application that halves HP recovery for short- and long-rests.

  3. The Twisted activity provides an Active Effect that will set a DEX-based skill checks and saves at disadvantage. It will also reduce the movement speed.

  4. The Withered activity provides an Active Effect that will set a STR-based skill checks and saves at disadvantage.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using [[lookup @attributes.spell.abilityLabel]] as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC [[lookup @attributes.spell.dc]]):
