Carry Off.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can fly at half its flying speed when dragging two creatures it has grappled or at its full flying speed if dragging only one creature it has grappled.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Beak]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

Claw.name: Claw
Claw.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 15) if it is a Medium or smaller creature.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has two [[/item claws]], each of which can grapple only one target.

Escape Check.name: Escape Check
Escape Check.condition: If a creature is grappled by the Kongamato

Terrifying Screech.name: Terrifying Screech
Terrifying Screech.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] releases a screech in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in the area must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} until the end of its next turn.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t frightened.

Frightened.name: Frightened
Frightened.description: The target is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} until the end of its next turn.

Flyby.name: Flyby
Flyby.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t provoke an &Reference[OpportunityAttacks] when it flies out of an enemy’s reach.

Ash Drake.name: Ash Drake
Ash Drake.description:
A lean and dull-scaled drake perches on a chimney as if it just crawled out, its tail still hanging into the flue as smoke billows out.

Chimney Nesting. Ash drakes clog chimney flues and delight in dusting crowds with thick, choking ash and soot, while the drakes laugh with sneering, wheezing tones. To placate the creatures, owners of smelters and smithies leave large piles of ash for the drakes to play in, with the hope they leave the shop and workers alone. Anyone hunting ash drakes finds them difficult to attack in their cramped lairs because the creatures blend in with the surroundings. Ash drakes often befriend kobolds, who have little trouble appeasing the drakes and appreciate the added security they bring.

Hunt Strays and Pets. Ash drakes eat rats and stray animals, although few can resist snatching an unattended pet. Contrary to popular opinion, this drake doesn’t consume ash, but enjoys a pile of ash like a cat would catnip, rolling around in it and becoming wild-eyed. Anyone who disrupts such play becomes the target of the creature’s intensely hot, sooty breath weapon.

Slender Dragons. While an ash drake is three feet long with a four-foot-long tail that seems to trail off into smoke, it weighs less than one might expect—approximately ten pounds. Every third winter, when chimneys are active, a male drake leaves his lair to find a mate. The resulting eggs are left in a suitable chimney, and one of the parents protects the young until they leave the nest at two years of age.

Volcanic Haunts. Ash drakes outside a city live in or near volcanic plateaus and mutter about the lack of neighbors to bully. In the wild, an ash drake may partner with a red dragon or flame dragon (see page 116), since the dragon provides its lesser cousin with plenty of ash.

Firesight.name: Firesight
Firesight.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can see through areas obscured by fire, smoke, and fog without penalty.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The ash drake makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

Ash Cloud.name: Ash Cloud
Ash Cloud.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] beats its wings, filling the area within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it with ash for 1 minute.

The ash spreads around corners, and its area is &Reference[heavily obscured].

Each creature that isn’t an [[lookup @name lowercase]] and that enters the cloud for the first time on its turn or starts its turn there must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or become &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its next turn.

The ash moves with the [[lookup @name lowercase]], remaining centered on it for the duration.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its next turn.

Ash Breath.name: Ash Breath
Ash Breath.description:
The ash [[lookup @name lowercase]] blistering hot, choking ash in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in the area must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t poisoned.

A poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description: The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute. A poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Black Knight Commander.name: Black Knight Commander
Black Knight Commander.description: The black knight commander strikes an imposing figure upon its chosen mount; one that inspires bloodlust in its allies and fear in its foes. Devoted to its own twisted code, the black knight commander has a sense of honor but spares no compassion for those who stand in its way. Whether the knight fights for a dark lord or a demonic god, all its foes will be trampled into the dust and their families slaughtered so there can be no revenge. The only victory is a total victory.

Hateful Presence.name: Hateful Presence
Hateful Presence.description:
Each friendly creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] gains a +2 bonus on weapon damage rolls but can’t use the &Reference[Help] action.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect can provide the target with the bonuses mentioned above. However, it's important to monitor the distance between you and the creatures that received the bonus. There is no automated system to automatically calculate distances and revoke the bonus if a creature moves out of the area of effect (AOE).

+2 Weapon Damage.name: +2 Weapon Damage
+2 Weapon Damage.description: The target gains a +2 bonus on weapon damage rolls but can’t use the &Reference[Help] action.

Mounted Charge.name: Mounted Charge
Mounted Charge.description: If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature while mounted and then hits it with a Lance attack on the same turn, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can use a bonus action to command its mount to make one melee weapon attack against that creature as a reaction.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Lance]] attack and two [[/item Mace]] attacks.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is mounted, its mount can then make one Hooves attack.

If both Mace attacks hit one creature, the target takes an extra [[/damage average]] damage.

Frightful Charge.name: Frightful Charge
Frightful Charge.description:
While mounted, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] lets loose a terrifying cry. It then moves up to 30 feet in a straight line and can move through the space of any Large or smaller creature. This movement doesn’t provoke &Reference[opportunity attacks].

The first time it enters a creature’s space during this move, that creature must make a [[/save format=long activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average activity=dnd5eactivity000]] damage and is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t frightened.

A frightened creature can make a [[/save format=long activity=obOhPyuIuHL4Bqse]] at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

affects.special: The first time it enters a creature’s space during this move

Frightened.name: Frightened
Frightened.description: The target is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute.

Plate Armor.name: Plate Armor
Plate Armor.description: Plate consists of shaped, interlocking metal plates to cover the entire body. A suit of plate includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and thick layers of padding underneath the armor. Buckles and straps distribute the weight over the body.

Locked Saddle.name: Locked Saddle
Locked Saddle.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t be knocked prone, dismounted, or moved against its will while mounted.

Lance.name: Lance
Lance.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]].

Special. You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

Mounted Warrior.name: Mounted Warrior
Mounted Warrior.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is rarely seen without its warhorse mount.

The warhorse wears custom barding that raises is Armor Class to 15, and mounting and dismounting the warhorse costs the [[lookup @name lowercase]] only 5 feet of movement.

While the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is mounted, its mount can’t be charmed or frightened.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect (AE) will be attached to the summoned warhorse, but it will initially be disabled. After placing the summoned creature on the scene, navigate to its Effects tab in the character sheet and enable the "Barding AC 15" AE. Enabling this effect will update the creature's statistics as described above.

There is another AE on the Mounted Warrior activity that can be applied to the [[lookup @name lowercase]] while mounted, adding the Frightened condition to the character sheet.

Charmed/Frightened CI.name: Charmed/Frightened CI
Charmed/Frightened CI.description: While the ghost knight is mounted, its mount can’t be charmed or frightened.

Shroud.name: Shroud
Shroud.description:
The translucent person calls out a name in a barely audible whisper.

Bitter Spirits. Shrouds are transitional creatures: remnants of wicked people who died but refuse to rest in peace, yet have not grown strong enough to become shadows. They are aggressive enemies of all living creatures and the light that nurtures life. Shrouds blend naturally into darkness, but they stand out starkly in bright light.

Thin Outlines. Shrouds look like flickering shadowy outlines of the people they were before they died, retaining the same height and body type.

Repetitive Speech. Shrouds cannot converse, but they occasionally can be heard cruelly whispering a name, term, or phrase over and over again: something that must have had meaning to them in life.

Shadow Evolution.name: Shadow Evolution
Shadow Evolution.description:
If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] deals at least 12 necrotic damage to a creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead in 1 minute or less, the shroud transforms into a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.QGcQYZbVl4bWzi4E]{shadow} at the start of the turn after it last dealt damage.

It uses the statistics of the shadow, except it reduces the shadow’s hp by an amount equal to the damage the shroud took before it transformed.

Sunlight Weakness.name: Sunlight Weakness
Sunlight Weakness.description:
While in sunlight, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

Foundry Note

This feature includes an Active Effect in the Effects tab to apply disadvantage on ability saves and skill checks. However, there is currently no automation to apply disadvantage to attack rolls.

Sunlight Weakness.name: Sunlight Weakness
Sunlight Weakness.description: While in sunlight, the shroud has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

Strength Drain.name: Strength Drain
Strength Drain.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target has disadvantage on weapon attacks that use Strength until the end of its next turn.

If a non-evil humanoid dies from this attack, a new [[lookup @name lowercase]] rises from the corpse [[/r 1d4]] hours later.

Foundry Note

This feature includes an Active Effect (AE) that can be used as a reminder by the target but does not automate the activity above.

Strength Drain.name: Strength Drain
Strength Drain.description: Until the end of its next turn, the creature has disadvantage on Strength-based weapon attacks.

Shadow Stealth.name: Shadow Stealth
Shadow Stealth.description: While in dim light or darkness, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes the &Reference[Hide] action.

Amorphous.name: Amorphous
Amorphous.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Bereginyas.name: Bereginyas
Bereginyas.description:
These small, winged faeries appear to be made of gray mist, and they can conceal themselves completely in the fogbanks and clouds enshrouding their mountainous lairs.

Mist Dancers. These evil, cunning faeries (whose name means “mist dancers” in Old Elvish) overcome their victims by seeping into the creature’s lungs to choke it on the bereginyas’s foul essence.

Mountain Spirits. They are most commonly found in the highest mountain ranges, often above the tree line, but they can be encountered in any foggy or misty mountainous region. Shepherds and goatherds often leave bits of milk or cheese to placate them, particularly during the spring lambing season.

Foul Form.name: Foul Form
Foul Form.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s semi-solid form emits poisonous gases.

Any creature that starts its turn within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned}

A creature that succeeds on this saving throw by 5 or more is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Foul Form for the next 24 hours.

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description: The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned}.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

If both attacks hit the same target, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] attaches to the target. While attached, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can use only the [[/item Smother]] action, and it moves with the target whenever the target moves, requiring none of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s movement.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement.

A creature, including the target, can take its action to detach the [[lookup @name lowercase]] by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]].

Smother.name: Smother
Smother.description:
While attached to a creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] extends a tendril of poisonous gas down the creature’s throat.

The creature must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, it takes [[/damage average]] damage, immediately runs out of breath, and begins &Reference[suffocating apply=false]{suffocating}.

On a success, it takes half the damage, doesn’t run out of breath, and isn’t suffocating.

Suffocation ends if the creature dies, if the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is removed from the creature, or if the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is killed.

A suffocating creature that fails this saving throw reduces its remaining rounds of breath by 1.

Sufficating.name: Sufficating
Sufficating.description:
The target immediately runs out of breath, and begins &Reference[suffocating apply=false]{suffocating}.

Suffocation ends if the attacking creature dies, if it is removed from the target, or if the attacking creature is killed.

Abominable Beauty.name: Abominable Beauty
Abominable Beauty.description:
An otherworldly humanoid of such indescribable beauty, it pains anyone’s eyes to gaze upon her.

Beauty that Destroys. An abominable beauty is so perfect that her gaze blinds, her voice is so melodious that no ears can withstand it, and her touch is so tantalizing that it burns like fire. In adolescence, this fey creature adopts features that meet the superficial ideals of the nearest humanoid population: long-legged elegance near elves, a stout figure with lustrous hair near dwarves, unscarred or emerald skin near goblins.

Jealous and Cruel. Abominable beauties are so consumed with being the most beautiful creature in the region that they invariably grow jealous and paranoid about potential rivals. Because such an abominable beauty cannot abide competition, she seeks to kill anyone whose beauty is compared to her own.

Male of the Species. Male abominable beauties are rare but even more jealous in their rages.

Burning Touch.name: Burning Touch
Burning Touch.description:
When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with a [[/item Slam]] attack, the Slam deals an extra 21 (6d6) fire damage (included in the attack).

In addition, a creature that touches the [[lookup @name lowercase]] or hits her with a melee weapon attack while within 5 feet of her takes [[/damage average]] damage.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] uses [[/item Blinding Gaze]]. She then makes two [[/item Slam]] attacks.

Blinding Gaze.name: Blinding Gaze
Blinding Gaze.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] fixes her gaze on a creature within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of her.

If the target can see the beauty’s eyes, the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[blinded apply=falses]{blinded} for 1 minute.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature’s saving throw is successful, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Blinding Gaze for the next 24 hours.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=falses]{blinded} for 1 minute.

Deafening Voice.name: Deafening Voice
Deafening Voice.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] speaks a lilting incantation.

Each creature within 30 feet of her and that can hear her voice must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is &Reference[deafened apply=false]{deafened} for 1 hour.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage, isn’t deafened, and is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s Deafening Voice for the next 24 hours.

Immolated Vengeful Spirit.name: Immolated Vengeful Spirit
Immolated Vengeful Spirit.description:
The ghostly humanoid floats through the air, its head hovering several inches above its severed neck.

A vengeful spirit is created when a strong-willed humanoid with magical talent is killed by relatively mundane means wielded by angry or fearful people. The victim’s angry spirit returns, looking for retribution against those involved in its death—whether that death was wrongful murder or justified execution. These spirits inflict punishment on the living with the rage that animates them, and they mete out their revenge in poetic fashion.

Varied Vengeance. A vengeful spirit is defined by its means of death. Regardless of the cause of death, each vengeful spirit seeks to have its killer or killers die in like fashion. This spirit was burned at the stake, perished in a building set alight by angry villagers, or similarly killed by fire.

Other Vengeful Spirits

The statistics presented here are for a beheaded vengeful spirit. Other types of vengeful spirits use these statistics, except as defined below.

Immolated. This spirit was burned at the stake, perished in a building set alight by angry villagers, or similarly killed by fire. An immolated vengeful spirit has immunity to fire damage, and its Decapitation action is renamed to Conflagration. Conflagration can target any creature, and it deals fire damage instead of slashing damage. In addition, a target that fails the saving throw is ignited, instead of losing its head, and takes 5 (1d10) fire damage at the start of each turn until another creature takes an action to douse the fire.

Strangled. This spirit was the victim of strangulation or an ill-performed hanging. Its Decapitation action is renamed to Asphyxiation. Asphyxiation can target only a creature that needs to breathe, and it deals bludgeoning damage instead of slashing damage. In addition, a target that fails the saving throw is suffocating, instead of losing its head, until the spirit dies or until lifted by the remove curse or dispel magic (DC 13) spell.

Conflagration.name: Conflagration
Conflagration.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] points at one creature it can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet and that is below half its hp maximum.

The target must make a [[/save format=long activity=dnd5eactivity000]], taking [[/damage average activity=dnd5eactivity000]] damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

A target that fails the saving throw is ignited and takes [[/damage average activity=1FlYeAbOQiMMey4K]] damage at the start of each of its turns until another creature takes an action to douse the fire.

Angry Defiance.name: Angry Defiance
Angry Defiance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] adds its Charisma modifier to its AC (included in the character sheet).

Incorporeal Movement.name: Incorporeal Movement
Incorporeal Movement.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move through other creatures and objects as if they were &Reference[difficult terrain]. It takes [[/damage average]] damage if it ends its turn inside a solid object.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Essence of Rage.name: Essence of Rage
Essence of Rage.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be enraged until the end of its next turn.

While enraged, the target has advantage on melee attack rolls and must move to and attack the nearest creature other than the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

In addition, attack rolls against the enraged target have advantage.

Foundry Note

This feature includes an Active Effect (AE) that can be used as a reminder by the target but does not automate advantage on attacks at this time.

Enraged.name: Enraged
Enraged.description:
The target is enraged until the end of its next turn.

While enraged, the target has advantage on melee attack rolls and must move to and attack the nearest creature other than the spirit.

In addition, attack rolls against the enraged target have advantage.

Water Leaper.name: Water Leaper
Water Leaper.description:
The frogheaded, legless creature with wide, batlike wings opens its gaping maw and shrieks. Its long, sinuous tail whips around it, tipped in a barb dripping with poison.

Gliding Wings. The creature has no legs or arms, but it sports a pair of wide, membranous wings. It uses its wings to glide beneath the water and to soar through the air.

Scourge of Waterways. Water leapers plague fresh lakes and rivers. They prey on animals that come to the water’s edge to drink, as well as on fishermen that ply their trade in the water leaper’s territory. Stories circulate among fishers of waterways known for broken lines and missing bait. Fishers give these areas a wide berth for fear of water leapers. Desperate or unwary fishers who ignore the warnings are never seen again; drifting, empty boats are the signs of their passing.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and one [[/item Stinger]] attack.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC [[lookup @skills.ath.passive]]).

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, and the water leaper can’t [[/item Bite]] another target.

Grappled & Restrained.name: Grappled & Restrained
Grappled & Restrained.description:
The target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled}.

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}

Stinger.name: Stinger
Stinger.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute.

While poisoned in this way, the creature takes [[/damage average activity=iilHNPrJoT8pFSzi]] damage at the start of each of its turns.

A poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

damage.condition: If poisoned by the attacking creature

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description: The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute.

Amphibious.name: Amphibious
Amphibious.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can breathe air and water.

Underwater Camouflage.name: Underwater Camouflage
Underwater Camouflage.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made while underwater.

Swallow.name: Swallow
Swallow.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack against a Medium or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target is also swallowed, and the grapple ends.

While swallowed, the target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} and &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, it has &Reference[total cover] against attacks and other effects outside the [[lookup @name lowercase]], and it takes [[/damage average]] damage at the start of each of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s turns. A [[lookup @name lowercase]] can have only one creature swallowed at a time.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes 15 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] at the end of that turn or regurgitate the creature, which falls &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone} in a space within 5 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies, a swallowed creature is no longer restrained by it and can escape from the corpse by using 10 feet of movement, exiting &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Save: 15+ Damage.name: Save: 15+ Damage
Save: 15+ Damage.condition: If the water leaper takes 15 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature

Damage: While Swallowed.name: Damage: While Swallowed
Damage: While Swallowed.condition: If a creature is swallowed by the gug

Escape Corpse.name: Escape Corpse
Escape Corpse.condition: Must use 10 feet of movement to escape

Swallowed.name: Swallowed
Swallowed.description: While swallowed, the target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} and &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, it has &Reference[total cover] against attacks and other effects outside the creature.

Prone.name: Prone
Prone.description: A swallowed creature escaping the stomach lands &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Gerridae.name: Gerridae
Gerridae.description:
This large water-striding insect resembles a strange cross between a camel and a wingless, long-legged locust. A large hollow in the small of its back holds enough space for a rider.

Elvish Water Steeds. Known by their Elvish name, these large fey water striders were enchanted and bred by the elves in ages past, when their explorers roamed the world. Elven mages started with normal water striders and—through elaborate magical procedures and complex cross-breeding programs—transformed the mundane water striders into large, docile mounts. They can cross large bodies of water quickly while carrying a humanoid rider, even in windy conditions.

Fond of Sweet Scents. Gerridae can sometimes be distracted by appealing scents, such as from apple blossoms or fresh hay. They are also fond of raw duck and swan.

Gerridae in Midgard

Since the elven retreat from Midgard almost 500 years ago, many of the gerridae have gone feral, and while normally shy and docile, they can attack in furious swarms if hunted or surprised in their claimed territories. Some enterprising elfmarked Barsellan pirates have domesticated them and use the water striders as chasers and boarding craft when taking on Bemmean and Septime ships.

Bred to the Saddle.name: Bred to the Saddle
Bred to the Saddle.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t be charmed or frightened while it has a rider.

Water Bound.name: Water Bound
Water Bound.description: For every hour the [[lookup @name lowercase]] spends on dry land, its hp maximum is reduced by 2 ([[/r 1d4]]).

Water Walker.name: Water Walker
Water Walker.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move across the surface of water as if it were harmless, solid ground. This trait works like the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.YBda6nLKjxdT1LbS]{water walk} spell.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The gerridae makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and one [[/item Claw]] attack.

Lake Troll.name: Lake Troll
Lake Troll.description:
This large, lanky creature has arms too long for its body. Its hands are webbed and equipped with wicked claws. Its skin is covered in dull green scales and embedded with stones, and limp hair like scraggly seaweed hangs across its long-nosed face.

Water-dwelling cousins of the more common trolls, lake trolls are both stronger and slightly more intelligent, but thankfully less common. Accompanied by a reek of old, rotting fish, these slimy creatures live beneath the surface of lakes, ponds, rivers, and sometimes even ocean coves.

Violently Territorial. A lake troll is savage in the defense of its claimed expanse of territory; any encroachment into the creature’s water is met with sudden violence from the depths. Fishermen are the most vulnerable to these attacks, especially when they explore new bodies of water.

Cruel Cunning. Even seasoned soldiers are wise enough to fear the claws of a lake troll; a person with no weapon facing the creature is doomed. Lake trolls delight in splintering wood and twisting metal with their talons and in shrugging off the deadliest of blows with their tough hide. They often prioritize wielders of grand weapons because they delight in the horror brought on by dulling their prey’s weapons with a few strokes of their powerful claws. Lake trolls are cunning ambushers. They make use of the water to cover their attack and to protect themselves from the flames of would-be troll hunters.

Hard to Kill. A lake troll’s regeneration is shut down only by cold and fire damage at nearly the same time, making them tricky to fight and exceedingly difficult to kill. Many adventurers have been shocked or slain when a lake troll they presumed was burned to death suddenly leapt back into the fray. Because they’re reclusive and so very lethal, these creatures are poorly understood by most scholars.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

If both Claw attacks hit one creature that is wielding a weapon, the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or the target’s weapon takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls.

If the weapon’s penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed.

If the target is wielding more than one weapon, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] chooses which weapon to affect.

Foundry Note: Warp Weapon Enchantment Activity

On a failed Dex save, choose one weapon (mundane or magic) the target is wielding (not shields or foci) and apply the appropriate “Warp Weapon –N” enchantment on that weapon in the chat card.

You will need to open the PC’s sheet and drag that weapon onto the enchantment drop zone in chat after you place the enchantment in chat, which will then apply the penalty and modify its title on the affected weapon.

Start with -1 and increase the penalty by one each time on the same object to attack. Each additional failed save against the troll using the same weapon warps it further: remove the existing Warped enchantment and replace it with Warped –2, then –3, and so on, up to the limits described above.

Amphibious.name: Amphibious
Amphibious.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can breathe air and water.

Keen Smell.name: Keen Smell
Keen Smell.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

Regeneration.name: Regeneration
Regeneration.description:
The [[lookup @name]] regains [[/heal]] at the start of his turn.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes cold or fire damage, it regains only [[/heal activity=BYAJHk4WQObqaj2G]] at the start of its next turn.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes both cold and fire damage, this trait doesn’t function at the start of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s next turn.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hp and doesn’t regenerate.

Death Butterfly Swarm.name: Death Butterfly Swarm
Death Butterfly Swarm.description:
These enormous clouds of orange and green butterflies add a reek of putrefaction to the air, stirred by the flapping of their delicate wings.

Demon-Haunted. A death butterfly swarm results when a rare breed of carrion-eating butterfly, drawn en masse to the stench of decay, feeds on the corpse of a fiend, demon, or similar creature.

Dizzying and Poisonous. The colorful, chaotic flapping of the insects’ wings blinds and staggers those in its path, allowing the swarm to necrotize flesh from those it overruns. Attracted to rotting material, the swarm spreads a fast-acting, poison on its victims, creating carrion it can feed on immediately.

Devour the Undead. Undead creatures are not immune to a death butterfly swarm’s poison. A swarm can rot an undead creature’s animating energies as easily as those of the living. Given the choice between an undead and living creature, a death butterfly swarm always attacks the undead, finding ghouls and vampires particularly appealing. Some good-aligned forces regard summoning these swarms as a necessary evil.

Potent Poison.name: Potent Poison
Potent Poison.description: Undead with resistance or immunity to poison damage or the poisoned condition can be affected by the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s poison.

Weight of Wings.name: Weight of Wings
Weight of Wings.description:
A creature that starts its turn in the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s space has its speed halved and must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or become &Reference[blinded aplly=false]{blinded}.

Both effects end when the creature ends its turn outside the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s space.

On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the blinding effect of Weight of Wings for the next 24 hours.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded aplly=false]{blinded}.

Bites.name: Bites
Bites.description:
Melee Weapon Attack: [[/attack]], reach 0 ft. , one creature in the swarm’s space. Hit: [[/damage average]] damage, or [[/damage average activity=QohFCLptnGJO6uT5]] damage if the swarm has half of its hp or fewer.

The target must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, it takes [[/damage average activity=dnd5eactivity100]] damage and is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

On a success, it takes half the damage and isn’t poisoned.

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description: The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can occupy another creature’s space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny insect. The swarm can’t regain hp or gain temporary hp.

Miremal.name: Miremal
Miremal.description:
A short, lean, biped emerges from the shadows. Fungi and mosses cover its pale-skinned body, growing into its flesh. Its green eyes weep bloody tears.

Miremals are savage, degenerate fey who delight in crafting paths through treacherous swamps. These seemingly safe paths are riddled with traps and ambush points.

Unreliable Guides. Miremals hunt in packs of three to six and often serve a more powerful creature, especially one that commands potent magic. As a result, many of their paths lead travelers into the grove of a green hag coven or into the lair of a black dragon.

Swamp Dwellers. Miremals have adapted from sylvan forests to the swamps: patches of red and green fungus sprout from their skin, mushrooms and branches grow haphazardly out of their bodies, and moss hangs from beneath their arms. They can even take on a puddle-like form when close to death, escaping from whatever seeks to harm them. Their eyes are forest green and perpetually wet with bloody tears. Their legends say their tears come from rage over the banishment from their forest homes and agony from knowing they can never return.

Hate Moss Lurkers. Miremals are occasionally confused with @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures-m.Actor.nWzyo8lSMRZExl60]{moss lurkers} (see page 278), but the two despise one another and both consider the comparison odious.

Miremals in Midgard

Miremals once served the Faerie Queen Titania as honorable scouts and spies. The habits of mind they cultivated, though, made them susceptible to the blandishments of Titania’s dark sister Sarastra, Queen of Night and Magic. She planted within the miremal a hunger for flesh, and many succumbed to Sarastra’s enchantment. They turned against those fey who resisted and devoured their former companions.

When the miremal regained their senses, they saw the slaughter they had wrought, including the remains of a cherished young changeling Titania had sworn to protect. Titania cursed and banished the miremal, changing their form and admonishing them to repent and atone. They have not heeded her warning and have shown no remorse.

Muddled Escape.name: Muddled Escape
Muddled Escape.description:
If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes 7 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hp, it is reduced to 1 hp instead and becomes a puddle of filthy swamp water.

At the start of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s next turn, it can move up to 15 feet as a puddle.

Then it returns to its normal form.

Swamp Camouflage.name: Swamp Camouflage
Swamp Camouflage.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in swampy terrain.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and one [[/item Claw]] attack.

Bog Spew.name: Bog Spew
Bog Spew.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] spews a noxious stream of bog filth mixed with stomach acid at one creature it can see within 20 feet of it.

The target must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, the target takes [[/damage average]] damage and is &Reference[blinded apply=blind]{blinded} until the end of its next turn.

On a success, the target takes half the damage and isn’t blinded.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=blind]{blinded} until the end of its next turn.

Amphibious.name: Amphibious
Amphibious.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can breathe air and water.

Swamp Adder.name: Swamp Adder
Swamp Adder.description:
The vicious snake with a squat, diamond-shaped head, a puffed neck, and a peculiar yellow band around its body slithered slowly through the marsh.

Marsh Hunter. This venomous snake—sometimes known as the “speckled band”—is native to the marshes of southern realms, where it devours waterfowl and incautious halflings.

Bred for Venom. The swamp adder is simultaneously feared and prized for its potent paralytic venom. A swamp adder is quite thin, and the largest weigh as much as 50 pounds. A dose of paralytic swamp adder venom is worth 3,000 gp or more in some markets.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, the target takes [[/damage average activity=dnd5eactivity100]] damage and is &Reference[paralyzed apply=false]{paralyzed} for 1 minute.

On a success, a target takes half the damage and isn’t paralyzed.

The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Paralyzed.name: Paralyzed
Paralyzed.description:
The target is is &Reference[paralyzed apply=false]{paralyzed} for 1 minute.

The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Swamp Camouflage.name: Swamp Camouflage
Swamp Camouflage.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in swampy terrain.

Gearforged Templar.name: Gearforged Templar
Gearforged Templar.description:
The bronze and mithral figure advances with heavy movements. Its eye lenses glare dark blue, and gears click when it swings its glaive.

Mechanical Champion. An intricate construction of bronze, steel, copper, and mithral, the gearforged templar is an imposing sight. A humanoid spirit contained in a soulgem animates the heavy body of gears and springs. Gearforged are relatively rare, and the templar is a paragon among them.

Tireless Defender. The gearforged templar is relentless in pursuit of its duty. More so than other gearforged, the templar becomes fixed on its charge to the exclusion of distractions and even magical coercion. Gearforged templars serve as commanders of military or guard units, bodyguards for important individuals, or personal champions for nobility.

Defensive Zone.name: Defensive Zone
Defensive Zone.description: When a creature enters the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s reach, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Greatsword]] attack against the creature.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The gearforged templar makes four [[/item Greatsword]] or [[/item Javelin]] attacks.

If two Greatsword attacks hit one creature, the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be pushed up to 10 feet away from the templar.

The templar can choose not to push a creature.

Whirlwind.name: Whirlwind
Whirlwind.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] whirls its greatsword in a great arc.

Each creature within 10 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Construct Nature.name: Construct Nature
Construct Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Parry.name: Parry
Parry.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it.

To do so, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect (AE) is available to activate the AC bonus on the Effects tab of the character sheet.

utility.condition: When hit by a melee attack

Eala.name: Eala
Eala.description:
This swanlike creature’s feathers are made of shining metal. When it inhales, the feathers on its chest glow red hot.

Eala are beautiful but deadly creatures native to the Plane of Shadow. They grow feathers like their Material Plane counterparts, but their feathers are made of gleaming, razor-sharp metal.

Metallic Diet. Eala plumage displays a stunning mixture of metallic colors, which vary depending on their diet. An eala uses its fire breath to melt metals with low melting points such as gold, silver, lead, copper, and bronze. The eala consumes the molten metal, some of which migrates into the creature’s deadly feathers. Eala that display primarily or entirely a single color are highly prized among some nobility.

Eala in Midgard

Eala are favorites of Sarastra, the Queen of Night and Magic and a ruler of the shadow fey. She is partial to jet black eala, and all such specimens are brought to her flock at the Winter Palace. Those who bring her such birds are rewarded with a magical dagger and the title and status of “Honored Eala Catcher,” or “Lord or Lady of Black Feathers” for those who bring her several.

Swan Song.name: Swan Song
Swan Song.description:
When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is reduced to 0 hp, it can use its last breath to sing a plaintive and beautiful melody.

Each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it that can hear the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[incapacitated appky=false]{incapacitated} until the end of its next turn.

While incapacitated, the creature’s speed is reduced to 0.

Incapacitated.name: Incapacitated
Incapacitated.description: The target is &Reference[incapacitated appky=false]{incapacitated} until the end of its next turn.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The eala makes two [[/item Wing Blades]] attacks.

Fire Breath.name: Fire Breath
Fire Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] breathes fire in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in the area must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s fire breath ignites flammable objects and melts soft metals, such as gold and lead, in the area that aren’t being worn or carried.

Vine Troll Skeleton.name: Vine Troll Skeleton
Vine Troll Skeleton.description:
Moss and flowering vines cover the hulking skeleton.

Corrupted Earth Magic. Vine troll skeletons guard @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.fm2p5JVYtEBfIV0n]{duskthorn dryad} (see page 150) glades and the sacred circles of druids; others serve the @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.degnu3X7o8BrbrKu]{vila} (see page 386) or even @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.nWzyo8lSMRZExl60]{moss lurker} (see page 278) colonies as guardians. In each case, they were created by corrupted earth magic for a purpose, and that energy empowers great strength and endurance—but little in the way of wits.

Constant Regrowth. The vines holding the skeleton together regenerate quickly. This powerful magic allows vine troll skeletons to reattach severed limbs. Just like with their living cousins, only fire or acid can destroy vine troll skeletons, rendering the living vines harmless.

Bound to a Tree’s Heart. Vine troll skeletons are direct offshoots of the main vine wrapped around a duskthorn dryad’s tree, a treant, or a @UUID[Actor.zwkxlTqq07dTUGFW]{weeping treant} (see page 369). They are created by enchanting a dead troll’s heart and fusing that heart with the vines of a duskthorn dryad or with the heartwood of a tree or treant, calling on magic similar to that involved in binding a dryad to her tree. Killing the duskthorn dryad or destroying the heart at the center of the parent tree kills the skeleton bound to that heart. Because of this, vine troll skeletons are single-minded defenders of their parent tree or duskthorn dryad.

Tree Bound.name: Tree Bound
Tree Bound.description:
The vine troll skeleton is magically bound to a @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.fm2p5JVYtEBfIV0n]{duskthorn dryad}, tree, or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NB6wUgVqeOQtsQKu]{treant}, and the skeleton must stay within 1 mile of it.

If the skeleton’s bound duskthorn dryad, tree, or treant dies, the skeleton is immediately destroyed and doesn’t regenerate.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks, or it makes three [[/item Poisoned Thorn]] attacks.

Regeneration.name: Regeneration
Regeneration.description:
The [[lookup @name]] regains [[/heal]] at the start of its turn.

If the skeleton takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn’t function at the start of the skeleton’s next turn.

The skeleton dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hp and doesn’t regenerate or if its bound tree is destroyed (see [[/item Tree Bound]] trait).

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Deathwisp.name: Deathwisp
Deathwisp.description:
A shadowy figure flickers in and out of view. Its indistinct shape betrays a sylvan ancestry, and its eyes are malevolent blue points of light.

Fey Undead. A deathwisp is a wraith-like spirit created in the Shadow Realm from the violent death of a shadow fey or evil fey.

Rift Walkers. Many deathwisps remain among the shadows, but a few enter the natural world through planar rifts and gates or by walking along the shadowy roads between the worlds. Retaining only a trace of their former personality and knowledge, their lost kindness has been replaced with malice.

Devour Breath. A deathwisp feasts on the breath of living things, and it invariably seeks to devour animals and solitary, intelligent prey. It is quite intelligent and avoids fights against greater numbers.

Flicker.name: Flicker
Flicker.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] flickers in and out of sight. Ranged weapon attacks against it are made with disadvantage.

Incorporeal Movement.name: Incorporeal Movement
Incorporeal Movement.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move through other creatures and objects as if they were &Reference[difficult terrain]. It takes [[/damage average]] damage if it ends its turn inside a solid object.

Sunlight Sensitivity.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
Sunlight Sensitivity.description: While in sunlight, the deathwisp has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

Shadow Traveler.name: Shadow Traveler
Shadow Traveler.description:
While in shadows, dim light, or darkness, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] disappears into the darkness and reappears in an unoccupied space it can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet.

A tendril of inky smoke appears at the origin and destination when it uses this bonus action.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Ghostly Pike]] attacks, or it can make one Ghostly Pike attack and one [[/item Life Drain]] attack.

Life Drain.name: Life Drain
Life Drain.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]].

The target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or its hp maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken.

This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest.

The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0.

Create Specter.name: Create Specter
Create Specter.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] targets a Humanoid within 10 feet of it that has been dead for no longer than 1 minute and died violently.

The target’s spirit rises as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PuPo4H4Dcxigf0fY]{specter} in the space of its corpse or in the nearest unoccupied space. This specter is under the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s control.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can have no more than twelve specters under its control at one time.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Ia’Affrat.name: Ia’Affrat
Ia’Affrat.description:
A dark, droning cloud containing thousands of gray, thumb-sized wasps, shifts and swarms around the black silhouette of a tall human with glowing red eyes. The wasps, too, glow with the heat of a low-burning coal and are wreathed in foul-smelling smoke.

Faithless Servant. Ia’Affrat the Insatiable is the inverted reflection of his unkempt, overly-unyielding creator, Arbeyach, Hell’s Prince of Swarms. Ia’Affrat acts as Arbeyach’s emissary to the courts of his rivals and to the mortal world as diplomat, spy, assassin, and scourge. Though he serves the rigid and resolute Prince of Hell, Ia’Affrat shows little loyalty to his maker. The eloquent and sophisticated creature has betrayed his master in thousands of small ways over the centuries, and eventually may betray him utterly. Until then, Ia’Affrat’s shifting hive mind pursues an unquenchable lust for arcane mysteries, human interaction, and the material pursuit of unwholesome flavors and dark delights.

Joker and Devourer. Ia’Affrat delights in comedy, wine, song, dance, food, and inflicting torture and public humiliation on his foes—he is a rapacious devourer, greedy for all transient pleasures.

Collective Mind.name: Collective Mind
Collective Mind.description:
Ia’Affrat’s individual Fiends are connected via a hive mind.

He can telepathically communicate with any of his individual Fiends within 50 miles of him, and he can’t be surprised.

If he is reduced to half his hp or lower, his Intelligence score is reduced to 10, he immediately changes into his shapeless form, and he can’t take on a Humanoid form again until he regains hp to be above half his hp or he finishes a long rest.

Foundry Note

This feature also provides an Active Effect (AE) that will modify this creature's INT ability score. You can enable the AE in the effects tab of the character sheet.

10 INT Score.name: 10 INT Score
10 INT Score.description: If Ia’Affrat is reduced to half his hp or lower, his Intelligence score is reduced to 10.

Devil’s Sight.name: Devil’s Sight
Devil’s Sight.description: Magical darkness doesn’t impede Ia’Affrat’s darkvision.

Grasping Limbs (Humanoid Form Only).name: Grasping Limbs (Humanoid Form Only)
Grasping Limbs (Humanoid Form Only).description: Ia’Affrat can wield weapons and hold, grasp, push, pull, or interact with objects that might otherwise require a more Humanoid form to accomplish.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If Ia’Affrat fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: Ia’Affrat has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Smoke Shroud.name: Smoke Shroud
Smoke Shroud.description:
Ia’Affrat emits a cloud of dark smoke within 5 feet of himself.

The area is lightly obscured to all except Ia’Affrat, and each non-devil creature that starts its turn in the smoke must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its turn.

At the start of each of his turns, Ia’Affrat chooses whether this shroud is active.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its turn.

Swarm (Shapeless Form Only).name: Swarm (Shapeless Form Only)
Swarm (Shapeless Form Only).description: Ia’Affrat can occupy another creature’s space and vice versa and can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny insect, but he can’t grapple or be grappled.

Shape Swarm.name: Shape Swarm
Shape Swarm.description:
Ia’Affrat can shape himself into a Large or smaller Humanoid or back into a shapeless mass of Tiny insectoid Fiends.

His statistics, other than his size, are the same in each form, and he can’t regain hp or gain temporary hp, except for the [[/item .sN3zgIbcuXgGAVgQ]]{Consume Host} legendary action.

He can’t take on a Humanoid form if he is occupying the space of another creature.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: Ia’Affrat makes three [[/item .cYCrhBLzOreamNpy]]{Bite} or [[/item .R5jwdfedfjpH1KOI]]{Burning Claw} attacks, or he makes four [[/item Flaming Insect Bolt]] attacks.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description: Ia’Affrat can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Ia’Affrat regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

Bite (Shapeless Form Only).name: Bite (Shapeless Form Only)
Bite (Shapeless Form Only).description:
Melee Weapon Attack: [[/attack]], reach 0 ft. , one target in the swarm’s space. Hit: [[/damage average extended]] damage, or [[/damage average activity=sh6UDHmKTYyC5ZsB]] damage if Ia’Affrat has half of its hp or fewer.

If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

save.condition: When hit

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description: The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

Teleport.name: Teleport
Teleport.description: Ia’Affrat magically teleports, along with any equipment he is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space he can see.

Vermin Breath.name: Vermin Breath
Vermin Breath.description:
Ia’Affrat exhales [[/r 1d4]] @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.S0zDrv6lbnwWaz9E]{swarms of insects} in spaces he can see within 30 feet.

The swarms take their turns immediately after Ia’Affrat, and they are allies of Ia’Affrat, obeying his telepathic commands.

They remain for 1 minute, until Ia’Affrat dies, or until Ia’Affrat dismisses them as a bonus action.

Ia’Affrat can have no more than five swarms of insects under his control at a time.

Consume Host.name: Consume Host
Consume Host.description:
While inhabiting a Humanoid, Ia’Affrat consumes the host from the inside.

The host takes [[/damage average]] damage, and Ia’Affrat regains hp equal to that amount.

Inhabit.name: Inhabit
Inhabit.description:
Ia’Affrat crawls into the body of a Humanoid, or a Humanoid corpse that has been dead no more than 7 days, that he can see within 5 feet of him.

If the target is unwilling, the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or the target loses control of its body, and Ia’Affrat takes control of the body. Ia’Affrat controls the body but doesn’t deprive the target of awareness.

Ia’Affrat can’t be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, and he retains his alignment, his Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores, his [[/item Flaming Insect Bolt]] action and [[/item Teleport]] and [[/item .sN3zgIbcuXgGAVgQ]]{Consume Host} legendary actions, and his condition immunities. He otherwise uses the target’s statistics, but doesn’t gain access to the target’s knowledge, class features, or proficiencies.

If the target was a Humanoid corpse, he uses the statistics it had before it died. Ia’Affrat inhabits the target until the target’s body is reduced to 0 hp, Ia’Affrat ends it as a bonus action, or Ia’Affrat is forced out by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.TkJ8Wtg1L7TZtspm]{dispel evil and good} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.WzvJ7G3cqvIubsLk]{greater restoration} spell.

When the inhabit ends, Ia’Affrat reappears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the target.

The target is immune to Ia’Affrat’s Inhabit for 24 hours after succeeding on the saving throw or after the inhabit ends.

affects.special: a Humanoid, or a Humanoid corpse that has been dead no more than 7 days

Cavelight Moss.name: Cavelight Moss
Cavelight Moss.description:
These patches of tangled, lacy moss cling to the ceiling, slowly pulsing with an eerie glow. Their stems gently writhe among the soft, feathery mass, dusting the ground below with a twinkling of phosphorescent spores.

Plant Carnivore. Cavelight moss glows with a pale, yellow light, but when agitated, its light changes to an icy blue. Cavelight moss is frequently mistaken for a benign organism, but it hunts living flesh and renders its meals immobile before starting the long process of digestion. A cavelight moss is a collective of smaller life forms patched together and sharing sensations. Barely cognitive, a cavelight moss spends its time positioning itself above well-traveled sections of cavern, feeding on rats, bats, and crawling insects. When it senses larger prey, it slowly and quietly moves toward the creature.

Long-Lived Spores. A cavelight moss can survive for 200 years, shedding luminous spores and consuming vermin. Its spores germinate in the carcasses of its victims, and in lean times, these spores can grow slowly on guano or other areas rich in moisture and organic nutrients.

Rare Colonies. If a cave system has no true protectors and food is plentiful, these creatures congregate—most commonly, in bat colonies of millions of individuals. When they gather this way, cavelight mosses function as a large colony, covering strategic locations where prey roams. When a source of food moves on, the entire colony slowly disperses as well.

Variable Illumination.name: Variable Illumination
Variable Illumination.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] sheds bright light in a 5- to 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional number of feet equal to the chosen radius. The moss can alter the radius as a bonus action.

Foundry Note

Token lighting is not enabled by default, but the light color and effect are pre-set.

An @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-macros.Macro.kgSZSzFEECWolfhC]{application is available} that allows you to set or modify the light radius for the selected creature token in the scene when you're ready. This application can also remove the light settings, effectively turning the light off.

When using the application, select the respective creature from the drop-down.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The cavelight moss makes two [[/item Tendrils]] attacks.

If both attacks hit a Large or smaller creature, the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC [[lookup @skills.ath.passive]]).

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, and at the start of each of the target’s turns, it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or suffer one level of &Reference[exhaustion apply=false]{exhaustion}. The cavelight moss then gains [[/healing]].

A creature that succeeds on the saving throw can’t suffer further levels of exhaustion from the cavelight moss’s grapple for the next 24 hours.

The cavelight moss can have only one creature grappled at a time.

Grappled & Restrained.name: Grappled & Restrained
Grappled & Restrained.description:
A Large or smaller creature, the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 15).

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}

Exhaustion.name: Exhaustion
Exhaustion.description: The target gains one level of &Reference[exhaustion apply=false]{exhaustion}.

Spinosaurus.name: Spinosaurus
Spinosaurus.description:
This massive, blue-skinned saurian lumbers out of the river, depositing a platoon of armed lizardfolk on the bank before releasing a terrifying roar.

Friend to Lizardfolk. The spinosaurus is a special saurian bred for size and loyalty by lizardfolk. Lizardfolk prize them like prime warhorses, and lavish them with food and care. As spinosauruses age slowly, most large lizardfolk tribes have several young spinosauruses and one adult spinosaurus in their care, reserving the massive adult for major engagements or when the entire tribe must move at once.

Enormous Size and Color. This immense saurian has a long, tooth-filled maw, powerful claws, and colorful spines running the length of its back. An adult spinosaurus is 70 feet long and weighs 35,000 pounds or more, while a young spinosaurus is a mere 20 feet long, weighing 6,000 pounds or more.

Swift Predator. A spinosaurus is at home on both land and water, chasing prey from one to the other when necessary. Though they are carnivores, they have an affinity for lizardfolk and other reptilian humanoids, eating such creatures only if the creatures horribly mistreat them or if they experience extreme starvation with such creatures as the only option for food.

Spinosauruses in the Southlands

The lizardfolk of Veles-Sa in the Southlands use spinosauruses as a mode of transportation. The creatures are large enough to pull barges or to carry a crew of raiders anywhere on the rivers, and they are swift overland. Lizardfolk scouts are especially fond of these enormous reptiles, as they are powerful combatants and can carry a dozen lizardfolk warriors.

In addition to their role as trained raiders in Veles-Sa, some spinosauruses live in or along most of the major river systems of the Southlands—including the River Nuria. There they are also called “river dragons” or sometimes “river walkers,” and they are frequently associated with the worship of Baal-Hotep and Set. They are kept as sacred animals in several river temples, where they are fed regular meals and have been known to grow to enormous size and strength.

Finally, along the Spice Coast, spinosauruses carry high-value spice cargoes along the coast when banditry is rife or when a lizardfolk mercenary company is available to guard materials going north toward Mhalmet, Nuria, or Ishadia. These Spice Coast beasts are often especially bred for gaudy coloration: green-and-orange, blue-and-gold, and even red-and-black bloodlines have been spotted in the Spice Coast harbors.

Spinosauruses as Mounts

Spinosauruses mate each year in the winter. A male spinosaurus brings food and helps build an enormous nest of reeds, sticks, and mud. Then the male departs, leaving the female to lay and care for the eggs. Spinosaurus eggs are typically found in nests along riversides or deep in marshes. They are sometimes stolen and sold, generally to lizardfolk and sometimes to daring humans with a knack for training animals. These eggs are worth as much as 2,000 gp apiece; live young are worth twice that. Characters eager for spinosaurus mounts, however, should note that buying or domesticating such an enormous carnivore requires vast quantities of food and patience. They do not take easily to domestication.

Before it can be ridden in combat, a spinosaurus must practice bearing the weight of its trainer and passengers. They rarely master more than a handful of tricks, but they are extremely comfortable in the water and can be trained to be are aware that some of their riders may not breathe water.

An adult spinosaurus can carry up to six tons as cargo. Riding a spinosaurus requires an exotic saddle, riding platform, or howdah.

Hold Breath.name: Hold Breath
Hold Breath.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can hold its breath for 1 hour.

Reptilian Affinity.name: Reptilian Affinity
Reptilian Affinity.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] never willingly attacks a reptilian Humanoid, such as a lizardfolk or dragonborn, unless attacked first.

If magically forced to attack such a creature, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls against it.

This trait doesn’t function if the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s rider or tamer directs it to attack.

Siege Monster.name: Siege Monster
Siege Monster.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] deals double damage to objects and structures.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The spinosaurus makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below.

Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

Move.name: Move
Move.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] moves up to half its speed without provoking &Reference[OpportunityAttacks].

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]].

If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 18).

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, and the spinosaurus can’t Bite another target.

Grappled & Restrained.name: Grappled & Restrained
Grappled & Restrained.description:
If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 18).

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}.

Frightful Presence.name: Frightful Presence
Frightful Presence.description:
Each creature of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s choice that is within 120 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and aware of it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature’s saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

Frightful Presence.name: Frightful Presence
Frightful Presence.description: The target is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute, and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Rusalka.name: Rusalka
Rusalka.description:
A barefoot woman with long hair and almost transparent skin sits upon a willow branch. Her hair and clothing are wet, as if she has just returned from a swim. Her smile seems friendly enough.

When a woman drowns, her dripping body may rise again as a rusalka. Some claim the drowning must be a suicide. Others say that the water itself must be tainted with murder or some great evil spirit.

Near Water. Rusalkas dwell in the water where they died, emerging only at night. Some climb a nearby tree, dangle their feet in the water, and sing alluring songs. Others sit on the bank, combing their wet tresses and awaiting prey. They must, however, remain in or near the water where they died, as part of their curse. However, during a full moon, the rusalki can leave the water to dance along the shore or the riverbank, singing all night long and inviting young men to join them.

Songs and Poetry. Rusalkas mesmerize and seduce passersby with song and dance and poetry. Young men are their usual victims, but they also prey on curious children, lonely older men, and other heartbroken women. When a potential victim comes near enough, the rusalki entangles the person with her hair and drags him or her beneath the water to drown.

Lover’s Walks. A rusalka cannot pass for human on any but the darkest night, but she might claim to be a lonely tree spirit or a benevolent nymph willing to grant a wish in exchange for a kiss. She may part the water of a lake and coax her victim toward the center with the promise of a kiss—delivered as her hair entraps the victim and the water rushes around him. Alternatively, she may use water walk so she and the victim can stroll across the surface of the water, reward him with a long kiss (to prevent him from catching a deep breath), then end the spell over deep water and drag him to the bottom.

Undead Nature. A rusalka doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Withered Tresses.name: Withered Tresses
Withered Tresses.description: If a [[lookup @name lowercase]] is kept out of water for 24 consecutive hours, its hair and body dry into desiccated swamp weeds and the creature is utterly destroyed.

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.description:
The rusalka’s innate casting ability is [[lookup @attributes.spell.abilityLabel]] (spell save DC [[lookup @attributes.spell.dc]]). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

At will: [[/item .J88EiXVy8z0KSWxt]]{Control Water}, [[/item .NldtdlhfjEkYlQNt]]{Suggestion}, [[/item .oMytO3T13SD10458]]{Tongues}, [[/item .24UDgSP9kkNa9Zwu]]{Water Walk} (can be ended freely at will)

1/day each: [[/item .RWU8bgS4QQ9t3zts]]{Dominate Person}

Watery Camouflage.name: Watery Camouflage
Watery Camouflage.description: In dim light or darkness, a [[lookup @name lowercase]] that’s underwater is invisible.

Breathless Kiss.name: Breathless Kiss
Breathless Kiss.description:
[[/attack extended]]. Hit: The target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC [[lookup @skills.ath.passive]]) and the [[lookup @name lowercase]] draws all the air from the target’s lungs with a kiss.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has movement remaining, she drags the grappled creature into deep water, where it begins &Reference[suffocation]{suffocating}.

Escape Check.name: Escape Check
Escape Check.condition: If grappled

Grappled.name: Grappled
Grappled.description: The target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} and the attacking creature draws all the air from the target’s lungs with a kiss.

Drowning Hair.name: Drowning Hair
Drowning Hair.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s long hair tangles around a creature the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has grappled.

The creature takes [[/damage average]] damage, or half damage with a successful [[/save format=long]].

In addition, until it escapes the rusalka’s grapple, it is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained} and has disadvantage on Strength checks to break free of the grapple.

save.condition: When grappled by the attacking creature

Drowning Hair.name: Drowning Hair
Drowning Hair.description: The target is is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained} and has disadvantage on Strength checks to break free of the grapple.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Control Water.name: Control Water
Control Water.description:
Until the spell ends, you control any freestanding water inside an area you choose that is a cube up to 100 feet on a side. You can choose from any of the following effects when you cast this spell. As an action on your turn, you can repeat the same effect or choose a different one.

Flood. You cause the water level of all standing water in the area to rise by as much as 20 feet. If the area includes a shore, the flooding water spills over onto dry land, instead create a 20-foot tall wave that travels from one side of the area to the other and then crashes down. Any Huge or smaller vehicles in the wave's path are carried with it to the other side. Any Huge or smaller vehicles struck by the wave have a 25 percent chance of capsizing.

The water level remains elevated until the spell ends or you choose a different effect. If this effect produced a wave, the wave repeats on the start of your next turn while the flood effect lasts.

Part Water. You cause water in the area to move apart and create a trench. The trench extends across the spell's area, and the separated water forms a wall to either side. The trench remains until the spell ends or you choose a different effect. The water then slowly fills in the trench over the course of the next round until the normal water level is restored.

Redirect Flow. You cause flowing water in the area to move in a direction you choose, even if the water has to flow over obstacles, up walls, or in other unlikely directions. The water in the area moves as you direct it, but once it moves beyond the spell's area, it resumes its flow based on the terrain conditions. The water continues to move in the direction you chose until the spell ends or you choose a different effect.

Whirlpool. This effect requires a body of water at least 50 feet square and 25 feet deep. You cause a whirlpool to form in the center of the area. The whirlpool forms a vortex that is 5 feet wide at the base, up to 50 feet wide at the top, and 25 feet tall. Any creature or object in the water and within 25 feet of the vortex is pulled 10 feet toward it. A creature can swim away from the vortex by making a Strength (Athletics) check against your spell save DC.

When a creature enters the vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage and is caught in the vortex until the spell ends. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage, and isn't caught in the vortex. A creature caught in the vortex can use its action to try to swim away from the vortex as described above, but has disadvantage on the Strength (Athletics) check to do so.

The first time each turn that an object enters the vortex, the object takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage; this damage occurs each round it remains in the vortex.

materials.value: A drop of water and a pinch of dust.

Suggestion.name: Suggestion
Suggestion.description:
You suggest a course of activity (limited to a sentence or two) and magically influence a creature you can see within range that can hear and understand you. Creatures that can't be charmed are immune to this effect. The suggestion must be worded in such a manner as to make the course of action sound reasonable. Asking the creature to stab itself, throw itself onto a spear, immolate itself, or do some other obviously harmful act ends the spell.

The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it pursues the course of action you described to the best of its ability. The suggested course of action can continue for the entire duration. If the suggested activity can be completed in a shorter time, the spell ends when the subject finishes what it was asked to do.

You can also specify conditions that will trigger a special activity during the duration. For example, you might suggest that a knight give her warhorse to the first beggar she meets. If the condition isn't met before the spell expires, the activity isn't performed.

If you or any of your companions damage the target, the spell ends.

materials.value: A snake's tongue and either a bit of honeycomb or a drop of sweet oil

Tongues.name: Tongues
Tongues.description: This spell grants the creature you touch the ability to understand any spoken language it hears. Moreover, when the target speaks, any creature that knows at least one language and can hear the target understands what it says.

materials.value: A small clay model of a ziggurat

Water Walk.name: Water Walk
Water Walk.description:
This spell grants the ability to move across any liquid surface—such as water, acid, mud, snow, quicksand, or lava—as if it were harmless solid ground (creatures crossing molten lava can still take damage from the heat). Up to ten willing creatures you can see within range gain this ability for the duration.

If you target a creature submerged in a liquid, the spell carries the target to the surface of the liquid at a rate of 60 feet per round.

materials.value: A piece of cork

Dominate Person.name: Dominate Person
Dominate Person.description:
You attempt to beguile a humanoid that you can see within range. It must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be &Reference[charmed] by you for the duration. If you or creatures that are friendly to you are fighting it, it has advantage on the saving throw.

While the target is charmed, you have a telepathic link with it as long as the two of you are on the same plane of existence.
