[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or contract a &Reference[disease]{disease}.

Until the disease is cured, the target can’t regain hp, and its hp maximum decreases by 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) every 24 hours.

This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest after the disease is cured. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0.

Diseased.name: Diseased
Diseased.description:
The target contracts a &Reference[disease]{disease}.

Until the disease is cured, the target can’t regain hp, and its hp maximum decreases every 24 hours.

Paralyzing Bolt.name: Paralyzing Bolt
Paralyzing Bolt.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[paralyzed apply=false]{paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

save.condition: When hit

Paralyzed.name: Paralyzed
Paralyzed.description: The target is &Reference[paralyzed apply=false]{paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

Animating Worms.name: Animating Worms
Animating Worms.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] touches the body of a dead Humanoid, passing on some of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s worms. The worms fill the target, animating it as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.nU8GN8La8DCt8SDb]{skeleton} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NAISFPoNNgUCsEyW]{zombie} (the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s choice) under the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s control.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Young Spinosaurus.name: Young Spinosaurus
Young Spinosaurus.description:
This massive, blue-skinned saurian lumbers out of the river, depositing a platoon of armed lizardfolk on the bank before releasing a terrifying roar.

Friend to Lizardfolk. The spinosaurus is a special saurian bred for size and loyalty by lizardfolk. Lizardfolk prize them like prime warhorses, and lavish them with food and care. As spinosauruses age slowly, most large lizardfolk tribes have several young spinosauruses and one adult spinosaurus in their care, reserving the massive adult for major engagements or when the entire tribe must move at once.

Enormous Size and Color. This immense saurian has a long, tooth-filled maw, powerful claws, and colorful spines running the length of its back. An adult spinosaurus is 70 feet long and weighs 35,000 pounds or more, while a young spinosaurus is a mere 20 feet long, weighing 6,000 pounds or more.

Swift Predator. A spinosaurus is at home on both land and water, chasing prey from one to the other when necessary. Though they are carnivores, they have an affinity for lizardfolk and other reptilian humanoids, eating such creatures only if the creatures horribly mistreat them or if they experience extreme starvation with such creatures as the only option for food.

Spinosauruses in the Southlands

The lizardfolk of Veles-Sa in the Southlands use spinosauruses as a mode of transportation. The creatures are large enough to pull barges or to carry a crew of raiders anywhere on the rivers, and they are swift overland. Lizardfolk scouts are especially fond of these enormous reptiles, as they are powerful combatants and can carry a dozen lizardfolk warriors.

In addition to their role as trained raiders in Veles-Sa, some spinosauruses live in or along most of the major river systems of the Southlands—including the River Nuria. There they are also called “river dragons” or sometimes “river walkers,” and they are frequently associated with the worship of Baal-Hotep and Set. They are kept as sacred animals in several river temples, where they are fed regular meals and have been known to grow to enormous size and strength.

Finally, along the Spice Coast, spinosauruses carry high-value spice cargoes along the coast when banditry is rife or when a lizardfolk mercenary company is available to guard materials going north toward Mhalmet, Nuria, or Ishadia. These Spice Coast beasts are often especially bred for gaudy coloration: green-and-orange, blue-and-gold, and even red-and-black bloodlines have been spotted in the Spice Coast harbors.

Spinosauruses as Mounts

Spinosauruses mate each year in the winter. A male spinosaurus brings food and helps build an enormous nest of reeds, sticks, and mud. Then the male departs, leaving the female to lay and care for the eggs. Spinosaurus eggs are typically found in nests along riversides or deep in marshes. They are sometimes stolen and sold, generally to lizardfolk and sometimes to daring humans with a knack for training animals. These eggs are worth as much as 2,000 gp apiece; live young are worth twice that. Characters eager for spinosaurus mounts, however, should note that buying or domesticating such an enormous carnivore requires vast quantities of food and patience. They do not take easily to domestication.

Before it can be ridden in combat, a spinosaurus must practice bearing the weight of its trainer and passengers. They rarely master more than a handful of tricks, but they are extremely comfortable in the water and can be trained to be are aware that some of their riders may not breathe water.

An adult spinosaurus can carry up to six tons as cargo. Riding a spinosaurus requires an exotic saddle, riding platform, or howdah.

Hold Breath.name: Hold Breath
Hold Breath.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can hold its breath for 1 hour.

Reptilian Affinity.name: Reptilian Affinity
Reptilian Affinity.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] never willingly attacks a reptilian Humanoid, such as a lizardfolk or dragonborn, unless attacked first.

If magically forced to attack such a creature, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls against it.

This trait doesn’t function if the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s rider or tamer directs it to attack.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and one [[/item Claw]] attack.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]].

If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 15).

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, and the spinosaurus can’t Bite another target.

Grappled & Restrained.name: Grappled & Restrained
Grappled & Restrained.description:
If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 15).

Until this grapple ends, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}.

Fraughashar.name: Fraughashar
Fraughashar.description:
This slight creature resembles a goblin, but its blue skin and the icicles hanging from the tip of its long nose speak to the chilling truth.

The fraughashar are a race of short, tricky, cruel fey who inhabit cold mountainous regions. Fraughashar have light blue skin, short pointed ears, and needlelike teeth. Delighting in mayhem, they always seem to have devilish grins on their faces.

Sacred Rivers. The fraughashar view cold rivers and river gorges as sacred places in which their wicked god Fraugh dwells, and they likewise revere the snowy peaks where the Snow Queen (see page 184) holds sway. They are fiercely protective of their territory, and their easy mobility over frozen and rocky terrain lets them make short work of intruders.

Chilling Tales. The origin of the strange and deadly fraughashar is unclear. Some druidic legends claim the fraughashar were born out of a winter so cold and cruel that the spirits of the river itself froze. Bardic tales claim that the fraughashar are a tribe of corrupted goblins, and that they were permanently disfigured during a botched attempt at summoning an ice devil. Whatever the truth of their beginnings, the fraughashar are cruel and merciless. They kill anyone who enters their land.

Leather Armor.name: Leather Armor
Leather Armor.description: The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.

Shield.name: Shield
Shield.description: A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.

Deft Snow Walk.name: Deft Snow Walk
Deft Snow Walk.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can move across icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check, and difficult terrain composed of ice and snow doesn’t cost it extra movement.

In addition, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it prone while in icy or snowy terrain.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The fraughashar makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and one [[/item Dagger]] attack.

Vættir.name: Vættir
Vættir.description:
The creature’s blue-black skin is stretched taut over its bones, and its lips are drawn back in a cruel grimace. It holds a bronze axe high over its head, and its eyes glow an icy blue.

Servants of the Land. Servants of the land, vættir haunt those who disrespect the wild or ancient laws and traditions. Regardless of where they’re found, vættir always wear ancient mail and carry bronze axes.

Jealous and Wrathful. A wrathful vættir rises from its burial mound when its grave goods are stolen or when it is disrespected. Vættir jealously guard both honor and treasures, and they may be relentless enemies over matters as small as an accidental word or a single coin.

Dangerous Helpers. Vættirs will answer a summons for aid by descendants or nearby villages. Summoned vættir wander into longhouses or taverns and sit down beside those who call them, ready to serve. However, there’s always a price, and a vættir’s help is often more than bargained for.

Chain Shirt.name: Chain Shirt
Chain Shirt.description: Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearer's upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers.

Grave Goods Sense.name: Grave Goods Sense
Grave Goods Sense.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can pinpoint the location of creatures wearing or carrying one of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s personal items or grave goods within 60 feet of it, and the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can sense the general direction of its personal items and grave goods within 1 mile of it.

Rejuvenation.name: Rejuvenation
Rejuvenation.description:
A destroyed [[lookup @name lowercase]] gains a new body in 24 hours, regaining all its hp and becoming active again.

The new body forms in a random unoccupied space within 100 feet of where it fell.

This trait doesn’t function if the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is put to rest (typically by returning its remains to its burial mound).

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can use its [[/item Disorienting Gaze]].

It then makes two [[/item Vættir’s Greataxe]] or [[/item Necrotic Bolt]] attacks.

Disorienting Gaze.name: Disorienting Gaze
Disorienting Gaze.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] locks eyes with one creature it can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

The target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} 1 minute.

While incapacitated, the creature moves in a random direction when it moves.

An incapacitated creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature’s saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Disorienting Gaze for the next 24 hours.

Incapacitated.name: Incapacitated
Incapacitated.description:
The target is &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} 1 minute.

While incapacitated, the creature moves in a random direction when it moves.

An incapacitated creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Corpse Breath.name: Corpse Breath
Corpse Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] spews forth a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]‑foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]] of putrid gas.

Each creature in the area must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t poisoned.

A poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description:
The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute.

A poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Sunlight Sensitivity.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
Sunlight Sensitivity.description: While in sunlight, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Young Flame Dragon.name: Young Flame Dragon
Young Flame Dragon.description:
The dragon bears black scales, more charred than naturally colored. Cracks between the scales glow a dull red, until the dragon rears its head and roars. Red embers become bright orange flames as the creature lights up from tail to maw.

Flame dragons are capricious creatures, fascinated by dark emotions and destructive passions. The dragons of eternal fire are proud and jealous, quick to anger, and utterly unforgiving. They bring total ruin to entire civilizations for trivial reasons, but their true motivation is the fun to be had. These burning serpents treat rage, deceit, and despair as toys for their amusement. “May you be the fire’s plaything” is a curse often used by the foolish.

Taunting Others. The hot-blooded creatures tease their victims like cats, seeing the world and all within it as their rightful prey. Young flame dragons are less subtle than their elders. Wyrmlings may force a woman to watch her family die or ruin a beautiful face for pleasure—direct and evil. As the dragon matures, this natural sadism develops into a desire for more complicated sport. Aging dragons of fire use politics, murder, and magic in elaborate schemes only their ilk can appreciate. Many create plots so intricate and layered that they lack a true resolution, creating only endless manipulation. A hero might foil an assassination only to see the king thus saved become a despot. She might defeat the vizier whispering lies in the ruler’s ear only to discover he was a pawn in a vast conspiracy. Dark ambitions, poisoned daggers, and old vendettas build such momentum that one scheme begins each time another ends. Often, even killing the draconic mastermind cannot extinguish the fires it started.

Malevolent Purpose. The results of a flame dragon’s schemes are secondary to the enjoyment it derives from pursuing a nebulous and ever-changing goal. Some flame dragons spend centuries torturing a family line for nothing more than trespassing on the dragon’s land. Others plot eternal curses after twisting poorly chosen words into dire insults. The vengeance itself is secondary to an excuse for hate, plot, and ruin. Flame dragons relish such opportunities for revenge. Each is a delightful hobby. Any disruption in their game kindles a terrible rage, and in these rare moments of defeat, their anger can be catastrophic. Entire cities burn.

Fond of Souvenirs. Flame dragons are as materialistic and territorial as other true dragons. Each pursues an individual obsession it fixates upon with mad devotion to fill its hoard. Some corrupt innocence, others push nations to war, but they always collect a memento for each victory, petty or grand. One might collect scorched skulls, while another saves the melted treasures of toppled empires. When not out sowing discord, the ancient flame dragons enjoy contemplating their hoards. Every piece reminds them of their own majesty and genius.

Vengeful Brethren. Nothing is safe from a flame dragon’s scheming and narcissism. They crave absolute attention and constant reassurance. Anyone who humiliates a flame dragon would be wiser to kill it. Its survival ensures the dragon’s undivided attention for generations. Wiser still, is to remove all trace of involvement in a flame dragon’s death. All burning serpents see the murder of one of their kin as the gravest insult.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The dragon makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

Fire Incarnate.name: Fire Incarnate
Fire Incarnate.description:
Creatures with resistance to fire damage don’t have resistance to the fire damage dealt by the flame dragon.

A creature with immunity to fire damage is still immune to the dragon’s fire damage.

Heated Body.name: Heated Body
Heated Body.description: A creature that touches the [[lookup @name lowercase]] or hits it with a melee attack while within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it takes [[/damage average]] damage.

Fire Breath.name: Fire Breath
Fire Breath.description:
The dragon exhales fire in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in that area must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Hulking Whelp.name: Hulking Whelp
Hulking Whelp.description:
This gray-skinned dog-like creature seems pathetically eager to please but fantastically skittish, its ears alerting at every nearby sound, and its large oval eyes following anything that passes by.

Emotional Giant. A hulking whelp is a tightly wound ball of emotion, extremely defensive of its personal space and terrified of the world around it. When it feels its personal space is violated, or its fragile concentration is broken, the small, quivery fey grows into a muscled beast of giant proportions.

Calm Friend. When its emotions are under control, a hulking whelp is friendly and even helpful, although this has more to do with its guilt over past actions than a true desire to help others. In its calm form, a hulking whelp is just over three feet tall at the shoulder and weighs 50 pounds. Unleashed, it is 20 feet tall and 4,000 pounds.

Foundry Note

There are two versions of this creature since they look different and are different sizes depending on its state: @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.v6F6ctt6HQozLC3w]{Hulking Welp} (Huge) and @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures.Actor.qmcgendPnZhDqqob]{Welp} (Small).

Frightened Anger.name: Frightened Anger
Frightened Anger.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects that reduce strong emotions, such as the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3MYDjS6k9IYL0aTj]{calm emotions} spell.

Pacify.name: Pacify
Pacify.description:
A friendly creature that has interacted peacefully with the [[lookup @name lowercase]] in its whelp form can try to calm it by speaking firmly and persuasively.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] must be able to hear the creature, who must take an action to make a [[/check format=long]].

If the check succeeds, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] transforms back into its whelp form on its next turn and stops attacking.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes damage before then, it remains in its hulking form and continues attacking.

Unleashed Emotion.name: Unleashed Emotion
Unleashed Emotion.description:
On each of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s turns, it attacks the nearest creature it can see.

If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack for two turns in a row, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] uses [[/item Change Shape]] to return to its whelp form and stops attacking.

Defensive Transformation.name: Defensive Transformation
Defensive Transformation.description: When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is hit with an attack or when a creature it can see or hear within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it threatens to harm it, it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or transform into its hulking canine form (see the [[/item Change Shape]] bonus action).

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The hulking whelp makes two [[/item Slam]] attacks.

Change Shape.name: Change Shape
Change Shape.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] transforms into a Huge, hulking canine or back into its true whelp form, which is Fey. Its statistics, other than its size and creature type, are the same in each form.

Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn’t transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

Adult Cave Dragon.name: Adult Cave Dragon
Adult Cave Dragon.description:
Covered in black spikes, the dragon’s eyeless head swings from side to side. Darkness creeps from its strange, eel-like hide, spreading like ink in water.

Apex predators of the underworld, cave dragons are the stuff of nightmare for creatures with little else to fear. They can speak, but they value silence, speaking rarely except when bargaining for food.

Born to Darkness. Eyeless, these dragons have long, thin spikes that help them navigate tunnels or seal passages around them, preventing foes from outflanking them. Their stunted wings are little more than feelers, useful in rushing down tunnels. Their narrow snouts poke into tight passages, which their tongues scour free of bats and vermin. Young cave dragons and wyrmlings can fly, poorly, but older specimens lose the gift of flight. Cave dragon hide is more like eel skin than reptilian scales, and it grows mottled with brown and black as it ages.

Ravenous Marauders. Cave dragons are always hungry and ready to eat everything. They devour undead, plant creatures, or anything organic. When feeding, they treat all nearby creatures as both a threat and the next course. Alliances they make only last so long as their allies make themselves scarce when the dragon feeds. They can be bribed with food as easily as with gold, but other attempts at diplomacy typically fail. Cave dragons do form alliances with peoples of the underworld, joining them in battle against enemies, but there is always a price to be paid in flesh, bone, and marrow. Wise allies keep a cave dragon well fed.

A Hard Life. Limited food underground makes truly ancient cave dragons almost unheard of. The eldest tend to die of starvation after stripping their territory bare of prey. Their nigh-endless hunger leaves the ancients the most likely of cave dragons to form alliances, especially with allies that promise—and deliver—food. On occasion, cave dragons climb to the surface to feed, but their earthbound, plodding pace leaves them outcompeted by other predators or unable to keep up with swift or flying prey. They prefer tight tunnels where they can ambush and outmaneuver prey.

Edible Hoards and Vertical Lairs. Due to the scarcity of food in their subterranean world, a cave dragon’s hoard may consist largely of food sources: bat colonies, enormous beetles, carcasses in states of decay, a cavern infested with shriekers, and whatever else the dragon doesn’t immediately devour. Cave dragons are fond of bones and items with strong taste or smell. Vast collections of bones, teeth, ivory, and the shells of huge insects litter their lairs, arranged like artful ossuaries. Large vertical chimneys serve as nesting sites for eggs and are popular resting places when a cave dragon sleeps within its lair. Chimneys just wide enough to hold young cave dragons make preferred ambush sites, as the dragons’ tough spikes help hold them in position until prey passes beneath. The oldest cave dragons also retreat to vertical chimneys near nesting sites or within their lairs to die in peace. Stories claim that enormous treasures are heaped up in these ledges, abysses, and other inaccessible locations.

A Cave Dragon’s Lair

Labyrinthine systems of tunnels, caverns, and chasms make up the world of cave dragons. They claim miles of cave networks as their own. Depending on the depth of their domain, some consider the surface world their territory as well, though they visit only to eliminate potential rivals.

Lair Actions

On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row:

  • Cave-In. The ceiling collapses above one creature the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. The creature must make a [[/save dex 15 format=long]]. On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage 3d6 bludgeoning average]] damage and is knocked &Reference[prone]{prone} and buried. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t knocked prone or buried. A buried creature is restrained and unable to breathe or stand up. A creature, including the buried creature, can take an action to free the buried creature by succeeding on a [[/check str 15 format=long]].

  • Release the Vermin. A 20-foot radius sphere of insects appears centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. When a creature enters the cloud of insects for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must make a [[/save con 15 format=long]], taking [[/damage 2d10 piercing average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The cloud of insects lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

  • Split the Earth. A crack appears in the ground within 120 feet of the dragon that is 10 feet long, 10 feet wide, and 20 feet deep. Each creature standing on a spot where the crack opens must succeed on a [[/save dex 15 format=long]] or fall in, taking falling damage. A creature that successfully saves moves with the crack’s edge as it opens. The crack remains open for 1 minute, until the dragon uses this lair action again, or until the dragon dies

Regional Effects

The region containing a legendary cave dragon’s lair is warped by the dragon’s magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

  • Flight of the Beetles. Swarms of vermin within 1 mile of the lair increase in both size and number as their populations try to survive the dragon’s undiscriminating hunger.

  • Toxic Air. Once each hour, poisonous and odorless gases fill random passages and caverns for 1 minute, and just as quickly disperse, within 6 miles of the dragon’s lair.

  • Water Underground. Each time the dragon’s temper flares, but no more often than once every 30 days, flash flooding turns tunnels into death traps as tremors create fissures in the stone within 6 miles of the lair. On the surface, ponds drain away, and long-dry creek beds break their banks in flood.

If the dragon dies, these effects fade over the course of [[/r 1d10]] days.

Darkness Aura.name: Darkness Aura
Darkness Aura.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] emits magical darkness in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]] around it. The darkness moves with the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and spreads around corners. Darkvision can’t penetrate this darkness, and no natural light can illuminate it.

If any of the darkness overlaps with an area of light created by a spell of 4th level or lower, the spell creating the light is dispelled.

At the start of each of its turns, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] chooses whether this aura is active.

A successful @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.15Fa6q1nH27XfbR8]{dispel magic} (DC 14) cast on the [[lookup @name lowercase]] suppresses this aura for 1 minute.

Lair Actions.name: Lair Actions
Lair Actions.description: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description: The dragon can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. The dragon regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If the dragon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

Magical Tunneler.name: Magical Tunneler
Magical Tunneler.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can burrow through any unworked earth and stone.

While doing so, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can choose whether to leave the material it moves through undisturbed or leave a 10-foot diameter tunnel in its wake.

Spiked Climb.name: Spiked Climb
Spiked Climb.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] uses its spikes to hold itself in place while climbing, allowing it to climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

If it climbs upside down on a ceiling or suspends itself on a vertical surface while leaving its claws free, it can’t use the Ruff Spikes reaction.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The dragon uses its [[/item Frightful Presence]]. It then makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]].

Frightful Presence.name: Frightful Presence
Frightful Presence.description:
Each creature of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s choice that is within 120 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and aware of it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature’s saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

Frightened.name: Frightened
Frightened.description: The target is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute, and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Poison Breath.name: Poison Breath
Poison Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales a cone of black, poisonous gas in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each target in that area must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} until it finishes a short rest.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each hour, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description: The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} until it finishes a short rest.

Ruff Spikes.name: Ruff Spikes
Ruff Spikes.description:
When a creature moves to a space within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]], the dragon flares its many feelers and spikes.

The creature must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take [[/damage average]] damage and be prevented from entering that space.

save.condition: When a creature moves to a space within 5 feet of the cave dragon

Limb Sweep.name: Limb Sweep
Limb Sweep.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] sweeps its wingless limbs outward.

Each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take [[/damage average]] damage and be pushed up to 10 feet away from the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Cave-In.name: Cave-In
Cave-In.description:
The ceiling collapses above one creature the dragon can see within 120 feet of it.

The creature must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone} and buried.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t knocked prone or buried.

A buried creature is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained} and unable to breathe or stand up.

A creature, including the buried creature, can take an action to free the buried creature by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]].

Buried, Prone, and Restrained.name: Buried, Prone, and Restrained
Buried, Prone, and Restrained.description: The target is &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone} and buried. A buried creature is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained} and unable to breathe or stand up.

Release the Vermin.name: Release the Vermin
Release the Vermin.description:
A [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot radius [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]] of insects appears centered on a point the dragon can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

When a creature enters the cloud of insects for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The cloud of insects lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

Split the Earth.name: Split the Earth
Split the Earth.description:
A crack appears in the ground within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the dragon that is [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet long, [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet wide, and 20 feet deep.

Each creature standing on a spot where the crack opens must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or fall in, taking falling damage.

A creature that successfully saves moves with the crack’s edge as it opens.

The crack remains open for 1 minute, until the dragon uses this lair action again, or until the dragon dies.

Foundry Note

Scaling is applied to the damage activity when a character falls into the crack. A scale of 1 represents 10 feet, while a scale of 2 indicates 20 feet.

Kishi.name: Kishi
Kishi.description:
This strong and handsome warrior has a snarling hyena’s face at the back of its head.

Dark Appetites. Kishi are two-faced male demons perpetually driven by their voracious appetites, carnal or otherwise, with a predilection for female humanoids. Kishi frequently behead, scalp, or skin their conquests and decorate their shields with their trophies.

Hats and Veils. Kishi demons typically masquerade as muscular warriors or glib storytellers, wearing elaborate headdresses or clan veils to hide the demonic hyena face on the back of their head.

Deadly Charmers. They use magical and nonmagical means of persuasion to inveigle women into their embrace, but their trysts always end in a grisly feast upon their victim’s flesh.

Variant: Demon Summoning

Some kishi demons have the following action option that allows them to summon other demons.

Summon Demon (1/Day). The kishi demon magically calls 1d4 giant hyenas that are Fiends with the kishi’s damage resistances and immunities. It has a 50 percent chance of calling one kishi demon instead. The called creatures arrive in 1d4 rounds, acting as allies of the kishi and obeying its telepathic commands. The creatures remain for 1 hour, until the kishi dies, or until the kishi dismisses them as a bonus action.

Shield.name: Shield
Shield.description: A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.

Fiendish Weapons.name: Fiendish Weapons
Fiendish Weapons.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s weapon attacks are magical.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra 2d8 cold damage (included in the attack).

Two Heads.name: Two Heads
Two Heads.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and on saving throws against being blinded, charmed, deafened, frightened, stunned, and knocked unconscious.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Trophy Shield.name: Trophy Shield
Trophy Shield.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] absorbs some of the essence of a creature it killed since the end of its previous turn and magically creates a grisly trophy of the creature on its shield or spear.

For 1 hour, its Armor Class becomes 20, and creatures of the same type as the slain creature have disadvantage on attack rolls against the kishi.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Spear]] attacks.

Spear.name: Spear
Spear.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]]  or [[/damage twoHanded average]] damage if used with two hands.

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.description:
The kishi casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using [[lookup @attributes.spell.abilityLabel]] as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC [[lookup @attributes.spell.dc]]):

At will: [[/item .IThJJCxjFGIILBF3]]{Detect Evil and Good}, [[/item .vE3zTq4p04VjXUUp]]{Detect Magic}, [[/item .UmdhcaiqaVXtEH0j]]{Suggestion}

3/day: [[/item .pbpkgyb6Tnm0GDVi]]{Glibness}

1/day: [[/item .2iC7b4oTFKmWFwOB]]{Dominate Person}

Detect Evil and Good.name: Detect Evil and Good
Detect Evil and Good.description:
For the duration, you know if there is an aberration, celestial, elemental, fey, fiend, or undead within 30 feet of you, as well as where the creature is located. Similarly, you know if there is a place or object within 30 feet of you that has been magically consecrated or desecrated.

The spell can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.

Detect Magic.name: Detect Magic
Detect Magic.description:
For the duration, you sense the presence of magic within 30 feet of you. If you sense magic in this way, you can use your action to see a faint aura around any visible creature or object in the area that bears magic, and you learn its school of magic, if any.

The spell can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.

Suggestion.name: Suggestion
Suggestion.description:
You suggest a course of activity (limited to a sentence or two) and magically influence a creature you can see within range that can hear and understand you. Creatures that can't be charmed are immune to this effect. The suggestion must be worded in such a manner as to make the course of action sound reasonable. Asking the creature to stab itself, throw itself onto a spear, immolate itself, or do some other obviously harmful act ends the spell.

The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it pursues the course of action you described to the best of its ability. The suggested course of action can continue for the entire duration. If the suggested activity can be completed in a shorter time, the spell ends when the subject finishes what it was asked to do.

You can also specify conditions that will trigger a special activity during the duration. For example, you might suggest that a knight give her warhorse to the first beggar she meets. If the condition isn't met before the spell expires, the activity isn't performed.

If you or any of your companions damage the target, the spell ends.

materials.value: A snake's tongue and either a bit of honeycomb or a drop of sweet oil

Glibness.name: Glibness
Glibness.description: Until the spell ends, when you make a Charisma check, you can replace the number you roll with a 15. Additionally, no matter what you say, magic that would determine if you are telling the truth indicates that you are being truthful.

Dominate Person.name: Dominate Person
Dominate Person.description:
You attempt to beguile a humanoid that you can see within range. It must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be &Reference[charmed] by you for the duration. If you or creatures that are friendly to you are fighting it, it has advantage on the saving throw.

While the target is charmed, you have a telepathic link with it as long as the two of you are on the same plane of existence. You can use this telepathic link to issue commands to the creature while you are conscious (no action required), which it does its best to obey. You can specify a simple and general course of action, such as "Attack that creature," "Run over there," or "Fetch that object." If the creature completes the order and doesn't receive further direction from you, it defends and preserves itself to the best of its ability.

You can use your action to take total and precise control of the target. Until the end of your next turn, the creature takes only the actions you choose, and doesn't do anything that you don't allow it to do. During this time you can also cause the creature to use a reaction, but this requires you to use your own reaction as well.

Each time the target takes damage, it makes a new Wisdom saving throw against the spell. If the saving throw succeeds, the spell ends.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a 6th-level spell slot, the duration is concentration, up to 10 minutes. When you use a 7th-level spell slot, the duration is concentration, up to 1 hour. When you use a spell slot of 8th level or higher, the duration is concentration, up to 8 hours.

Dominate Person.name: Dominate Person
Dominate Person.description: The target is Charmed and must do its best to obey any commands sent by the caster.

Summon Demon (Variant).name: Summon Demon (Variant)
Summon Demon (Variant).description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] magically calls [[/r 1d4]] giant hyenas that are Fiends with the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s damage resistances and immunities.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has a [[/r 1d100cs<=50#A kishi demon is called on a result of 1 instead]]{50 percent chance} of calling one kishi demon instead. The called creatures arrive in [[/r 1d4]] rounds, acting as allies of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and obeying its telepathic commands.

The creatures remain for 1 hour, until the [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies, or until the [[lookup @name lowercase]] dismisses them as a bonus action.

Chance Kishi Demon is Called.name: Chance Kishi Demon is Called
Chance Kishi Demon is Called.chatFlavor: A kishi demon is called on a result of 1 instead

Necrohydra.name: Necrohydra
Necrohydra.description:
Five snaking necks sprout from this decayed, draconic body. However, instead of reptilian heads, each neck ends in a humanoid head.

Necrohydras are created by powerful, evil necromancers and often used as guardians or placed at the vanguard of an undead army to strike fear and despair into the enemy. The wordless, heart-wrenching dirge the creature produces can drain all hope from listeners. The necrohydra can speak, though the few words it croaks out are usually only in response to questions by its master.

Familiar Heads. Sometimes a necrohydra is created as an instrument of revenge or a tool to further damage the morale of a necromancer’s enemies. In these instances, the necromancer uses the heads of humanoids that are familiar to those that will face the necrohydra—heroes, beloved leaders or officers, loved ones, or close allies. A necromancer may coach the necrohydra to say certain mocking phrases to strike at the hearts of the necromancer’s enemies.

Multiple Heads.name: Multiple Heads
Multiple Heads.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has five fleshy heads. While it has more than one head, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against being blinded, charmed, deafened, frightened, stunned, and knocked unconscious.

Whenever the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes 25 or more damage in a single turn, one of its fleshy heads dies. If all its fleshy heads die, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t use [[/item Unnerving Faces]] and can’t use or maintain [[/item Dreadful Dirge]].

At the end of its turn, it grows two skeletal heads for each of its fleshy heads that died since its last turn, unless it has taken radiant damage since its last turn.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] regains [[/heal]] for each skeletal head regrown in this way.

Reactive Heads.name: Reactive Heads
Reactive Heads.description: For each head the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has beyond one, it gets an extra reaction that can be used only for &Reference[opportunity attacks].

Unnerving Faces.name: Unnerving Faces
Unnerving Faces.description:
When a creature the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can see starts its turn within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]], the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can shift the face on one of its fleshy heads to appear like one of the creature’s departed loved ones or mentors.

If the creature can see the [[lookup @name lowercase]], it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[paralyzed apply=false]{paralyzed} with fear until the end of its turn.

Paralyzed.name: Paralyzed
Paralyzed.description: The target is &Reference[paralyzed apply=false]{paralyzed} with fear until the end of its turn.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes as many [[/item Bite]] attacks as it has heads.

Dreadful Dirge.name: Dreadful Dirge
Dreadful Dirge.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s heads emit a cacophonous, moaning wail.

Each creature that isn’t a Construct or Undead within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] that can hear the wail must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} until the wail ends.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue wailing. It can stop wailing at any time.

The wail ends if the necrohydra is incapacitated.

A frightened creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

affects.special: That isn’t a Construct or Undead

Frightened.name: Frightened
Frightened.description:
The target is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} until the wail ends.

A frightened creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Necrotic Bile.name: Necrotic Bile
Necrotic Bile.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] spews rotten bile soaked in necrotic energy in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in that area must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Ghost Knight.name: Ghost Knight
Ghost Knight.description:
The skeleton’s armor creaks as its decaying mount shifts and emits a ghostly whinny. The skeleton sets its lance, skulls dangling from the hilt, and charges.

Servants Beyond Death. Some orders of knighthood require service after death; ghost knights are one such group. Both the willing and the conscripts enter the order as living men and women, and those who serve bravely and loyally for five years or more are “raised up” into the ranks of the undead by their undead lords, becoming fully-fledged ghost knights.

Undead Mounts. To advance through the ranks of the order, the ghost knight accepts the blessing of undeath, which extends to its mount. Riding an undead warhorse (use the statistics of a warhorse skeleton), the ghost knight is a dangerous foe, spearing enemies with its lance and trampling foes under its mount’s hooves.

Locked Saddle.name: Locked Saddle
Locked Saddle.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t be knocked prone, dismounted, or moved against its will while mounted.

Mounted Warrior.name: Mounted Warrior
Mounted Warrior.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is rarely seen without its warhorse skeleton mount.

The warhorse skeleton wears custom barding that raises its Armor Class to 15, and it has immunity to necrotic damage.

While the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is mounted, its mount can’t be charmed or frightened.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect (AE) will be attached to the summoned warhorse skeleton, but it will initially be disabled. After placing the summoned creature on the scene, navigate to its Effects tab in the character sheet and enable the "Barding AC 15" AE. Enabling this effect will update the creature's statistics as described above.

There is another AE on the Mounted Warrior activity that can be applied to the [[lookup @name lowercase]] while mounted, adding the Frightened condition to the character sheet.

Barding AC 15.name: Barding AC 15
Barding AC 15.description: The warhorse skeleton wears custom barding that raises its Armor Class to 15, and it has immunity to necrotic damage.

Charmed/Frightened CI.name: Charmed/Frightened CI
Charmed/Frightened CI.description: While the ghost knight is mounted, its mount can’t be charmed or frightened.

Spirited Charge.name: Spirited Charge
Spirited Charge.description: If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature while mounted and then hits with a Lance attack on the same turn, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can use a bonus action to command its mount to make one melee weapon attack against that creature as a reaction.

Turning Defiance.name: Turning Defiance
Turning Defiance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] and any undead within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=s1GyVPyhcSTuqCzM]] feet of it have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The ghost knight makes three [[/item Battleaxe]] or [[/item Lance]] attacks.

If the ghost knight is mounted, it can make two Battleaxe or Lance attacks, and its mount can make one melee weapon attack.

Half Plate Armor.name: Half Plate Armor
Half Plate Armor.description: Half plate consists of shaped metal plates that cover most of the wearer's body. It does not include leg protection beyond simple greaves that are attached with leather straps.

Necrotic Weapons.name: Necrotic Weapons
Necrotic Weapons.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s weapon attacks are magical.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra 2d6 necrotic damage (included in the attack).

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Battleaxe.name: Battleaxe
Battleaxe.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]]  or [[/damage twoHanded average]] damage if used with two hands.

Tophet.name: Tophet
Tophet.description:
An enormous bronze and iron statue filled with fire towers above the ring of chanting, frenzied worshipers.

Worshipers of fire gods use tophets to incinerate sacrifices in their flaming maws. A tophet has a large opening in the front where the flames can be seen; sometimes this is an enormous mouth, and at other times it is a large hole in the tophet’s belly. Horns and expressions of anger or wide‑mouthed laughter are common.

Eager for Sacrifices. Among fire cultists, it’s widely known that when a tophet’s hands are raised above its mouth, it is demanding a sacrifice to roll down its palms and into its fiery maw.

Heed Musical Commands. Flutes and drums can be used to control the actions of a tophet during sacrifices. They have the fortunate side effect of drowning out the cries and screams of living sacrifices.

Magical Fires. The fires within a tophet’s bronze body are largely magical and fueled by sacrifices. They don’t require more than a symbolic amount of wood or coal to keep burning, but they do require sacrifices of food, cloth, and living creatures to keep them under control. A tophet that is not granted a sacrifice when it demands one might go on a fiery rampage, burning down buildings, granaries, or barns until its hunger is satisfied.

Burning Heart.name: Burning Heart
Burning Heart.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

Each creature in the bright light has resistance to cold damage.

At the start of each of its turns, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] chooses whether this light is active.

Foundry Note

Light is set up in the Prototype Token by default.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Slam]] attacks. It can replace one [[/item Slam]] attack with a use of [[/item Burning Belly]].

Slam.name: Slam
Slam.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC 16) if it is a Large or smaller creature.

Burning Belly.name: Burning Belly
Burning Belly.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Slam]] attack against a target it is grappling as it shoves the creature into its open, flame-filled belly.

If the attack hits, the target is forced into the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s burning belly, and the grapple ends.

While inside the belly, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, has &Reference[three-quarters cover] against attacks and other effects outside the belly, and it takes [[/damage average]] damage at the start of each of its turns.

A creature, including the target, can take its action to pull the target free from the belly by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]]. The creature making the attempt takes [[/damage average]] damage.

Escape the Belly.name: Escape the Belly
Escape the Belly.condition: If a creature is inside the belly of the attacking creature

Restrained.name: Restrained
Restrained.description:
If the attack hits, the target is forced into the burning belly, and the grapple ends.

While inside the belly, the target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, has &Reference[three-quarters cover] against attacks and other effects outside the belly,

Gout of Flame.name: Gout of Flame
Gout of Flame.description:
Flames erupt on a point the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

Each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of that point must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Construct Nature.name: Construct Nature
Construct Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Heated Body.name: Heated Body
Heated Body.description: A creature that touches the [[lookup @name lowercase]] or hits it with a melee attack while within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it takes [[/damage average]] damage.

Library Automaton.name: Library Automaton
Library Automaton.description:
The humming of servos, ticking of gears, and petite discharges of steam precede the library’s diminutive custodian.

Library automatons are small constructs created to fulfill organizational responsibilities of huge libraries.

Eyes of the Past. Each automaton includes a single humanoid eyeball mounted at the end of an articulated appendage. These eyes are typically donations from the library’s ailing scholars, allow them to continue serving the repositories of knowledge that were their life’s work.

Telekinetic. The automatons can move and manipulate written materials telekinetically, and they can store such works in an extradimensional space within their bodies. The library automaton tirelessly pores through tomes, translates ancient texts, catalogs the institution’s volumes, fetches texts for visitors, and occasionally rids the vast halls of uninvited pests.

Scholarly Familiars. Many spellcasters have discovered library automatons make particularly effective caretakers for their spellbooks and scrolls while on adventure.

Library Automaton Familiars

The library automaton’s scholarly nature leads some of them to serve spellcasters and learn more of the world. Such automatons have the following trait (included in this character sheet).

Familiar. The library automaton can serve another creature as a familiar, forming a magic, telepathic bond with that willing companion. While the two are bonded, the companion can sense what the automaton senses as long as they are within 1 mile of each other. While the automaton is within 10 feet of its companion, the companion has resistance to psychic damage. At any time and for any reason, the automaton can end its service as a familiar, ending the telepathic bond.

Bibliophile.name: Bibliophile
Bibliophile.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] understands any written language it can see, provided it is touching the surface on which the words are written.

Bibliotelekinesis.name: Bibliotelekinesis
Bibliotelekinesis.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is surrounded by an invisible, shapeless, magical force that can perform simple tasks at the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s command.

This force has a Strength equal to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Strength, and it can interact with objects up to 15 feet away from the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can use this force to perform simple tasks that a Small humanoid with two hands could do, such as opening a door, moving a bookshelf’s ladder, picking up and organizing books, and similar tasks.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t use this force to make attacks or wield a weapon or shield.

Book Safekeeper.name: Book Safekeeper
Book Safekeeper.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s body contains a small, extradimensional space. This space can hold up to 100 pounds of Small or smaller objects.

This space can hold only books, scrolls, parchment, or other written works on paper or other paper- or wood-like materials.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] is the only creature capable of retrieving items from this space while it is alive.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is destroyed, the objects within its extradimensional space are ejected into an unoccupied space nearest it.

Unnerving Gaze.name: Unnerving Gaze
Unnerving Gaze.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or have disadvantage on the next attack roll, ability check, or saving throw it makes before the start of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s next turn.

Foundry Note

This feature includes an Active Effect (AE) that can be used as a reminder by the target but does not automate the benefits above.

Disadvantage.name: Disadvantage
Disadvantage.description: The target has disadvantage on the next attack roll, ability check, or saving throw it makes before the start of the automaton's next turn.

Familiar (Variant).name: Familiar (Variant)
Familiar (Variant).description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can serve another creature as a familiar, forming a magic, telepathic bond with that willing companion.

While the two are bonded, the companion can sense what the [[lookup @name lowercase]] senses as long as they are within 1 mile of each other.

While the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is within 10 feet of its companion, the companion has resistance to psychic damage.

At any time and for any reason, the automaton can end its service as a familiar, ending the telepathic bond.

Psychic Damage Resistance.name: Psychic Damage Resistance
Psychic Damage Resistance.description: When the familiar is within 10 feet of its companion, the companion has resistance to psychic damage.

Construct Nature.name: Construct Nature
Construct Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Ancient Wind Dragon.name: Ancient Wind Dragon
Ancient Wind Dragon.description:
Howling wind encircles the white- and gray-scaled dragon, filling and pushing its wings without the need for them to beat.

Wind dragons view anywhere touched by air as their property, and mortals point to them as the epitome of arrogance. Their narcissism is not without reason, for awe-inspiring power supports their claims of rightful control. To the dragons of the shifting gales, strength is the ultimate arbiter.

Braggarts and Bullies. Wind dragons number among the greatest bullies and worst tyrants of mortal creatures. The sometimes-foolhardy creatures take offense at any perceived challenge and pleasure in humiliating rivals. They claim great swathes of territory but care little for its governance—they perceive mortals in that territory as possessions. Vassals receive only dubious protection in exchange for their loyalty. A wind dragon might seek bloody vengeance for the murder of a follower, but it’s unlikely to go to any length to prevent the loss of that life in the first place.

Lords of the Far Horizons. Some believe that the dragons of the winds claim much more than they are capable of controlling or patrolling. Because they so love altitude, they prefer to rule and meet with earth-bound supplicants at the highest point available: the summit of a great mountain or atop a towering monument erected by fearful slaves. But these dragons are also driven by wanderlust and roam far from their thrones. They return eventually, ready to subjugate new generations and press a tyrannical claw on the neck of anyone who questions their right to rule.

Perpetual Infighting. These wandering tyrants are even more territorial among their own kind than they are among groundlings. Simple trespass by one wind dragon into the territory of another can lead to a battle to the death. Thus, their numbers never grow large, and the weakest among them are frequently culled.

Portable Hoards. Wind dragons’ hoards typically consist of only a few truly valuable relics. Other dragons might sleep on a bed of coins, but common things bore wind dragons. While all true dragons desire and display great wealth, wind dragons concentrate their riches in a small number of notable trophies or unique historic items—often quite portable.

A Wind Dragon’s Lair

Wind dragons make their lairs where they can overlook and dominate their claims, but the location must be remote enough that inhabitants can’t pester them with requests for protection or justice. As they have little to fear from the elements, a shallow cave high on an exposed mountain face is ideal. Wind dragons enjoy heights dotted with rock spires and tall, sheer cliffs. They perch in the howling wind and catch updrafts and downdrafts sweeping through canyons and tearing across crags.

Lair Actions

On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row:

  • Air Blast. A torrent of wind blasts outward in a 60-foot-radius sphere centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. Each creature in that area must succeed on a [[/save str 15 format=long]] or be knocked &Reference[prone]{prone} and &Reference[stunned]{stunned} until the end of its next turn. Flying creatures, other than wind dragons, have disadvantage on the saving throw.

  • Blinding Wind. Sand and dust swirls up from the ground in a cylinder that is 30 feet tall with a 20-foot radius, centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. The area within the cylinder is &Reference[difficult terrain]. A creature that enters the cylinder for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must succeed on a [[/save dex 15 format=long]] or be &Reference[blinded]{blinded} until the end of its next turn. The cylinder of sand and dust lasts until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

  • Gale Force Smash. A blast of wind slams into a surface of the lair and sends fragments of ice and stone flying out from a point on the ground, wall, or ceiling the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. Each creature within 15 feet of that point must make a [[/save dex 15 format=long]] taking [[/damage 4d8 bludgeoning average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Freedom of Movement.name: Freedom of Movement
Freedom of Movement.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] ignores &Reference[difficult terrain], and magical effects can’t reduce its speed or cause it to be restrained. It can spend 5 feet of movement to escape from nonmagical restraints or being grappled.

Storm Sight.name: Storm Sight
Storm Sight.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can see through areas obscured by fog, mist, clouds, or precipitation.

Whirling Winds.name: Whirling Winds
Whirling Winds.description: Gale force winds rage around the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s body. Arrows, bolts, and other ordinary projectiles launched at the dragon are deflected upward and automatically miss. Boulders hurled by giants or siege engines, and similar projectiles, are unaffected.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The wind dragon uses its [[/item Frightful Presence]]. It then makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

Tempest Breath.name: Tempest Breath
Tempest Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales a blast of stormy wind in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in that area must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is pushed up to 45 feet away from the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t pushed or knocked prone.

Nonmagical flames in the area are extinguished.

Gale Force Smash.name: Gale Force Smash
Gale Force Smash.description:
A blast of wind slams into a surface of the lair and sends fragments of ice and stone flying out from a point on the ground, wall, or ceiling the dragon can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

Each creature within 15 feet of that point must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Lair Actions.name: Lair Actions
Lair Actions.description: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If [[lookup @name lowercase]] fails a saving throw, they can choose to succeed instead.

Frightful Presence.name: Frightful Presence
Frightful Presence.description:
Each creature of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]’s choice that is within 120 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and aware of it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature’s saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

Frightened.name: Frightened
Frightened.description: The target is &Reference[frightened apply=false]{frightened} for 1 minute, and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Wing Attack.name: Wing Attack
Wing Attack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] beats its wings.

Each creature within 10 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take [[/damage average]] damage and be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can then fly up to half its flying speed.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its next turn.

Skitterhaunt.name: Skitterhaunt
Skitterhaunt.description:
This large beetle moves erratically, leaking noxious fluid from its cracked exoskeleton.

Ooze Vermin. This parasitic ooze lives in the shells of monstrous vermin, such as beetles, scorpions, and spiders, which it has infested and killed. A skitterhaunt creature might be mistaken for its original, living version at a glance, but the sluggish, erratic movements and oozing carapace of skitterhaunts quickly reveal their true nature.

Wide Range of Prey. A skitterhaunt infection can decimate whole nests of vermin. When those are in short supply, these oozes move on to prey on other species, such as ants, crabs, and other creatures with exoskeletons or similar hard outer shells.

Hosts Required. Skitterhaunts can’t survive long outside their host creatures; they quickly liquefy and lose their cohesion. A body abandoned by a skitterhaunt is an eerie, hollowed-out husk with a strong, acidic odor.

Broken Shell.name: Broken Shell
Broken Shell.description: A creature that hits the [[lookup @name lowercase]] with a melee attack while within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it takes [[/damage average]] damage.

Vermin Encasement.name: Vermin Encasement
Vermin Encasement.description:
The creature within the vermin’s shell is a shapeless ooze protected by the vermin’s exoskeleton.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is reduced to 0 hp, the exoskeleton breaks, and the [[lookup @name lowercase]] ooze exits it.

Once out of its [[lookup @name lowercase]], the ooze is Small, has an AC of 10, 10 hp, and a speed of 15 feet, and it can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

In addition, its only attack is a Slam that uses the same statistics as its [[/item Sting]], except it deals bludgeoning damage instead of piercing damage.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies if it remains outside of a host for more than 24 hours. It can exit or enter a dead host’s exoskeleton as a bonus action.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Mandibles]] attack and one [[/item Sting]] attack, or it makes two Sting attacks.

Mandibles.name: Mandibles
Mandibles.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} (escape DC [[lookup @skills.ath.passive]]) if it is a Medium or smaller creature.

Until this grapple ends, the creature is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, and the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t use its Mandibles on another target.

Grappled & Restrained.name: Grappled & Restrained
Grappled & Restrained.description:
the target is &Reference[grappled apply=false]{grappled} if it is a Medium or smaller creature.

Infest Vermin.name: Infest Vermin
Infest Vermin.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] infests a Large or smaller Beast with an exoskeleton within 5 feet of it.

The target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or become &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} until the [[lookup @name lowercase]] no longer infests it.

Every 24 hours that elapse, the target must repeat the saving throw or take [[/damage average activity=6gPHOLlCtPwtcwu6]] damage, and its hp maximum is reduced by that amount. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest after the [[lookup @name lowercase]] no longer infests it. The target dies if this reduces its hp maximum to 0.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] then takes control of the body, dissolving the flesh and hiding within the exoskeleton.

A target that succeeds on two consecutive saving throws forces the [[lookup @name lowercase]] out of its body and is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Infest Vermin for the next 24 hours.

Acid Spray.name: Acid Spray
Acid Spray.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] spits acid in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]] that is [[lookup @target.template.width activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet wide.

Each creature in that line must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Bone Collective.name: Bone Collective
Bone Collective.description:
Thousands of tiny bones coalesce into a humanoid form, then disperse in a clattering swarm the next moment. The tiny bones rustle as the creature moves, a quiet sound similar to sand sliding down a dune.

Spies and Sneaks. Bone collectives are not primarily fighters, preferring to spy and skulk. However, when cornered, they fight fearlessly, seeking to strip the flesh from their foes. They wear robes or cloaks to pass as humanoid, as they know that most creatures find them disturbing.

Commanders and Servants of Undeath. Bone collectives’ long finger bones and hooked claws help them ascend and control zombie mounts, and their magic allows them to control small groups of undead. This undead affinity occasionally leads them to serve as spies or spymasters for necromancers, @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures-g.Actor.0o8tN7kL2JZYOYWv]{darakhul} (see page 202), vampires, or liches.

Feed on Society. Bone collectives join societies around them, whether human, goblin, or ghoul. They prey on the living and the dead, to replenish lost bones. They produce a reddish venom that drains the luster of life from victims. Those who survive can describe the horrifying red smile of the collective’s venom-coated fangs.

Collective Mind.name: Collective Mind
Collective Mind.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s individual bones are connected via a hive mind.

It can telepathically communicate with any of its individual bones within 50 miles of it, and it can’t be surprised.

If the collective is reduced to half its hp or fewer, its Intelligence score is reduced to 1, it can’t cast spells, it immediately changes to its shapeless form, and it can’t take on a Humanoid form.

Grasping Limbs.name: Grasping Limbs
Grasping Limbs.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can wield weapons and hold, grasp, push, pull, or interact with objects that might otherwise require a Humanoid form to accomplish.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can occupy another creature’s space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny bone.

Wyrmblood Venom.name: Wyrmblood Venom
Wyrmblood Venom.description:
When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits a poisoned creature with a [[/item Bite]] or [[/item Piercing Bones]] attack, the target’s Charisma score is reduced by [[/r 1d4]].

The target is &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} if this reduces its Charisma to 0.

The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest.

CHA Score -1.name: CHA Score -1
CHA Score -1.description: The target’s Charisma score is reduced by 1. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest.

CHA Score -2.name: CHA Score -2
CHA Score -2.description: The target’s Charisma score is reduced by 2. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest.

CHA Score -3.name: CHA Score -3
CHA Score -3.description: The target’s Charisma score is reduced by 3. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest.

CHA Score -4.name: CHA Score -4
CHA Score -4.description: The target’s Charisma score is reduced by 4. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest.

Shape Swarm.name: Shape Swarm
Shape Swarm.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can shape itself into a Small Humanoid or back into a shapeless form of Tiny bones.

Its statistics are the same in each form, and it can’t regain hp or gain temporary hp. It can’t take on a Humanoid form if it is occupying the space of another creature.

Multiattack.description: The bone collective makes two [[/item Claw]] attacks, or one Claw attack and one [[/item Bite]] attack.

Bite.description:

Humanoid Form Only

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.description:
The bone collective casts the [[/item .dB81ZFIaKHUKbVOR]]{Animate Dead} spell as an action, requiring no material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 14).

Humanoid Form Only

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Animate Dead.name: Animate Dead
Animate Dead.description:
This spell creates an undead servant. Choose a pile of bones or a corpse of a Medium or Small humanoid within range. Your spell imbues the target with a foul mimicry of life, raising it as an undead creature. The target becomes a skeleton if you chose bones or a zombie if you chose a corpse (the DM has the creature's game statistics).

On each of your turns, you can use a bonus action to mentally command any creature you made with this spell if the creature is within 60 feet of you (if you control multiple creatures, you can command any or all of them at the same time, issuing the same command to each one). You decide what action the creature will take and where it will move during its next turn, or you can issue a general command, such as to guard a particular chamber or corridor. If you issue no commands, the creature only defends itself against hostile creatures. Once given an order, the creature continues to follow it until its task is complete.

The creature is under your control for 24 hours, after which it stops obeying any command you've given it. To maintain control of the creature for another 24 hours, you must cast this spell on the creature again before the current 24-hour period ends. This use of the spell reasserts your control over up to four creatures you have animated with this spell, rather than animating a new one.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you animate or reassert control over two additional undead creatures for each slot level above 3rd. Each of the creatures must come from a different corpse or pile of bones.
