Deadly Nobles. A nobleman or woman of the shadow fey is not to be taken lightly—many courtiers or politicians are deadly with their slim blades, and they are known to distill virulent poisons. Often a skilled duelist serves as a champion for her liege, standing in the noble’s stead in challenges or serving as an elite bodyguard.

Duelist’s Mobility.name: Duelist’s Mobility
Duelist’s Mobility.description: &Reference[OpportunityAttacks] made against the [[lookup @name lowercase]] have disadvantage. If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is prone at the start of its turn, it can immediately stand without costing movement.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The shadow fey duelist makes two [[/item Rapier]] attacks and one [[/item Dagger]] attack.

Parry.name: Parry
Parry.description:
The shadow fey duelist adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the duelist must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect (AE) is available to activate the AC bonus on the Effects tab of the character sheet.

Dagger.name: Dagger
Dagger.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and if the target is a creature, it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or become &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute.

A poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Poisoned.name: Poisoned
Poisoned.description:
The target is &Reference[poisoned apply=false]{poisoned} for 1 minute.

A poisoned creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Studded Leather Armor.name: Studded Leather Armor
Studded Leather Armor.description: Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.

Fey Ancestry.name: Fey Ancestry
Fey Ancestry.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can’t put it to sleep.

Sunlight Sensitivity.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
Sunlight Sensitivity.description: While in sunlight, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

Shadow Traveler.name: Shadow Traveler
Shadow Traveler.description:
While in shadows, dim light, or darkness, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] disappears into the darkness and reappears in an unoccupied space it can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet.

A tendril of inky smoke appears at the origin and destination when it uses this bonus action.

Map Mimic.name: Map Mimic
Map Mimic.description:
A treasure map flaps as if caught in a strong wind. It suddenly splits open, revealing a fanged mouth and face.

Mimic Spawn. Mimic adhesive is not just a powerful means of trapping prey, it also contains millions of microscopic larvae that feed on flesh. Most of the larvae are consumed by the mimic when it eats. Mimics are either unaware of this, or they’re indifferent to the fact that they routinely cannibalize their own offspring. A few larvae survive by adhering to the clothing or equipment of someone who escaped from a full-grown mimic’s attack. These larvae hitch a ride, their host taking them far from the dungeon, cavern, or ruin of their birth. There, they drop off and grow into wormlike mimic young called map mimics. In time, map mimics grow into typical mimics.

Smaller than a Dinner Plate. Map mimics are too small to mimic the types of objects their parent does, but they still deceive prey by altering their forms. They can assume the shape, texture, and coloration of anything up to the size of a dinner plate.

Paper Scrolls. Their preferred form is parchment paper. They can display the path they’ve followed on their hide, complete with important landmarks. In this form, they curl up and wait inside bottles, or in the clutches of a corpse in plain view, until an unsuspecting adventurer discovers them. If the mimic is hungry, it attacks and attaches to the finder’s face. Otherwise, it continues its charade as a map, eventually leading the reader back to the parent mimic.

False Appearance.name: False Appearance
False Appearance.description: While the [[lookup @name lowercase]] remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary object.

Life Path.name: Life Path
Life Path.description: Regardless of the form it takes, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can make a map on its surface (no action required) that shows the route it has traveled since it left its parent mimic. The map shows terrain features and landmarks of where it has been, but doesn’t show the names of those places.

Pseudopod.name: Pseudopod
Pseudopod.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and it attaches to the target.

While attached, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t attack, the target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded}, and at the start of each of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s turns, the target takes [[/damage average average=mW5aOsPD1L302dmA]] damage.

The attached [[lookup @name lowercase]] moves with the target whenever the target moves, requiring none of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s movement. It can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement on its turn.

A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the [[lookup @name lowercase]] by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]].

affects.special: The creature the mimic is attached to

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded}.

Change Shape.name: Change Shape
Change Shape.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] transforms into a Tiny object or back into its true, amorphous form. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn’t transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

Firebird.name: Firebird
Firebird.description:
This proud bird struts like a peacock, made all the more majestic by its flaming fan of feathers, which shift through the color spectrum.

Guides and Helpers. Firebirds are welcome sights to those in need of warmth and safety. They primarily work at night or in underground areas, where their talents are most needed. Friendly to all creatures, they become aggressive only upon witnessing obviously evil acts. Firebirds enjoy working with good adventuring parties, providing light and healing, though their wanderlust prevents them from staying for long.

Redeemers. Firebirds enjoy acting as reformers. They search for creatures they perceive as potential “light bringers,” and they grant boons to such creatures, magically coaxing the creatures into performing good deeds in the hope such acts redeem the creatures.

Magical Feathers. Firebird feathers are prized throughout the mortal world, and occasionally, the creatures bestow feathers upon those they favor. Firebirds also seed hidden locations with specialized feathers, which burst into full-grown firebirds after a year. Firebirds live over 100 years.

Enforce Good Deeds.name: Enforce Good Deeds
Enforce Good Deeds.description:
A creature that has received assistance, such as healing or a glowing feather, from the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be affected by the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.JQyigMNPiDnGI18b]{geas} spell for 30 days.

While under the geas, the affected creature must assist nonhostile creatures suffering from starvation or thirst by alleviating the starvation or thirst.

Fiery Weapons.name: Fiery Weapons
Fiery Weapons.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s weapon attacks are magical.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra 2d6 fire damage (included in the attack).

Glowing Feathers.name: Glowing Feathers
Glowing Feathers.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] sheds bright light in a 5- to 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional number of feet equal to the chosen radius.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can alter the radius as a bonus action.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] willingly gifts a feather to a creature, the feather sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet indefinitely.

Foundry Note

Token lighting is not enabled by default, but the light color and effect are pre-set.

An @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-macros.Macro.kgSZSzFEECWolfhC]{application is available} that allows you to set or modify the light radius for the selected creature token in the scene when you're ready. This application can also remove the light settings, effectively turning the light off.

When using the application, select the respective creature from the drop-down.

Warming Presence.name: Warming Presence
Warming Presence.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] and each creature within 5 feet of it are immune to the effects of cold environments, provided the cold is caused by naturally occurring weather and climate.

When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is inside a structure, it can choose for this trait to affect all creatures within the structure (no action required), regardless of how close they are to it.

Cold DI.name: Cold DI
Cold DI.description: While within 5 feet of the firebird, you are immune to the effects of cold environments, provided the cold is caused by naturally occurring weather and climate.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Beak]] attack and one [[/item Talon]] attack.

Blinding Ray.name: Blinding Ray
Blinding Ray.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] fires a burning ray of light from its tail feathers in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot line that is [[lookup @target.template.width activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet wide.

Each creature in that line must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its next turn.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t blinded.

Blinded.name: Blinded
Blinded.description: The target is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} until the end of its next turn.

Healing Feathers.name: Healing Feathers
Healing Feathers.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] touches another creature, brushing its wings against the creature.

The target magically regains [[/heal average]] and is freed from any disease, poison, blindness, or deafness.

Geas.name: Geas
Geas.description:
You place a magical command on a creature that you can see within range, forcing it to carry out some service or refrain from some action or course of activity as you decide. If the creature can understand you, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become &Reference[Charmed] by you for the Duration. While the creature is charmed by you, it takes 5d10 psychic damage each time it acts in a manner directly counter to your instructions, but no more than once each day. A creature that can't understand you is unaffected by the spell.

You can issue any command you choose, short of an activity that would result in certain death. Should you issue a suicidal command, the spell ends.

You can end the spell early by using an action to dismiss it. A Remove Curse, Greater Restoration, or wish spell also ends it.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th or 8th level, the Duration is 1 year. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 9th level, the spell lasts until it is ended by one of the Spells mentioned above.

Geas.name: Geas
Geas.description: The creature is Charmed for the Duration. While the creature is charmed by the caster, it takes psychic damage each time it acts in a manner directly counter to their instructions, but no more than once each day.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Swarm of Sluaghs.name: Swarm of Sluaghs
Swarm of Sluaghs.description:
This tiny humanlike creature has a torso that trails away in place of legs, eyes that are black voids, and long, pale arms ending in sharp claws.

Cowards Alone. These tiny, malevolent fey dwell in darkness. Alone they are cowards, but they are rarely encountered alone. They are most active during the winter, especially during winter’s long nights. They usually speak to their victims as they attack, but those shouts are little more than whispers to the ears of their prey.

Chilling Touch. Sluaghs feed by draining their prey of warmth with their chilling claws. They devour small animals if nothing more appetizing is available, though they prefer humanoid prey. Their victims have unnaturally cold skin with a pale, blue tint. Swarms of sluaghs serve hags, devils, trollkin (see page 371), and evil fey who know the blood rituals to summon and direct them. Shadow fey (see page 158) and drow send them against other elves, often targeting the defenders of elven settlements.

Legless Flocks. Sluaghs are tiny, gaunt humanoid creatures the size of a weasel. They have no legs; instead their torso tapers off in a disquieting way. Though they can fly, they can also pull themselves quickly across the ground with their arms. They are always draped in black, though their actual skin and hair are pale white. They have sharp claws and fangs, and their eyes are entirely black. In masses, they somewhat resemble a flock of strange birds.

Sunlight Weakness.name: Sunlight Weakness
Sunlight Weakness.description:
While in sunlight, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

Foundry Note

This feature includes an Active Effect in the Effect tab that provides disadvantage on ability saves and skill checks. However, there is currently no automation to apply disadvantage to attack rolls at this time.

Sunlight Weakness.name: Sunlight Weakness
Sunlight Weakness.description: The target has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks while in sunlight.

Chilling Touch.name: Chilling Touch
Chilling Touch.description:
Melee Weapon Attack: [[/attack]], reach 0 ft. , one creature in the swarm’s space. [[/damage average extended]], or 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) cold damage if the swarm has half of its hp or fewer.

The target must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be unable to regain hp for 1 minute.

The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Foundry Note

The Save activity includes an Active Effect (AE) that can be used as a reminder by the target but does not automate the above activity.

Unable to Regain HP.name: Unable to Regain HP
Unable to Regain HP.description:
The target is unable to regain hp for 1 minute.

The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Swarm.name: Swarm
Swarm.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can occupy another creature’s space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny fey. The swarm can’t regain hp or gain temporary hp.

Shadow Stealth.name: Shadow Stealth
Shadow Stealth.description: While in dim light or darkness, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes the &Reference[Hide] action.

utility.condition: While in dim light or darkness

Degenerate Titan.name: Degenerate Titan
Degenerate Titan.description:
This giant retains a look of daunting power despite its stooped bearing, tattered clothing, and pieces of slapdash armor strapped on wherever it fits.

Haunt Ruins. The degenerate descendants of @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures-t.Actor.8XG1NhOJvfcgU5YQ]{ancient titans} (see page 361) haunt the ruins where their cities once flourished. These descendants hunt for any living thing to eat, including each other, and sometimes chase after herds of goats or other animals for miles. While they are easily distracted, they always find their way home unerringly.

Insane and Moody. Degenerate titans are prone to erratic actions and unexpected mood shifts. They are fiercely territorial creatures who worship the still-active magical devices of their cities and any surviving statuary as if the statues were gods. Their lairs are filled with items scavenged from the city. These collections are a hodge-podge of dross and delight, as the degenerate titans are not intelligent enough to discern treasure from trash.

Primal Power. Degenerate titans cannot command magical words of power like their ancestors, but they retain a connection to the natural world, allowing them to tap into the earth’s latent mystic power to generate strange geomancy. These devolved misfits may have lost most of their former gifts, but what remains are primal powers that tap, without subtlety or skill, into the fundamental building blocks of the world.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can use its [[/item Reality-Bending Shout]]. It then makes three [[/item Greatclub]] attacks or two [[/item Rock]] attacks.

Rock.name: Rock
Rock.description: Ranged Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, range 60/240 ft. , one target. Hit: 27 ([[/r 4d10 + 5]]) bludgeoning damage.

Reality-Bending Shout.name: Reality-Bending Shout
Reality-Bending Shout.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] utters a scream that vibrates the fabric of reality around one creature it can see within 30 feet of it.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can attempt to end one magical effect of its choice of 3rd level or lower on the target.

This effect works like the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.15Fa6q1nH27XfbR8]{dispel magic} spell, except the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must always make an ability check. The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s ability check for this is +4.

Earthstrike.name: Earthstrike
Earthstrike.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] slams its fists onto the ground, creating a shockwave in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity000]] that is [[lookup @target.template.width activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet wide.

Each creature in the line must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, a creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is flung 20 feet away from the titan and knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}, as the earth buckles and tosses the creature.

On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn’t flung or knocked prone.

If a flung creature strikes a solid surface, the creature takes 3 (1d6) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was flung.

If the creature is flung at another creature, that creature must succeed on a [[/save format=long activity=b5jALOGt4reQf4Tl]] or take the same damage and be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Foundry Note

Damage scaling is implemented in the Damage activity so that you can configure how much damage a character takes. Each scaling value corresponds to 10 feet of movement. For example, a value of 1 = 10 feet and 2 = 20 feet.

Damage: Solid Service.name: Damage: Solid Service
Damage: Solid Service.condition: If a flung creature strikes a solid surface

Armor Scraps.name: Armor Scraps
Armor Scraps.description: This armor consists of a metal chest made of scraps worn with leather.

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Shadow Fey.name: Shadow Fey
Shadow Fey.description:
A gray-skinned elf steps out of the darkness itself. Its pair of onyx horns seems to absorb the light around it. It gives a friendly smile, revealing small fangs.

To most, the shadow fey are little more than a dancing shadow among the leaves. To savants, they are the creatures that taught the shadowdancers all they know—and kept many secrets to themselves. They were once elves like all others, dwelling in mortal lands beneath the sun. An ancient catastrophe drove them to darkness, and now they are creatures of the shadow. Though they can be found on the Material Plane, they are inextricably tied to the Plane of Shadow, and that is the seat of their power and culture. Their bond with darkness allows the shadow fey to slip through distant spaces, traversing darkness itself from one place to another.

Shadow Elves. Shadow fey superficially resemble other elves, but they’re rarely mistaken for their light-bound cousins. Skin tones among the shadow fey range from alabaster white to ebony black, with shades of gray in between, but they otherwise lack color. A few have a scintillating shimmer to their skin. Many shadow fey grow horns that sweep out from their hair, varying in size from subtle nubs to obvious spikes. Others have shocking sets of teeth.

Dual Natured. The shadow fey are contradictory beings. They boast some of the best features of elves, tempered by aspects of a fouler nature. They can be deliberate and purposeful, but they’re also given to perplexing whimsy. Mortal creatures trying to fathom shadow fey motivations are in for a maddening experience; they are often illogical, capricious, and seemingly thrive on annoying others.

Split Rulership. The Summer Court and Winter Court each rule the shadow fey in the appropriate season. The turning of these seasons follows no clear calendar or schedule, though it is skewed toward summer. The Queen of Night and Magic and the Moonlit King each claim dominion in turn, ruling over the Summer and Winter courts respectively.

Chain Shirt.name: Chain Shirt
Chain Shirt.description: Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearer's upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers.

Shadow Traveler.name: Shadow Traveler
Shadow Traveler.description:
While in shadows, dim light, or darkness, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] disappears into the darkness and reappears in an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet.

A tendril of inky smoke appears at the origin and destination when it uses this bonus action.

Fey Ancestry.name: Fey Ancestry
Fey Ancestry.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can’t put it to sleep.

Sunlight Sensitivity.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
Sunlight Sensitivity.description: While in sunlight, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

Nightgarm.name: Nightgarm
Nightgarm.description:
This red-furred lupine creature has a too-wide mouth and blood-soaked claws.

Created in a ritual performed over a pregnant worg, nightgarms are always born female and are followers of the Great Wolf. They are dedicated to harassing the servants of rival gods, sending their spawn to infiltrate and take down settlements dedicated to those gods.

Wide-Jawed Lupines. Nightgarms resemble red-furred worgs with wide mouths, half-formed fingers, and comfort with bipedal and quadrupedal movement. They can hold items in their front paws, and their jaws can open to swallow especially large creatures.

Mother of Falsehearts. If a nightgarm eats a humanoid corpse whole, it gives birth nine hours later to a duplicate of the victim, known as a falseheart (see the Falseheart Template sidebar). Falsehearts are loyal to the nightgarm that birthed them and retain enough of the victim’s memories and capabilities to integrate into society as the victim. One in every thirteen falsehearts is born disloyal to the nightgarm.

Falseheart Template

The corpse of any Humanoid can become a falseheart if eaten whole by a nightgarm. When a Humanoid becomes a falseheart, it retains its statistics, except as described below.

Type. The Humanoid’s type changes to Monstrosity.

Alignment. The falseheart’s alignment changes to chaotic evil.

Damage Vulnerabilities. The falseheart is vulnerable to radiant damage.

New Trait: Convincing Copy. A creature very familiar with the Humanoid the falseheart replaced can tell the falseheart is an imitation with a successful DC 20 Wisdom (Insight) check.

New Trait: Keen Smell. The falseheart has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

New Trait: Mother’s Love. The falseheart is magically bound to the nightgarm that birthed it, following the nightgarm’s telepathic commands.

Telepathic Bond.name: Telepathic Bond
Telepathic Bond.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] ignores the range restriction on its telepathy when communicating with a falseheart it has birthed. The [[lookup @name lowercase]] and its falseheart don’t need to be on the same plane of existence.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

Bite.name: Bite
Bite.description:
[[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]]. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be swallowed.

A swallowed creature is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} and &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the [[lookup @name lowercase]], and it takes [[/damage average activity=Gk0xFFX64t2C5Phb]] damage at the start of each of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s turns.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can have only one creature swallowed at a time.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes 20 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must succeed on a [[/save format=long activity=6Pgc1TZ8czGjlaWM]] at the end of that turn or regurgitate the creature, which falls &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone} in a space within 5 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies, a swallowed creature is no longer restrained by her and can escape from the corpse by using 10 feet of movement, exiting &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone.

Save: 20+ Damage.name: Save: 20+ Damage
Save: 20+ Damage.condition: If the nightgarm takes 20 damage or more on a single turn from the swallowed creature

Escape Corpse.name: Escape Corpse
Escape Corpse.condition: Must use 10 feet of movement to escape

Swallowed.name: Swallowed
Swallowed.description: A swallowed creature is &Reference[blinded apply=false]{blinded} and &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the nightgarm.

Prone.name: Prone
Prone.description: A swallowed creature escaping the stomach of the nightgarm lands &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Lupine Howl.name: Lupine Howl
Lupine Howl.description:
The nightgarm magically calls [[/r 2d4]] @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.yawTeS8u2FCfzzZH]{wolves} or 2 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.EYiQZ3rFL25fEJY5]{dire wolves}.

The wolves arrive in [[/r 1d4]] rounds, acting as allies of the nightgarm and obeying her telepathic commands.

The wolves remain for 1 hour, until the nightgarm dies, or until the nightgarm dismisses them as a bonus action.

Falseheart Template.name: Falseheart Template
Falseheart Template.description:
The corpse of any Humanoid can become a falseheart if eaten whole by a nightgarm. When a Humanoid becomes a falseheart, it retains its statistics, except as described below.

Type. The Humanoid’s type changes to Monstrosity.

Alignment. The falseheart’s alignment changes to chaotic evil.

Damage Vulnerabilities. The falseheart is vulnerable to radiant damage.

New Trait: [[/item Convincing Copy]]. A creature very familiar with the Humanoid the falseheart replaced can tell the falseheart is an imitation with a successful DC 20 Wisdom (Insight) check.

New Trait: [[/item Keen Smell]]. The falseheart has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

New Trait: [[/item Mother’s Love]]. The falseheart is magically bound to the nightgarm that birthed it, following the nightgarm’s telepathic commands.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect (AE) is available to apply the Falseheart's traits to the affected humanoid.

The three New Traits detailed above will need to be manually dragged and dropped into the affected humanoid's character sheet. Feel the remove Falseheart Template from the title of the feature.

affects.special: The corpse of any Humanoid eaten whole by a nightgarm

Falseheart Template: Convincing Copy.name: Falseheart Template: Convincing Copy
Falseheart Template: Convincing Copy.description:
This feature is part of the Falseheart Template and it is not a feature for the Nightgarm

A creature very familiar with the Humanoid the falseheart replaced can tell the falseheart is an imitation with a successful [[/check format=long]].

affects.special: A creature very familiar with the Humanoid the falseheart replaced

Falseheart Template: Keen Smell.name: Falseheart Template: Keen Smell
Falseheart Template: Keen Smell.description:
This feature is part of the Falseheart Template and it is not a feature for the Nightgarm

The falseheart has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

Falseheart Template: Mother’s Love.name: Falseheart Template: Mother’s Love
Falseheart Template: Mother’s Love.description: The falseheart is magically bound to the nightgarm that birthed it, following the nightgarm’s telepathic commands.

Scheznyki.name: Scheznyki
Scheznyki.description:
The small, dwarf-like creature is bootless with broken, dirty toenails and wearing rough burlap and a leather tam hat. It brandishes a pick as it grins maliciously.

Corrupted Dwarves. These small, vicious, dwarf-like fey haunt abandoned quarries and ancient ruins, killing and robbing unsuspecting visitors. Legend says the scheznykis are lazy dwarves corrupted by the fey, though others claim that these are dwarves who swore allegiance to fey lords and ladies long ago.

Magical Hats. Scheznykis prize their tam hats and viciously hunt down any who steal their hats. When a scheznyki dies or if its hat is separated from it for more than 24 hours, some of the scheznyki’s magic imbues the hat (see Scheznyki’s Hat sidebar).

Arcane Beards. The majority of a scheznyki’s magic is tied to its beard, and its beard hair is a valuable component for creating exotic inks. If the majority of its beard is cut off, the scheznyki can’t cast spells until its beard regrows. If the scheznyki loses its hat and beard within the same 24-hour period, it falls into a deep, wasting coma and dies in 24 hours, crumbling to dust. If its beard is magically mended or regrown, or its hat restored to its head before this happens, the scheznyki recovers immediately.

Scheznyki’s Hat

When a scheznyki dies or 24 hours after its hat is stolen, its hat is imbued with the scheznyki’s magic and becomes a vanisher hat.

@UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.kp-tob1-2023-items.Item.oIfZL8IaXKQJx3Be]{Vanisher Hat}

Wondrous Item, Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This plain hat appears to be a rough burlap tam. A creature that can see through illusions sees the hat as a golden, bejeweled coronet. While wearing this hat, you can use an action to speak its command word to become invisible and gain a flying speed of 40 feet for up to 1 minute. Anything you are wearing or carrying is invisible with you. You remain invisible and capable of flying until you repeat the command word as an action or until you attack or cast a spell. Once used, the hat can’t be used again until the next dawn.

Beard Weakness.name: Beard Weakness
Beard Weakness.description:
A creature grappling the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can take its action to cut off the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s beard by succeeding on a [[/check format=long]] while holding an edged weapon.

If its beard is cut off, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t use [[/item Spellcasting]] until its beard regrows.

Invisibility.name: Invisibility
Invisibility.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] magically turns &Reference[invisible apply=false]{invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell, or until its &Reference[concentration] ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment it wears or carries is invisible with it.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes three [[/item War Pick]] or [[/item Arcane Bolt]] attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of [[/item Spellcasting]].

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using [[lookup @attributes.spell.abilityLabel]] as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC [[lookup @attributes.spell.dc]]):

At will: [[/item .ZqL54olDLMoPLfAj]]{Dancing Lights}, [[/item .IcH5qlLPlG5LHcn5]]{Faerie Fire}

3/day each: [[/item .nLzIR9zfAK3ikerF]]{Hideous Laughter}, [[/item .W2a0LeqBaSXG7K4I]]{Locate Object}, [[/item .ow2dDFdkzkqrIkLZ]]{Ray of Enfeeblement}

1/day each: [[/item .7ZBlU0Mzg23Uz5Ua]]{Dispel Magic}, [[/item .khEhLqcjDhHEur9y]]{Hold Person}

Vanisher Hat.name: Vanisher Hat
Vanisher Hat.description:
Wondrous Item, Uncommon (Requires Attunement)

This plain hat appears to be a rough burlap tam. A creature that can see through illusions sees the hat as a golden, bejeweled coronet.

While wearing this hat, you can use an action to speak its command word to become invisible and gain a flying speed of 40 feet for up to 1 minute. Anything you are wearing or carrying is invisible with you.

You remain invisible and capable of flying until you repeat the command word as an action or until you attack or cast a spell.

Once used, the hat can’t be used again until the next dawn.

Brute.name: Brute
Brute.description: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the [[lookup @name lowercase]] hits with it (included in the attack).

Magic Resistance.name: Magic Resistance
Magic Resistance.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Dancing Lights.name: Dancing Lights
Dancing Lights.description:
You create up to four torch-sized lights within range, making them appear as torches, lanterns, or glowing orbs that hover in the air for the duration. You can also combine the four lights into one glowing vaguely humanoid form of Medium size. Whichever form you choose, each light sheds dim light in a 10-foot radius.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the lights up to 60 feet to a new spot within range. A light must be within 20 feet of another light created by this spell, and a light winks out if it exceeds the spell's range.

materials.value: A bit of phosphorus or wychwood, or a glowworm

Faerie Fire.name: Faerie Fire
Faerie Fire.description:
Each object in a 20-foot cube within range is outlined in blue, green, or violet light (your choice). Any creature in the area when the spell is cast is also outlined in light if it fails a Dexterity saving throw. For the duration, objects and affected creatures shed dim light in a 10-foot radius.

Any attack roll against an affected creature or object has advantage if the attacker can see it, and the affected creature or object can't benefit from being invisible.

Locate Object.name: Locate Object
Locate Object.description:
Describe or name an object that is familiar to you. You sense the direction to the object's location, as long as that object is within 1,000 feet of you. If the object is in motion, you know the direction of its movement.

The spell can locate a specific object known to you, as long as you have seen it up close—within 30 feet—at least once. Alternatively, the spell can locate the nearest object of a particular kind, such as a certain kind of apparel, jewelry, furniture, tool, or weapon.

This spell can't locate an object if any thickness of lead, even a thin sheet, blocks a direct path between you and the object.

materials.value: A forked twig

Hideous Laughter.name: Hideous Laughter
Hideous Laughter.description:
A creature of your choice that you can see within range perceives everything as hilariously funny and falls into fits of laughter if this spell affects it. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or fall prone, becoming Incapacitated and unable to stand up for the Duration. A creature with an Intelligence score of 4 or less isn't affected.

At the end of each of its turns, and each time it takes damage, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. The target has advantage on the saving throw if it's triggered by damage. On a success, the spell ends.

materials.value: Tiny tarts and a feather that is waved in the air

Ray of Enfeeblement.name: Ray of Enfeeblement
Ray of Enfeeblement.description:
A black beam of enervating energy springs from your finger toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target deals only half damage with weapon attacks that use Strength until the spell ends.

At the end of each of the target's turns, it can make a Constitution saving throw against the spell. On a success, the spell ends.

Dispel Magic.name: Dispel Magic
Dispel Magic.description:
Choose one creature, object, or magical effect within range. Any spell of 3rd level or lower on the target ends. For each spell of 4th level or higher on the target, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. On a successful check, the spell ends.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you automatically end the effects of a spell on the target if the spell's level is equal to or less than the level of the spell slot you used.

Hold Person.name: Hold Person
Hold Person.description:
Choose a humanoid that you can see within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be &Reference[paralyzed] for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target.

Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional humanoid for each slot level above 2nd. The humanoids must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

materials.value: A small, straight piece of iron

Hold Person.name: Hold Person
Hold Person.description: The target is Paralyzed for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target.

Sea Dragon Wyrmling.name: Sea Dragon Wyrmling
Sea Dragon Wyrmling.description:
This aquamarine dragon has a shark’s head that tapers off into a sleek eel-like body. Its large fins double as wings.

Divine Dragons. Sea dragons are the children of the ocean and believe they are semi-divine beings, worthy of worship. Given their size and power, they might be right; certainly, they are often companions or steeds to gods of the sea. Despite the solemn duties the sea dragons invoke thanks to their lineage, they are extremely whimsical. While these immense creatures are playful, their games can shatter hulls and drown sailors. The sea dragons course through the waves with tangible joy as they hunt whales and entire schools of tuna.

Shipwreck Art. Sea dragons love collecting treasure. They especially prize the sunken, treasure-filled hulls of ships lost to storm, battle, or their own handiwork. While they appreciate all wealth, they prefer hardy items that stand up to long exposure to sea water. Precious metals and gemstones add a dramatic luster to the dragon’s lair when they catch stray beams of light. Sea dragons take more perishable treasures and place them on a reef-altar, to dissolve in the sea as a tithe to the sea gods.

Sunken Memorials. A sea dragon’s lair is littered with meticulously arranged ships consigned to the deeps. These wrecks are often artfully smashed to allow the treasures in the hold to spill out onto the sea floor. It may seem haphazard, but it displays a complex aesthetic that only other sea dragons can truly appreciate. Because they arrange these wrecks so carefully, a dragon notices immediately if its hoard is disturbed.

Priests of Seggotan

Every sea dragon is devoted to the dragon god of the sea. As a result, many sea dragons use the innate spellcasting variant. Sea dragons favor spells that manipulate water or the weather, emulate storms, deal lightning or cold damage, divine the future, or conjure sea creatures to fight alongside the dragon.

Sea Dragons in Midgard

Sea dragons are the offspring of Seggotan, the dragon god of time and the sea. A sea dragon shares its god’s idea that everything in the sea is the property of Seggotan, and they expect lesser beings to respect that truth.

The sea dragons are among the most powerful allies of the Mharoti Empire, securing seaways and acting as a communion point for the tidal priests. Thankfully for the Empire’s enemies, the most ancient sea dragons are too consumed with contemplation of time and their inscrutable duties in the depths of the ocean to make war.

Amphibious.name: Amphibious
Amphibious.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can breathe air and water.

Tidal Breath.name: Tidal Breath
Tidal Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales a crushing wave of frigid seawater in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type capitalize activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in that area must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, the creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is pushed up to 45 feet away from the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}

On a success, the creature takes half the damage and isn’t pushed or knocked prone.

Spark.name: Spark
Spark.description:
This mote of electrical energy floats menacingly, erupting in a shower of sparks and tendrils of lightning. When it disappears, it leaves only the whiff of ozone.

Born in Storms. When a great storm rips across a world in the Material Plane, it sometimes tears loose the fabric of reality, releasing sentient creatures composed entirely of elemental energy. Occasionally when a spark forms, an oppositely charged mate is created at the same time. When this happens, the two always stay within 300 feet of one another.

Seek Hosts. Fueled by its frenetic thought patterns and erratic actions, a spark jolts through its new world to find a physical body, drawn by an urge to know form. Some spellcasters deliberately seek out sparks for symbiosis. Spellcasters devoted to deities or study of the elements may reach an agreement with sparks, allowing the elementals to ride within their bodies for the sparks’ lifetime. Sparks rarely survive longer than a year, even within a symbiotic relationship with a mortal form. When they expire, they wink out and return to the elemental planes.

Elemental Nature.name: Elemental Nature
Elemental Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes three [[/item Electric Touch]] attacks.

Inhabit.name: Inhabit
Inhabit.description:
One Humanoid that the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it must succeed on a [[/save format=long activity=dnd5eactivity000]] or be inhabited by the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] then disappears, fusing with the target’s nervous system, and the target is &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} and loses control of its body. The [[lookup @name lowercase]] now controls the body but doesn’t deprive the target of awareness.

MORE

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, and it retains its alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, immunity to being paralyzed, petrified, or unconscious, and its Electric Touch attack. It otherwise uses the inhabited target’s statistics, but doesn’t gain access to the target’s knowledge, class features, or proficiencies.

Every 24 hours that elapse, the target must succeed on a [[/save format=long activity=d2vGEGYTP3VxqAYG]] or take [[/damage average activity=d2vGEGYTP3VxqAYG]] damage, and its hp maximum is reduced by that amount. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest after the [[lookup @name lowercase]] no longer inhabits it. The target dies if this reduces its hp maximum to 0.

Each time the [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes an [[/item Electric Touch]] attack and at the end of each long rest, the target can make a [[/save format=long activity=euQo8rdOjmNH9on0]], expelling the [[lookup @name lowercase]] on a success. Alternatively, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can exit the target’s body as a bonus action or can be forced out by an effect like the protection from energy spell.

The target is immune to this [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Inhabit for 24 hours after succeeding on the saving throw or after the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is expelled.

A willing target retains full function of its body, doesn’t need to make a Constitution saving throw every 24 hours, has immunity to lightning damage, and can communicate with the [[lookup @name lowercase]] telepathically.

If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] inhabits a willing target, it takes its turn at the same time as the target, but the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can attack only as a reaction to a creature moving within 5 feet of the target or as a reaction to the target attacking a creature within 5 feet of it.

Foundry Note

Active Effects (AEs) are available to be applied to an unwilling or willing target that grants the abilities described above. You will also need to manually drag the Electric Touch feature and drop it into the target's sheet; however, Electric Touch is a reaction when used by willing creatures.

Save: Expel Creature.name: Save: Expel Creature
Save: Expel Creature.condition: Each time the spark attacks with its Electric Touch and at the end of each long rest

Inhabited (Unwilling).name: Inhabited (Unwilling)
Inhabited (Unwilling).description: The target is &Reference[incapacitated apply=false]{incapacitated} and loses control of its body if they are unwilling to be inhabited.

Inhabited (Willing).name: Inhabited (Willing)
Inhabited (Willing).description: A willing target retains full function of its body, doesn’t need to make a Constitution saving throw every 24 hours, has immunity to lightning damage, and can communicate with the spark telepathically.

Ancient Void Dragon.name: Ancient Void Dragon
Ancient Void Dragon.description:
A dragon seemingly formed of the night sky has bright white stars for eyes. Lesser stars twinkle in the firmament of the dragon’s body.

Children of the Stars. Void dragons drift through the empty spaces beyond the boundaries of the mortal world and wander between the stars. They are aloof, mingling only with the otherworldly beings that live above and beyond the earth, including the incarnate forms of the stars themselves. When lesser creatures visit void dragons, the dragons barely notice.

Witnesses to the Void. Void dragons are intensely knowledgeable creatures. But they have seen too much, lingering at the edge of the Void itself. Gazing into the yawning nothing takes a toll. Void dragons carry a piece of that nothing with them, and it slowly devours their being. They are all unhinged, and their madness is contagious. It flows out of them to break the minds of lesser beings when the dragons fly into a rage and lash out.

Voracious Scholars. Despite their removed existence and strange quirks, Void dragons still hoard treasure. Gems that glitter like the stars of their home are particularly prized. Their crowning piece, however, is knowledge. Void dragons jealously hoard scraps of forbidden and forgotten lore of any kind and spend most of their time at home poring over these treasures. Woe to any who disturbs this collection, for nothing ignites their latent madness like a violation of their hoard.

A Void Dragon’s Lair

The true lair of a Void dragon exists deep in the freezing, airless space between stars. Hidden away in caves on silently drifting asteroids or shimmering atop the ruins of a Star Citadel, the Void dragon’s lair rests in the great Void of space.

When a Void dragon claims a home elsewhere, it forges a connection to its true lair. It prefers towering mountain peaks, valleys, or ruins at high elevation with a clear view of the sky. It can reach through space from this lair to its treasure hoard hidden in the Void. That connection has repercussions, of course. The most powerful Void dragons leave their mark on the world around them when they roost. Intrusions from beyond and a thirst for proscribed knowledge are common near their lairs.

When encountered in its lair, an adult Void dragon has a challenge rating of 17 (18,000 XP), and the ancient Void dragon has a challenge rating of 25 (75,000 XP).

Lair Actions

On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragon takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragon can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row:

  • Orb of the Void. The Void briefly overlaps the dragon’s lair in a 20-foot-radius sphere of blackness punctuated by deep blue streaks and pinpoints of light. The sphere is centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of the dragon. The sphere spreads around corners, is heavily obscured, and contains no air (creatures must hold their breath). Each creature in the sphere when it appears must make a [[/save con 15 format=long]], taking [[/damage 3d6 cold average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Any creature that ends its turn in the sphere takes [[/damage 3d6 cold average]] damage. The sphere lasts until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

  • Spatial Anomaly. The lair’s connection to the Void briefly rips the fabric of space, forcing two creatures the dragon can see within 120 feet of it to suddenly exist at the same point in space and time. The laws of reality repel the creatures back to their original positions as reality resets. The targets aren’t actually moved, but reality’s reset forces each target to make a [[/save str 15 format=long]]. On a failure, the creature takes [[/damage 3d10 force average]] damage and is knocked &Reference[prone]{prone}. On a success, the creature takes half the damage and isn’t knocked prone.

  • Zero Gravity. Gravity stops working in a 50-foot radius, 100-foot-high cylinder centered on a point the dragon can see within 120 feet of it. Each creature in that cylinder drifts 10 feet away from the ground and must succeed on a [[/save str 15 format=long]] or be &Reference[restrained]{restrained}. A flying creature automatically succeeds on the saving throw, but its speed is halved unless it can hover or flies magically. This effect lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

Regional Effects

The region containing a legendary Void dragon’s lair is warped by the dragon’s magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

  • Dark of the Void. Nonmagical illumination, including sunlight, can’t create bright light within 6 miles of the lair.

  • Torn Veil. Within 3 miles of the lair, disembodied voices whisper in the night. Celestials, Fey, and Fiends with a challenge rating of 2 or lower can choose to slip into the Material Plane from their native planes or vice versa.

  • Uncovered Knowledge. Secrets have a way of coming to light within 6 miles of the lair. Clues are inadvertently discovered, slips of the tongue hint at a hidden truth, and creatures become morbidly curious for forbidden knowledge.

If the dragon dies, these effects fade over the course of [[/r 1d10]] days.

Chill of the Void.name: Chill of the Void
Chill of the Void.description:
Creatures with resistance to cold damage don’t have resistance to the cold damage dealt by the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

A creature with immunity to cold damage is still immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s cold damage.

Collapsing Star.name: Collapsing Star
Collapsing Star.description:
When the [[lookup @name lowercase]] dies, it explodes in a swath of celestial destruction.

Each creature within 1,000 feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must make a [[/save format=long]], taking 55 ([[/r 10d10]]) bludgeoning damage and 55 ([[/r 10d10]]) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried take half the bludgeoning damage.

A creature that fails the saving throw by 5 or more is ejected to a random location on a random plane of existence or [[/r 5d100]] miles away from its current location in a random direction (GM’s choice).

Expert Void Traveler.name: Expert Void Traveler
Expert Void Traveler.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, sleep, or ambient pressure. While traveling in the Void, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] magically glides on solar winds, covering immense distances in short times.

Void Twist.name: Void Twist
Void Twist.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] adds 7 to its AC against one attack that would hit it, as it twists reality to open a small rift in space to protect itself.

To do so, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] must be able to see the attacker.

If the attack misses by 5 or more, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can choose to open a second, connected rift next to another creature it can see within 30 feet of it to direct the attack at that creature instead, using the original attack roll result against the new target’s AC.

Foundry Note

An Active Effect (AE) can be enabled in the Effects tab of the character sheet to apply the AC bonus, or it can be applied to your token via chat.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The dragon uses its [[/item Aura of Madness]]. It then makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claw]] attacks.

Void Slip.name: Void Slip
Void Slip.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] twists the fabric of space around it, disappearing and reappearing in an unoccupied space it can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

Each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the dragon must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take [[/damage average]] damage and be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Aura of Madness.name: Aura of Madness
Aura of Madness.description:
Each creature of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s choice that is within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]] and aware of it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or suffer @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.tables.RollTable.ypk2L9feVwTx0QVj]{short-term madness} for 1 minute.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

If a creature’s saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s Aura of Madness for the next 24 hours.

Short-Term Madness.name: Short-Term Madness
Short-Term Madness.description: The target succumbs to short-term madness for 1 minute.

Breath Weapons.name: Breath Weapons
Breath Weapons.description:
The dragon uses one of the following breath weapons (configured individually in Actions).

  • [[/item Gravitic Breath]]

  • [[/item Stellar Breath]]

Stellar Breath.name: Stellar Breath
Stellar Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales star fire in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type capitalize activity=dnd5eactivity000]].

Each creature in that area must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[//damage average]] damage and [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Orb of the Void.name: Orb of the Void
Orb of the Void.description:
The Void briefly overlaps the dragon’s lair in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity300]]-foot-radius [[lookup @target.template.type activity=dnd5eactivity300]] of blackness punctuated by deep blue streaks and pinpoints of light.

The sphere is centered on a point the dragon can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity300]] feet of the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

The sphere spreads around corners, is heavily obscured, and contains no air (creatures must hold their breath).

Each creature in the sphere when it appears must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Any creature that ends its turn in the sphere takes [[/damage average activity=FOO]] damage.

The sphere lasts until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

Spatial Anomaly.name: Spatial Anomaly
Spatial Anomaly.description:
The lair’s connection to the Void briefly rips the fabric of space, forcing two creatures the dragon can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it to suddenly exist at the same point in space and time.

The laws of reality repel the creatures back to their original positions as reality resets. The targets aren’t actually moved, but reality’s reset forces each target to make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, the creature takes [[/damage average]] damage and is knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}

On a success, the creature takes half the damage and isn’t knocked prone.

Zero Gravity.name: Zero Gravity
Zero Gravity.description:
Gravity stops working in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot radius, [[lookup @target.template.height activity=dnd5eactivity000]]-foot-high cylinder centered on a point the dragon can see within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it.

Each creature in that cylinder drifts 10 feet away from the ground and must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}

A flying creature automatically succeeds on the saving throw, but its speed is halved unless it can hover or flies magically.

This effect lasts until initiative count 20 on the next round.

Restrained.name: Restrained
Restrained.description: The target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained} until initiative count 20 on the next round.

Legendary Actions.name: Legendary Actions
Legendary Actions.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn.

The [[lookup @name lowercase]] regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

Legendary Resistance.name: Legendary Resistance
Legendary Resistance.description: If [[lookup @name lowercase]] fails a saving throw, they can choose to succeed instead.

Lair Actions.name: Lair Actions
Lair Actions.description: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the [[lookup @name lowercase]] can’t use the same effect two rounds in a row.

Gravitic Breath.name: Gravitic Breath
Gravitic Breath.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] exhales localized gravity in a [[lookup @target.template.size activity=8hO4xW2jpg9rdIt8]]-foot [[lookup @target.template.type activity=8hO4xW2jpg9rdIt8]], originating from the [[lookup @name lowercase]].

When a creature ends a fall in the cube, it takes 1d10 bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d10.

A creature that enters the cube for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a [[/save format=long]].

On a failure, the creature is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}

On a success, the creature’s speed is halved as long as it remains in the cube.

A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

The cube lasts for 1 minute.

Foundry Note

The Exhale Localized Gravity activity has several effects when used:

  1. It consumes one use of the feature.

  2. It changes the name of the activity from “Exhale Localized Gravity” to “Dissipate Localized Gravity.”

  3. It reveals the “Falling Damage” activity within the feature, allowing you to roll damage. Scaling is set up in this activity, allowing you to specify the distance a creature falls within the cube to calculate damage. An increment of 1 indicates 10 feet, 2 indicates 20 feet, and so on.

  4. It reveals the “Save” activity within the feature, which you can use for creatures that enter the cube for the first time or start their turn there.

  5. Clicking on “Dissipate Localized Gravity” will hide the “Falling Damage” & “Save” activities, and revert the name to “Exhale Localized Gravity.”

Save.name: Save
Save.condition: Enters the cube for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must

Falling Damage.name: Falling Damage
Falling Damage.condition: When a creature ends it turn in the cube

Restrained.name: Restrained
Restrained.description: The target is &Reference[restrained apply=false]{restrained}, and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Half Speed.name: Half Speed
Half Speed.description: The target's speed is halved as long as it remains in the cube.

Jaculus.name: Jaculus
Jaculus.description:
This small dragon has feathered wings on its forearms and clings with powerful claws to a tree.

The jaculus (plural jaculi) is a draconic predator similar to a small wyvern that roams the forest and jungle looking for valuable objects it can add to its hoard. Also called the javelin snake, a jaculus loves shiny or reflective items, and it is clever enough to identify items of real value. It will fight and kill to take items it desires, which it stashes inside hollow trees far from any forest trail.

Leapers. Jaculi are far better jumpers than flyers. They climb faster than they fly, and they use their wings to flap clumsily back into the trees only when necessary.

Teamwork Thievery. Jaculi are among the least intelligent of the dragons, but they’re still smarter than most humans. They’re known to pursue cunning and complicated plots to build their hoards. Many traditional tales tell of jaculi in the southern forests working as teams to separate merchants and other travelers from their wealth, figuring out ways to abscond with gems and jewelry before the owners even know they’ve been robbed. Some jaculi may feign docility or even pretend to be friendly and helpful, but wise travelers know that the creatures drop such ruses as soon as they can steal what they’re seeking.

Spearhead.name: Spearhead
Spearhead.description:
If the [[lookup @name lowercase]] moves at least [[lookup @range.value activity=IIWsrQAo8vksHGJS]] feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a [[/item Bite]] attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra [[/damage average]] damage.

If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or be knocked &Reference[prone apply=false]{prone}.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and two [[/item Claws]]{Claw} attacks.

Standing Leap.name: Standing Leap
Standing Leap.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s long jump is up to 20 feet and its high jump is up to 10 feet, with or without a running start.

Burrowling.name: Burrowling
Burrowling.description:
These light brown, furred creatures inquisitively survey their surroundings, each comforted by the presence of the others.

Friendly Farmers. Burrowlings work together at every task: digging tunnels, foraging, and rearing their young. They are omnivorous, eating roots, berries, insects, and reptiles—and they consider snakes a particular delicacy. The most advanced burrowling towns set up rudimentary farms, where they grow the fruits and vegetables they usually find in the wild.

Safe Warrens. Some towns have domesticated prairie dogs, which burrowlings train to stand watch alongside their masters. Pairs of adults stand watch around the town perimeter and sound a warning when they spot a foe. An alerted town retreats to the safety of its warrens, while the strongest creatures add more tunnels if necessary, and close access from the surface until the threat has passed. In combat, burrowlings stand together in defense of the helpless young and fight with crude slings or their sharp teeth and claws.

Die of Loneliness. If separated from its coterie, a burrowling becomes despondent, crying for others of its kind. A lone burrowling usually dies of loneliness within a week, unless it can find its way back to its town or discover another burrowling town. Rarely, a solitary creature makes its way to a non-burrowling settlement where it attempts to assist its new community. This frustrates the creature and those it interacts with as it tries to anticipate what its companions want. It may join an adventuring party in the hope of returning to a settlement. After spending at least six months with a party, the burrowling can use its Burrow Awareness with its new allies. Burrowlings live up to 15 years and can have a litter of pups up to twice a year. A burrowling pup reaches adulthood in a year.

Burrowlings in Midgard

Burrowling towns are found in the Western Wastes, where their greatest enemies are dust goblins. They seem to thrive in the badlands and magically scant territories of former human settlements.

Burrow Awareness.name: Burrow Awareness
Burrow Awareness.description: A [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks if at least one other [[lookup @name lowercase]] within 10 feet of it isn’t incapacitated.

Pack Tactics.name: Pack Tactics
Pack Tactics.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn’t incapacitated.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The burrowling makes one [[/item Bite]] attack and one [[/item Claw]] attack.

Weeping Treant.name: Weeping Treant
Weeping Treant.description:
This twisted tree’s face is made of cracked, black bark knotted into vaguely humanoid features, and thick tears of sap run down its face.

Weeping treants clearly are related to other treants, but they are smaller than the normal variety. Their gnarled trunks are twisted, and their wood often groans when they move.

Forest Wardens. Weeping treants are protectors of dark, shadowy forests—particularly forests in the Plane of Shadow—and they are as long-lived as the trees themselves. They act as guardians for an entire forest or for something specific within the forest, and they have no pity for those carrying axes or fire.

Skeptical Mein. Weeping treants are terrifying and relentless when fighting in defense of their charge. They are inherently distrustful, particularly of anything not of the natural or shadow world, and they’re notoriously difficult to fool or deceive.

Enchanted Bitter Tears. Sages and scholars debate why these creatures weep, but no one has come forward with a compelling reason beyond “it’s what trees do.” The weeping treants themselves refuse to speak on the matter. Their tears are occasionally components in druidic spells or items.

Speak with Plants.name: Speak with Plants
Speak with Plants.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] can communicate with plants as if they shared a language.

Weep Acid.name: Weep Acid
Weep Acid.description:
Thick tears of dark, acidic sap stream continuously down the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s face and trunk.

A creature that touches the [[lookup @name lowercase]] or hits it with a melee attack while within [[lookup @range.value activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of it must succeed on a [[/save format=long]] or take [[/damage average]] damage.

save.condition: Touch or hit with a melee attack

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Slam]] or [[/item Rock]] attacks.

Slam.name: Slam
Slam.description: [[/attack extended]]. [[/damage average extended]], and the target takes [[/damage average activity=VHCumde0cPT5Iyzz]] damage at the end of its next turn unless it or another creature takes an action to wipe off the acid.

affects.special: with the sticky acid affixed to them

Siege Monster.name: Siege Monster
Siege Monster.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] deals double damage to objects and structures.

Mavka.name: Mavka
Mavka.description:
With burnt and blackened skin, burnt twigs for hair, and clawed hands and feet that resemble burnt and twisted roots, this creature appears scorched and even frail. Pupilless red eyes gleam in its sockets with a hellish green flame.

Mavkas are twisted dryads created by undead warlocks and vampiric experiments.

Death Riders. Mavkas ride nightmares and are fearsome raiders, snatching victims up into the saddle, never to be seen again. They despise and trample foot soldiers as peasants unworthy of attention.

Hag Killers. Mavkas are the mortal enemies of @UUID[Compendium.kp-tome-of-beasts-1-2023.tob-1-2023-creatures-h.Actor.HAFIqDFsTXZ0XTpT]{red hags} (see page 228), who call these undead horrors “greenbanes.” When red hag covens discover vampires and other undead turning local dryads into mavkas, they go on a rampage, destroying all undead they encounter.

Mavkas in Midgard

There were once three dryad sisters named Mica, Anthelia, and Saramantha. After his conquest of Morgau, the Black Prince Lucan had the dryads and their trees killed and then raised the corpses as powerful undead—mavkas. His warlocks bonded the new undead with nightmares instead of trees to complete their corruption.

These three sisters have since spawned many more such undead fey. Some serve the Black Prince as generals or concubines, while others pursue their own ends, destroying vampires, laying waste to villages, and seeking power in the Shadow Realm.

Mounted Warrior.name: Mounted Warrior
Mounted Warrior.description: While the [[lookup @name lowercase]] is mounted, her mount can’t be charmed or frightened.

Charmed/Frightened CI.name: Charmed/Frightened CI
Charmed/Frightened CI.description: While the ghost knight is mounted, its mount can’t be charmed or frightened.

Nightmare Mount.name: Nightmare Mount
Nightmare Mount.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] has formed a bond with a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.5SgVGhQBswgWRwsF]{nightmare}.

The nightmare acts as a controlled mount while carrying the [[lookup @name lowercase]], obeying the [[lookup @name lowercase]]'s spoken commands.

Mounting and dismounting the nightmare costs the [[lookup @name lowercase]] only 5 feet of movement.

Multiattack.name: Multiattack
Multiattack.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] makes two [[/item Enervating Slam]] attacks or three [[/item Necrotic Bolt]] attacks.

If she is riding a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.5SgVGhQBswgWRwsF]{nightmare}, the nightmare can then make one Hooves attack.

If both Enervating Slam attacks hit one creature, the [[lookup @name lowercase]] regains hp equal to the total necrotic damage dealt by both attacks.

Flame Burst.name: Flame Burst
Flame Burst.description:
While riding a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.5SgVGhQBswgWRwsF]{nightmare}, the mavka channels her power into her mount, causing its fiery light to burn those nearby.

Each creature within [[lookup @target.template.size activity=dnd5eactivity000]] feet of the mavka must make a [[/save format=long]], taking [[/damage average]] damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
Spellcasting.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using [[lookup @attributes.spell.abilityLabel]] as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC [[lookup @attributes.spell.dc]]):

At will: [[/item .QuIvpJp62rNQlHdy]]{Create or Destroy Water}, [[/item .yoYLnGB8TkqXbZHx]]{Dancing Lights}

3/day each: [[/item .jWDaGOtY7XDrNXTK]]{Darkness}, [[/item .BTUjxd7vXWJ7t5wE]]{Hold Person}, [[/item .DKRG2FHAAZcVAmff]]{Silence}

1/day each: [[/item .WDNd8upYpWlzHdcl]]{Bestow Curse}, [[/item .AzZIJqPY3refJatL]]{Dispel Magic}

Undead Nature.name: Undead Nature
Undead Nature.description: The [[lookup @name lowercase]] doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Create or Destroy Water.name: Create or Destroy Water
Create or Destroy Water.description:
You either create or destroy water.

Create Water. You create up to 10 gallons of clean water within range in an open container. Alternatively, the water falls as rain in a 30-foot cube within range.

Destroy Water. You destroy up to 10 gallons of water in an open container within range. Alternatively, you destroy fog in a 30-foot cube within range.

Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you create or destroy 10 additional gallons of water, or the size of the cube increases by 5 feet, for each slot level above 1st.

materials.value: A drop of water if creating water or a few grains of sand if destroying it.

Dancing Lights.name: Dancing Lights
Dancing Lights.description:
You create up to four torch-sized lights within range, making them appear as torches, lanterns, or glowing orbs that hover in the air for the duration. You can also combine the four lights into one glowing vaguely humanoid form of Medium size. Whichever form you choose, each light sheds dim light in a 10-foot radius.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the lights up to 60 feet to a new spot within range. A light must be within 20 feet of another light created by this spell, and a light winks out if it exceeds the spell's range.

materials.value: A bit of phosphorus or wychwood, or a glowworm

Darkness.name: Darkness
Darkness.description:
Magical darkness spreads from a point you choose within range to fill a 15-foot-radius sphere for the duration. The darkness spreads around corners. A creature with darkvision can't see through this darkness, and nonmagical light can't illuminate it.

If the point you choose is on an object you are holding or one that isn't being worn or carried, the darkness emanates from the object and moves with it. Completely covering the source of the darkness with an opaque object, such as a bowl or a helm, blocks the darkness.

If any of this spell's area overlaps with an area of light created by a spell of 2nd level or lower, the spell that created the light is dispelled.

materials.value: Bat fur and a drop of pitch or piece of coal

Hold Person.name: Hold Person
Hold Person.description:
Choose a humanoid that you can see within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be &Reference[paralyzed] for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target.

Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional humanoid for each slot level above 2nd. The humanoids must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

materials.value: A small, straight piece of iron

Hold Person.name: Hold Person
Hold Person.description: The target is Paralyzed for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target.

Silence.name: Silence
Silence.description: For the Duration, no sound can be created within or pass through a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within range. Any creature or object entirely inside the sphere is immune to thunder damage, and creatures are Deafened while entirely inside it. Casting a Spell that includes a verbal component is impossible there.

Dispel Magic.name: Dispel Magic
Dispel Magic.description:
Choose one creature, object, or magical effect within range. Any spell of 3rd level or lower on the target ends. For each spell of 4th level or higher on the target, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. On a successful check, the spell ends.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you automatically end the effects of a spell on the target if the spell's level is equal to or less than the level of the spell slot you used.

Bestow Curse.name: Bestow Curse
Bestow Curse.description:
You touch a creature, and that creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become cursed for the duration of the spell. When you cast this spell, choose the nature of the curse from the following options:

  • Choose one ability score. While cursed, the target has disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with that ability score.
  • While cursed, the target has disadvantage on attack rolls against you.
  • While cursed, the target must make a Wisdom saving throw at the start of each of its turns. If it fails, it wastes its action that turn doing nothing.
  • While the target is cursed, your attacks and spells deal an extra 1d8 necrotic damage to the target.

A remove curse spell ends this effect. At the DM's option, you may choose an alternative curse effect, but it should be no more powerful than those described above. The DM has final say on such a curse's effect.

At Higher Levels. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the duration is concentration, up to 10 minutes. If you use a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the duration is 8 hours. If you use a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the duration is 24 hours. If you use a 9th level spell slot, the spell lasts until it is dispelled. Using a spell slot of 5th level or higher grants a duration that doesn't require concentration.

Cursed Charisma.name: Cursed Charisma
Cursed Charisma.description: The target has Disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with the chosen ability.

Cursed Constitution.name: Cursed Constitution
Cursed Constitution.description: The target has Disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with the chosen ability.

Cursed Dexterity.name: Cursed Dexterity
Cursed Dexterity.description: The target has Disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with the chosen ability.

Cursed Intelligence.name: Cursed Intelligence
Cursed Intelligence.description: The target has Disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with the chosen ability.

Cursed Strength.name: Cursed Strength
Cursed Strength.description: The target has Disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with the chosen ability.

Cursed Wisdom.name: Cursed Wisdom
Cursed Wisdom.description: The target has Disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with the chosen ability.

Cursed Attacks.name: Cursed Attacks
Cursed Attacks.description: The target has Disadvantage on attack rolls against you.

Cursed Actions.name: Cursed Actions
Cursed Actions.description: In combat, the target must succeed on a [[/save ability=wis dc=@attributes.spell.dc format=long]] at the start of each of its turns or be forced to take the &Reference[Dodge] action on that turn.

Cursed Resilience.name: Cursed Resilience
Cursed Resilience.description: If you deal damage to the target with an attack roll or a spell, the target takes an extra [[/damage 1d8 type=necrotic]] damage.

Sunlight Hypersensitivity.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
Sunlight Hypersensitivity.description:
The [[lookup @name lowercase]] takes [[/damage]] when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

Foundry Note

This feature includes an Active Effect in the Effects tab that applies disadvantage on ability checks. However, there is currently no automation to apply disadvantage to attack rolls at this time.

Sunlight Hypersensitivity.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
Sunlight Hypersensitivity.description: The target has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks while in sunlight.
